4. There are nevertheless three common threads which run through all the discussion of the last 18 months. First, a recognition that there is an important role for Government in support of the arts. Secondly, that over the last ten years or so there has been substantial growth in the arts industry and a massive increase in State and local government arts support. Thirdly, our present mechanisms for support must adapt to these changes.

5. In a ministerial statement to the House of Representatives on arts policy on 17 October 1985, I pointed with some pride to the level of support for the arts provided by this Government since it came to office. I make no apology for repeating some of those points today. This Government has increased funding to the Australia Council for arts support by nearly 51 per cent since it came to office. At the same time, through the community employment program and the bicentennial program, in excess of $46m has been allocated to the arts and related activities. Here I am talking only of the arts in a narrow way. Support for film, especially through the taxation system, has reached its highest levels. New buildings are under way for the National Institute of Dramatic Art and the Australian Film, Television and Radio School. Major expenditures have been provided for the various Commonwealth cultural authorities, notably the Australian National Gallery, the National Film and Sound Archive, the National Library of Australia and the National Maritime Museum.

6. The McLeay committee's report provides a most comprehensive and objective analysis. It provides a valuable framework for decision-making on the arts now and in the future. It has carefully reviewed the role of the Australia Council and its relationship to government and offers some creative and innovative ideas for assistance to the arts and individual artists. The Government is most grateful for the committee's thoughtful contribution.

7. Many of the committee's views are shared by the Australia Council whose comments on the committee's report and proposals for change are included in the document I have just tabled. There are some differences in emphasis and on the means of implementing change, reflecting the differing perspectives. By and large the Government agrees with most of the recommendations of both the committee and council although we have taken a further position on some issues. There is complete agreement on future directions.

8. Government support for the arts is based on a recognition that artistic expression is an integral part of society. Programs of arts support have been aimed at the development of excellence in a diverse range of arts practices and experience, and at fostering wide access to, and participation in, arts activities. The Government agrees with the committee and council that arts support should continue to head in these directions.

9. The Government also believes that an arts support body established by statute is an integral part of this process. The Australia Council whose considerable achievements are well recognised and whose initiatives have caused so much to prosper in the arts will continue to play a key role in their future development.
10. Both council and the committee recognise however that some changes are necessary to clarify council's relationship to government and to other players in the game.

11. There is now general acceptance in the community that a statutory body such as the Australia Council must have regard to relevant government policies and priorities and to the roles and activities of other Commonwealth, State and local agencies. Consistent with the Government's approach to statutory authorities a power of general ministerial direction will be included in the legislation. However, this power of direction will not apply to decisions on grants and will be subject to tabling in the parliament and comment in the council's annual report. This represents a reaffirmation in statutory form of the Government's belief in the arrangement whereby decisions on arts grants are made at `arms length' from government.

12. The committee recommended also that policy control by the Government be ensured by ministerial approval of estimates under each program of the council itself and its boards. I believe this goes too far. The Government has agreed that in the future the estimates of the council will be approved on a three line basis (direct assistance, other services to the arts and administration) supplemented by a report from the council relating its proposed allocation of resources to government policies and priorities.

13. These changes will provide a solid basis for the council's relationship with government and ensure that the `arms length' and `peer review' processes are maintained. They will also facilitate implementation of agreements with the states and territories and through the cultural ministers council. Implementation of the decisions of the cultural ministers council calls for agreement by government rather than its instrumentalities.

14. The Government also had before it recommendations from both the committee and the council relating to the council's structure and its grant administration process. The Government has accepted the view that changes are needed and that there should be a streamlining of the structure and administration of the council.

15. I issued press releases on 16 and 19 December last year, inviting public comment over a three month period on the Government's plans to revitalise arts support mechanisms and policies for the next decade.

16. I have now received advice from the council and comments from interested persons in the community on restructuring the council. The variety of views expressed have been carefully analysed and considered in the formulation of the new structure. Council's advice follows a long period of consultation with the arts community and its response is a matter of public knowledge.
17. The new structure will comprise:
A fifteen member council made up of a chairman, all board chairmen, arts practitioners and broad public interest representatives. Government representatives will no longer be on council.

Members of the council and boards will continue to be appointed by the Governor-General and minister respectively and boards will be directly accountable to council. Like the council, board representation will reflect artistic and broad public interests. Board membership numbers will be altered to provide for a minimum of five up to a maximum of nine members on the boards.
The number of boards will be reduced from eight to five:
a five member literary arts board;
a five member design board;
a nine member performing arts board integrating the present theatre and music boards;
a nine member visual arts/craft board integrating the present crafts and visual arts boards; and
a nine member aboriginal arts board.
Council will advise the Minister on board appointments and have ultimate responsibility for community arts development.

18. To this end a new community cultural development unit will be created which will comprise the chairman of council, all board chairmen and six other members appointed by the Minister in consultation with the council. The membership of this unit will be carefully chosen to ensure wide representation of community arts activities in the states and territories and the broad public interest.

19. This new structure will elevate council's community arts focus and provide for integration with the activities of the artform boards. The functions and funding role of the community arts board would transfer to the new unit which will have a broader brief to foster community cultural development.

20. In my press releases I outlined a major organisations unit to be set up by council as an administrative unit to monitor the financial and artistic performance of major arts organisations. This proposal was a recommendation of council and the McLeay Report. Council has now given further thought to how such a unit would work and has proposed an alternative which the government endorses.

21. At present the council receives approximately 10,000 applications for grants each year. Many of these are from organisations which it has supported for a number of years in the past and which in all probability, if funds are available, it will continue to support in the future. It is apparent therefore that not all organisations need to be assessed every year, nor should they need to make application every year. Therefore, council will adopt a biennial or triennial assessment process for certain organisations. Such organisations will have their financial affairs monitored by council's financial advisory unit in association with the relevant artform board. This assessment system will facilitate the organisations' ability to plan ahead and should contribute to financial stability. Council will consider the eligibility of organisations across all artforms for this system. Precise funding levels will, of course, continue to be determined by council in the annual budget context.

22. Generally, I was pleased with the public responses to the Government's proposals. They exhibited a caring and responsible attitude to the development of the arts in Australia. Many questions were asked, some of them detailed and specific, others of a general nature. In this context I must point out that whilst the government sets the broad structural framework for its arts funding body and determines the overall funding allocation, the Australia Council is responsible for putting that structure into operation.

23. Concern has been expressed on the part of certain sectors of the arts community that one or other particular artform might be disadvantaged by any change of structure. Let me assure you that the new structure will have quite the opposite effect. For example, the new community cultural development unit will bring community arts into prominence in the council structure. By the very nature of its membership it will provide for interaction of all council activities. It will support activities that assist the cultural development of communities but are not necessarily the ``arts'' in the narrowest sense of the term. Community arts can only benefit from such a structure and I am confident that both the arts and the general community will reap rich rewards. Community arts remains a cornerstone of the government's arts policy and represents an essential element in facilitating greater access to the arts.

24. The new performing arts board which will embrace theatre and music and the new visual arts/craft board, combining both crafts and visual arts activities, have been designed to link related, but distinct, artforms.

25. The performing arts board will facilitate consideration of issues common to the performing arts such as training, performance venues and administration. The board members will have a broad range of expertise and, where appropriate, they will be assisted by specialist art form committees especially for peer assessment of grant applications. Committees may also be convened, as necessary, to examine and advise on particular arts support issues.

26. I have consulted with the Chairman of the Council, professor Donald Horne, about implementation of these changes. To achieve some changes it will be necessary to amend the Australia Council Act, for example, to alter membership of boards and to create the new Community Cultural Development Unit.

27. However, there are changes which can be made prior to amendment of the Act. I propose to appoint the new performing arts and visual arts/craft boards to be operational from 1 July 1987. Under the present Act the maximum number of board members is eight. When the Act is amended to allow for a maximum of nine members, I will appoint a further member to each of these boards.

28. I shall Gazette the name change of the literature board to the literary arts board also as of 1 July. Pending changes in the Legislation, the Aboriginal Arts, Design and Literary Arts Boards will operate as at present. If necessary, I will fill vacancies on these boards for a twelve months period, which is the minimum permissible under the Act. Once the Act is amended the Membership of these Boards will be brought into line with the revised provisions.

29. Pending amendment of the Act to enable the creation of the New Community Cultural Development unit the Community Arts Board will be replaced by an interim structure. I have asked the council to set up a Committee to look at facilitating the change over, consider the functions and scope of the new unit, and administer the existing Community Arts Functions, including grant-making. Membership of this Committee should reflect the membership composition of the new unit.

30. I believe that the Australia Council must be in a position to review its priorities in response to changing circumstances. This is a continuing situation and demands a greater degree of cohesion between council and boards. I am confident that the new structure will provide the flexibility and interaction necessary to facilitate a successful development process and will be a more cost-effective arts support delivery mechanism. I have asked the council to examine its administration and to achieve whatever cost savings are possible over a period of one to two years.

31. Streamlining the operations of the Australia Council will call for changes not only in structure but in methods of operation. Consistent with the Government's overall approach to administration, we are determined to ensure that funds appropriated for a particular purpose, in this case support for the arts, are spent primarily on that purpose and not on administrative overheads. The arts should be administratively efficient and should serve the needs of all Australians.

32. Consistent with this approach the Government is encouraging the Australia Council and the States and Territories to accelerate their examination of those activities which might be devolved to the States or other appropriate agencies and authorities. The Government intends to pursue this matter with the Australia Council and through the Cultural Ministers Council. Whilst some States have questioned the value of devolution, others are willing to investigate the possibilities. The Government considers that such moves will not only produce a more efficient administration of arts support but will provide a greater equity and responsiveness to local needs.

33. The McLeay committee's report raises a number of particular issues concerning the development of the arts. These include the development of contemporary music, the introduction of royalty schemes, the operation of artbank and a number of taxation issues. Some of these issues require considerable examination and consultation. This is being undertaken. For instance, the National Arts Industry Training Committee, supported by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, is identifying and advising the Government on training needs in the arts industry. The Government is pursuing recommendations of a study carried out by the Australian trade commission on export opportunities for Australian contemporary music, and the Attorney- General's Department is consulting with interest groups and relevant departments on the feasibility of introducing a blank tape levy.

34. There remains the issue of co-ordinating the activities of the Australia Council with other Commonwealth agencies and the States and the proposal by the committee that the Government in conjunction with the States develop a national cultural strategy. The Government agrees on the need for greater co-ordination of Commonwealth policies and support for cultural development. To give effect to this and other related recommendations of the committee and provide enhanced support for the work of the Cultural Ministers Council, the co-ordination activities of the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment will be upgraded.

35. The feasibility of developing a national cultural strategy was discussed by the Cultural Ministers Council when it met on 22 May 1987. The articulation of broad national goals and strategies, including inter-relationships of Commonwealth, State and non-government agencies could provide a useful framework for the allocation of resources and development of complementary strategies at agency level.

36. I repeat that this Government believes that the development of Australian artistic talents is an integral part of the development of our society. It also believes that everyone in the community should have opportunities for artistic and creative expression. Governments have a responsibility to provide these opportunities and I strongly reject any threat to this fundamental principle. We have recently seen the Opposition's waste watch committee provide us with a frightening indication of what the Opposition's Arts policy might be. Indeed, the new opposition Arts spokesman is advocating Italian opera for schools while he would have funding for all art forms reduced in all probability to one or two major national companies. The Opposition entirely rejects the notion of cultural equity and has attacked programs, such as the Australia Council's Art and Working Life program, which provide access to the Arts for the ordinary men and women of Australia. We are proud of the Art and Working Life program under which, contrary to the assertions of the Opposition, funds do not go to trade unionists but go to artists. The artistic products are made with both financial input from trade unions and material assistance from those bodies. We do not intend to cut off this form of access to relevant art, which has the potential to reach three and a half million people, as the waste watch committee would have us do. This Government is committed to developing creative resources to afford all Australians the opportunities they deserve.
37. I believe our response to the recommendations of the committee report and the Australia Council is positive and will have a lasting impact on future Arts development for all Australians.
SCHEDULE OF THE GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES STANDING COMMITTEE ON EXPENDITURE 1986 REPORT INQUIRY INTO COMMONWEALTH ASSISTANCE TO THE ARTS
(``PATRONAGE, POWER AND THE MUSE'')
McLeay Committee
recommendations
Australia Council views
Government response
Recommendation 1:
Commonwealth arts support policy should aim to democratise culture by ensuring wide and ready community access to a diversity of cultural experiences.
Recommendation 2:
The Australia Council Act should be amended to provide that:
(a) the Council's role is to act in conjunction with other support agencies to preserve artistic heritage, promote innovation in the arts and promote general access to a diversity of art-forms;
(b) the Council's function of promoting excellence applies to all art-forms with which it is involved.
Council supports the recommendation. Council's own policies and priorities seek to ensure wide access to, and opportunity to participate in, a diversity of artistic activities.

Council supports in principle but believes its role should also extend to `artists welfare'. Council has also suggested expansion of its functions in section 5 of the Act to include `means' (McLeay specifically rejected both propositions). To deal with State/Commonwealth boundary problems Council has stated its objectives in terms of national leadership and national programs but argues that it needs to have a charter as broad as the existing section 5 to inform policy development and priorities of governments and their agencies at all levels.

The Government supports these recommendations. Artistic expression is an integral part of society. Development of excellence in a diverse range of arts practice and wide public access to and participation in arts activities is a fundamental objective of Government support. The existing functions of the Australia Council are consistent with the objective. To clarify Council's role amendment of the legislation is proposed requiring Council to have regard to Government policies and priorities and to the responsibilities and activities of other support agencies in the development of national policies and programs.
Recommendation 3:
(Recommendation 4 on Ministerial directions is related).
Government control of arts support policy should be ensured by:
(a) the Council submitting to the Minister each year, estimates of expenditure under each Board or Council program;
(b) Ministerial approval of the estimates when he or she is satisfied that the proposed allocation between programs is in accord with Government priorities.

Council proposes approval of its estimates on a 3 line basis (direct support, other services, administration) supported by supplementary information on break-down of the estimates to Board level including rationale-but not for the purpose of `government control of arts support', a concept rejected by Council.

The Government supports the objective of this recommendation, but considers that detailed control of Council estimates is inappropriate. Approval of estimates on a three line basis is proposed (direct support, other services, administration) supplemented by a report from Council relating its proposed allocation of resources to government policies and priorities. This, together with the introduction of program budgeting-which requires ministerial approval of objectives and performance indicators-will provide sufficient and effective government oversight.
Recommendation 4:

The Australia Council Act should be amended to provide for the issue of ministerial directions to the Council. This power should not extend to directions on particular grants. The amendments should ensure consultation between the Minister and the Council prior to issue of any direction, appropriate publicity for any direction within 21 days after it is issued, and freedom for the Council to comment on any ministerial direction in its annual report.

Qualified support by Council. Council rejected the Australian Film Commission model which it sees reflected in this Recommendation and proposes a new S.5 (2) to its Act which requires the Council to `consider the contents of any Ministerial request' and respond to the Minister as soon as practicable, subject to direct notification by the Minister to interested parties, general notification in the press and reference in Council's annual report.

The Government proposes to amend the legislation as recommended by the Committee to provide for the issue of Ministerial directions. The proposed power of Ministerial direction will exclude direction on individual grants and will be subject to tabling in the Parliament and comment in Council's annual report.
Recommendation 5:
(Recommendation's 11 and 12 on board structure and staffing are related)
In proposing appointments to the Australia Council and its Boards, the Minister should:
(a) ensure adequate representation of members with skills in public administration or who are likely to represent the broad public interest;
(b) ensure that members drawn from the arts community represent a diversity of artistic view points and interests.

Council proposes a maximum of 13 Council members (with power to co-opt as necessary) that all Board Chairpersons be on Council that there be no government representatives and that representatives on Council include:
- at least one aboriginal person
- adequate representation by persons with combined arts/administrative experience
- adequate representation by persons with broad intellectual and artistic experience
- a suitable balance should include at least two representatives each from the literary arts, performing arts, visual arts and at least one from aboriginal arts.
Further, Council proposes that it have the power to appoint Board members.

The Government supports this recommendation consistent with the objective of Commonwealth support for the arts. Amendment to the legislation is proposed to broaden the representation of interests on Council and its Boards, remove the requirement for appointment of `government' representatives on Council, require Chairpersons of Boards to be members of Council and provide for Ministerial consideration of Council advice on Board appointments. Council membership will remain at minimum 10, maximum 14, plus the General Manager as ex-officio member.
Recommendation 6:

The Australia Council should, within eighteen months of the release of this report, have delegated authority for deciding between applicants for small grants in ongoing programs to appropriate agencies and authorities closer to the field.
Council supports and has proposals for devolution which go substantially further than McLeay including the following target areas
- all general grant companies
- community arts project grants
- contemporary art spaces
- National Exhibition Touring Structure
- interstate touring
- suitable elements of craft grants
- artist-in-residence schemes (but not grants to individual artists)
- literary festivals/readings/workshops.
Council's prerequisites for devolution and peer group assessment and peer group decision-making;
Negotiations with States have commenced.
Council believes certain activities should not be devolved, namely-
- Aboriginal arts
- support for national organisations
- support for individual artists
- innovative and experimental projects.
The Government supports this recommendation and is pursuing discussions with the States and Territories and through the Cultural Ministers Council (CMC).
Scope for decentralisation of grant administration in the 1987-88 Budget has been addressed at the May 1987 meeting of CMC.
Complementary negotiations have also been initiated by the Council.
The Government accepts that transfer to the States of responsibility for grant administration may need to be accompanied by transfer of appropriate administrative resources.
Recommendation 7:
The Australia Council should revert to administering grants to major clients through a Major Companies Program under Council control but with input as necessary from the relevant Boards.

Council has decided to withdraw its earlier resolution to establish a Major Organisations Unit and instead adopts the policy that certain organisations should be put on a biennial or triennial funding basis subject to conditions. Such organisations will have their financial affairs monitored by the Financial Advisory Unit, subject to the relevant Board policy which is developed within Council's guidelines. A thorough assessment of each organisation will be made by the relevant Board at the end of the biennial or triennial period. This will achieve the original objective, but with a wider ambit.

The Government supports this recommendation. Council's revised proposal for the assessment of certain organisations should provide for more equitable administration and monitoring of grants for major and other organisations.
Recommendation 8:
(Recommendation 6 on devolution is related)

The Australia Council should negotiate with appropriate organisations in the State capitals and possibly in major regional centres, to establish arrangements under which selected organisations will be appointed to provide advisory services on the Council's behalf to applicants for grants.
Council supports in principle and is reviewing viable approaches.
The Government supports this recommendation and notes that Council intends to negotiate appropriate arrangements with the States.
Recommendation 9:
The Australia Council and its Boards should regularly meet outside Sydney and should open to the public such parts of their meetings as is feasible.
Council supports meetings outside Sydney and will implement as resources allow. Council is disposed to open discussion of policy issues.

The Government supports this recommendation and commends Council's willingness to meet outside Sydney as funds permit. There is already extensive community liaison by Boards of the Council and open policy discussions combined with broader representation on Council and its Boards will facilitate achievement of the Government's objective (see response to Recommendations 1 and 2).
Recommendation 10:

Ministers should continue to have regard to the critical importance of selecting the best appointees to the Australia Council and its Boards and the Council should review its induction processes for new members to ensure that sufficient attention is given to the roles of all participants in arts support and to the history of the Council's activities.
Council supports and is reviewing induction processes.

The `Government is conscious of the importance of appointing suitably qualified and experienced persons to the governing boards of all statutory authorities. Proposed improvements to the method of identifying suitable appointees are mentioned in the Government's paper on ``Statutory Authorities & Government Business Enterprises''.

Council is reviewing its induction processes to ensure that new members are adequately briefed including on delineation of the respective roles, functions and responsibilities of members, chairpersons and administrative staff.
Recommendation 11:
(Recommendation 5 is also related)

The board structure of the Australia Council should be streamlined by a reduction in the number of Boards and the classifications of Board staff to reflect changes in the role of the Boards recommended in this report.
Recommendation 12:
Changes of responsibilities within the Council's administration in response to this report should be accompanied by reductions in the numbers and classification of the staff of Boards.
Council supports and has now recommended a 4 Board structure:
- Literary Arts (supported by panels for, e.g. drama, poetry, prose, etc.)
- Plastic Arts (supported by panels for visual arts, crafts, etc.)
- Performing Arts (supported by panels for, e.g. music, theatre and dance)
- Aboriginal Arts
In this option responsibility for community arts would rest with Council itself.
Council supports the establishment of a Community Cultural Development Unit and a Design Unit.
Council proposes to establish a Cross-Disciplinary Arts Panel.
The Government strongly supports this recommendation and is to reduce the number of Boards as follows:
* Literary Arts Board
* Visual Arts/Craft Board
* Performing Arts Board
* Aboriginal Arts Board
* Design Board.
In future, support for development of community arts will be under the direct control of Council. A Community Cultural Development Unit will be established.

The streamlining of Board activities will enhance the effectiveness of Council and provide for a more cost-effective arts support delivery mechanism. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has asked the General Manager of the Australia Council to examine the Council's administration and over a period of 1-2 years to achieve whatever cost savings possible.
Recommendation 13:

The Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment should undertake a reporting and co-ordinating role for the full range of Commonwealth cultural policy. The Department's policy branches should be appropriately structured to undertake this role.

Council notes that the Department exercises a co-ordination role at present. Council is active in fostering co-ordination between agencies involved with tourism, education broadcasting and international relations sectors.
The Government agrees on the need for greater co-ordination of Commonwealth policies and support for cultural development.

To give full effect to this and other related recommendations of the Committee and provide enhanced support for the work of the Cultural Ministers Council modest additional resources will be provided for the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment.
Recommendation 14:

A national cultural strategy should be developed as a matter of priority. Development should continue to be under the authority of the Cultural Ministers' Council but drafting should be undertaken by a broadly-based group under the control of the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment.

Council considers that a national cultural strategy should go no further than a broad statement, be indicative rather than prescriptive and concern itself with issues relating to support for cultural development. It should not be a blueprint giving direction for the development of Australian culture per se.

The feasibility of developing a national cultural strategy was discussed by the Cultural Ministers Council at its meeting in May 1987. The articulation of broad national goals and strategies, including inter-relationships of Commonwealth, State and non-government agencies could provide a useful framework for the allocation of resources and development of complementary strategies at agency level.
Recommendation 15:

The Government should not generally propose nominees for membership of the boards of major arts organisations. Rather, in the event of management failure in these companies, the Government should insist that continued support be conditional on an acceptable restructuring of board and management to ensure a return to financial viability within a specified period of time.
Council supports.

The Government supports this recommendation in principle noting that the function of the Financial Advisory Unit of Council will be to monitor the financial performance of major arts organisations in conjunction with the relevant artform Boards.
Recommendation 16:

Provided that Recommendation 17 on forward commitment of funding is also implemented, aggregate, general support funding to the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet and the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust should not be significantly increased in real terms above the present level for a period of three years. These organisations should be eligible to apply during that period for assistance additional to their general support funding for specific projects under other Australia Council programs.
Recommendation 17:
The Australia Council should introduce a system of triennial funding for its three largest clients.

Council supports. Council has adopted a policy that certain organisations should be put on a biennial or triennial funding basis subject to annual budgetary outcome. (i.e. Council may be unable to honour forward commitment to funding at same level in real terms if the overall allocation it receives is reduced in real terms during triennium).
Such organisations will have their financial affairs monitored by the Financial Advisory Unit of Council, subject to the relevant Board policy which is developed within Council's guidelines.
A thorough assessment of each organisation would be made by the relevant Board at the end of biennial or triennial period.
The Government supports this recommendation in principle and sees advantage in a case by case review of triennial funding for companies in receipt of general grants.
Subject to the outcome of annual budgetary discussions the Council will give effect to this recommendation as far as practicable.
Recommendation 18:

Proposals for the rationalisation of State and Commonwealth resources devoted to major performing arts organisations should be developed and implemented by the Cultural Ministers' Council as a matter of high priority. In particular, those States in which a national organisation is based should make an appropriate contribution to reflect the savings accruing to them as a result of the location of the national company.

Council supports this recommendation. Council has developed a ``funding formula'' whereby the subsidy costs of opera resources, including the Australian Opera, would be shared more equitably among the Federal and State governments in return for performances in all six States.
The Government supports this recommendation and will pursue with the States and Territories through the Cultural Ministers Council.
Recommendation 19:

The Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, in conjunction with the Australian Taxation Office, should regularly report on the level of tax expenditures on film and should take account of this form of Commonwealth assistance when establishing priorities for arts support.
Council supports this recommendation.

The Government supports the thrust of this recommendation and has regard to taxation expenditure in annual budgetary discussions on support for the arts. Reporting on taxation expenditures generally, including estimates of the costs to revenue of the special 120/20 income tax concessions for films is provided by the Treasury. (Ref. Tax Expenditure Statement, the Treasury, October 1986).
Recommendation 20:

The Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment in conjunction with the Australian Taxation Office, should identify, estimate the effect of, and regularly report on all tax expenditures on the arts. The Department should continuously consider the effect of this indirect Commonwealth subsidy on overall Commonwealth arts support policy.
Council supports this recommendation.
See response to Recommendations 13 and 19.

While the Government supports the objective, the cost-benefit of collecting data on all tax expenditures needs to be weighed, e.g. income of non-profit art organisations, deductions for gifts to art bodies and exemption of certain works of art from wholesale sales tax.
Recommendation 21:

The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, in consultation with the Treasurer, should develop revised procedures for approval of tax deductibility of donations to arts organisations so as to replace the present delegation of authority to the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust with a system of Ministerial approval.

The Council supports changes to section 78 (1) (a) of the Income Tax Assessment Act to give effect to this recommendation. Ministerial approval of companies already receiving indirect support through the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust would simplify procedures and encourage more people to make donations to arts organisations.
The Government will give further consideration to this recom- mendation.
Recommendation 22:

The Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, in conjunction with the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Customs Service should resolve the current anomalous definitions of art for the purposes of taxation and import duties.
Council supports this recom- mendation.
The Government supports this recommendation in principle so far as it relates to import duties and will review relevant provisions of the Customs Tariff Act 1982.
Recommendation 23:
(Recommendation 26 on tertiary education training is related).

The Australia Council should convene a working party to develop appropriate business training arrangements for new entrants to the contemporary music industry. The working party should include representation from a broad cross-section of the industry. It should pay particular attention to the problems of delivering training to the industry.

Council supports in principle although implementation subject to resource limitations. The proposal has the support of the Music Board which is considering appropriate future action. Council is providing substantial support for the National Arts Industry Training Committee.
The Government supports this recommendation in principle.

The National Arts Industry Training Committee, supported by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, was established to identify and advise the Government on training needs in the arts industry.

The Government is also pursuing recommendations of a study carried out by the Australian Trade Commission on export opportunities for Australian contemporary music. These include co-operation with the industry to develop and co-ordinate export promotion activities, the production of pilot programs for placement on overseas networks and the dissemination of information/expertise on export marketing.
Recommendation 24:
The Government should, as a matter of priority, introduce a levy on the sale of blank audio recording tape to finance royalty payments to holders of copyright in recorded material.

Council supports this recommendation. It considers that this scheme should be broadened to cover video tapes. The proposal from Council would use part of this levy, rather than returning 85% of it overseas, to establish a creative development fund which would directly support the production and marketing of recording of Australian music and musicians. Thus Council's only concern with this recommendation is its lesser reach.
The Government will give further consideration to this recom- mendation.
The Government notes with approval:
* the Solicitor-General's advice that a scheme may be devised which is not, in law, a tax; and

* the consultations currently being held by the Attorney-General's Department with interest groups and relevant departments upon the form in which a blank tape royalty scheme might be implemented and looks forward to an early submission to it with firm proposals for a royalty.
Recommendation 25:
The Australia Council should establish a scheme to assist talented contemporary musicians in the production of demonstration tapes, video clips and their first record.

The Music Board of the Australia Council has reviewed its policies on rock music and will provide $30,000 in 1986/87 to assist young rock musicians who have not yet had a record publicly released, to make demonstration tapes (not video tapes). The limit per grant is $3,000.

The Government supports this recommendation in principle and has agreed that the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment pursue the feasibility of implementation in consultation with the Australia Council and other Commonwealth departments and agencies.
Recommendation 26:
The Council, together with the Technical and Further Education sector, should develop relevant training for the contemporary music industry covering:
(a) business principles for aspiring contemporary musicians;
(b) training in recording and production techniques.
Council supports ``in principle''.
See response to recommendation 23.
Recommendation 27:

The Australia Council should develop a scheme, similar to those it administers for visual artists and writers, under which talented contemporary musicians are assisted to train, study and perform in appropriate overseas centres.
Council considers this recommendation worthy of investigation in the broader context of breaking into the international market.
The Government supports this recommendation in principle and considers that representation by the contemporary music industry on the appropriate Board of the Council will facilitate implementation.
Recommendation 28:

The Department of Foreign Affairs should establish and maintain co-ordinating arrangements for Australian cultural activities overseas. These arrangements should aim to maximise the foreign policy and trade benefits available to Australia from Australian cultural activities and should make full use of the skills and resources of relevant artistic and cultural agencies such as the Australia Council and the International Cultural Corporation of Australia as well as the expertise of the Australian Trade Com- mission.

Council supports this recommendation. Council has established an International Committee to co-ordinate arts activities with membership comprising the Departments of Arts, Heritage and Environment, Foreign Affairs, Sport, Recreation and Tourism and Trade as well as State Arts Ministries.
The Government supports this recommendation and proposes to establish a standing committee chaired by the Department of Foreign Affairs to co-ordinate cultural activities overseas.
Recommendation 29:
Artbank should be established as a self-supporting, financially independent entity.
Council supports this recom- mendation.
The Government supports this recommendation and is evaluating a phased approach to the operation of Artbank on a commercially viable basis.
Recommendation 30:
Arrangements should be made for payments under the Public Lending Right Scheme to be increased annually in line with the rate of inflation.
Council supports.
The Government supports this recommendation in principle subject to annual budgetary considerations.
In practice this Government has increased funding over and above the level of inflation.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.
Debate (on motion by Mr N.A. Brown) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—During Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) incorrectly claimed that it is my policy and the policy of my Party to deregulate completely interest rates for all housing loans. That is completely incorrect. I will read from a policy statement which I issued on behalf of the Opposition on 3 January 1986 in which I said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition therefore believes that the Government should maintain the ceiling for existing borrowers but provide greater flexibility for banks to negotiate interest rates with new borrowers.

That means that we would keep the ceiling on existing loans; we would deregulate new loans. That policy was adopted in its entirety by the Government itself three months after I made that statement. Therefore, the claim by the Prime Minister that our policy is in favour of complete deregulation of existing housing interest rates is a complete and deliberate misstatement of the position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—During the attempt of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at Question Time to make a joke of the human tragedy of approximately 8,000 low income Australians who have gone bankrupt--
—Order! The honourable member is out of order when he starts on that tack. The honourable member should tell me where he has been misrepresented.
—I asked a question about the 8,000 people who have gone bankrupt and the Prime Minister laughed. I draw that to your attention, Madam Speaker.
—Order! The honourable member has told us. He will tell us where he has been misrepresented.
—The Prime Minister called into doubt the figures I cited on the record level of bankruptcies now occurring under his economic management. The figures cited in my question--
—Order! The Prime Minister did not call that into doubt. He said that he did not accept it. I think there is a difference.

—No, he did not. He said that he did not believe it. I am about to tell you, Madam Speaker, where I have been misrepresented. The figures cited in my question were supplied by the Attorney-General's Department. If they are wrong, as the Prime Minister claims, it purely substantiates his Ministers' inability to balance the books or to lodge their tax returns.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; CROSS; JONES; LANGMORE; LLOYD; MCARTHUR; MCGAURAN; MCHUGH; MACKELLAR; NEHL
PETITION.NAMEIDS: OE4; YF4; KH4; KG4; 2E4; VH4; XH4; ZH4; 014; AE4
PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 Oct 86 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government- induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 Oct. 86 to 1 July 87 so that pensions are restored to the 9 Oct. 86 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Cross,Mr Barry Jones,Mr Langmore,Mr Lloyd,Mr McArthur,Mr McGauran,Ms McHugh,Mr MacKellar and Mr Nehl.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEDDALL; FITZGIBBON; FREE; HICKS; LINDSAY; TICKNER
PETITION.NAMEIDS: QE4; FG4; HG4; AH4; OG4; RJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to show restraint with equity. In particular, the decision to defer the November pension adjustments has resulted in a loss of $25.62 for a single pensioner and $21.36 for each married pensioner.
The prospect of a further deferral of the May adjustment will result in the loss of another $35.10 for a single pensioner and $29.10 for each married pensioner.

When you are scrimping to make ends meet, as is the case with many pensioners, you can't afford such a cut in living standards. Pensioners are looking for a new deal from politicians-more of the same is not good enough!
Your petitioners request an immediate return to payment of May and November C.P.I. increases, and as is duty bound will ever pray the Government grant this request now.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beddall,Mr Fitzgibbon,Mr Free,Mr Hicks,Mr Lindsay and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duncan,Mr Kent,Ms McHugh,Mr Milton and Mr Saunderson.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia.
(2) Ban the import of cobalt-60 and Cesium-137 and Cesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products,
(3) Ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation. (Election Beam, X-Ray etc.)
(4) Ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Two Dollar Coin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That, as a consequence of the Hawke Government's decision to introduce a two dollar coin in 1988,

Whereas the introduction of a one dollar coin was only a twofold increase in the maximum value of coinage, the elimination of the two dollar note represents a five-fold increase before a note can be used.

It will have taken eighteen years from decimalisation to go from the fifty cent piece as the highest value coin to a one dollar coin, but only a further four years to replace the two dollar note with a coin.
The lowest value paper note will be five dollars, forcing a dramatic increase in the weight of coinage carried and dislocation of the retail industry.
Many people, particularly the elderly, will mistake the value of the coin for that of another lower value coin just as many now confuse a one dollar coin with the ten cent piece.

That the addition of two new coins in four years creates the biggest number of coins in circulation at any time in Australia's history and will lead to the removal of the one cent and two cent coins; this will accelerate the cost of living, particularly the cost of food where numerous items are involved and future price rises would need to be five cent increases on every item on every occasion.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the proposed two dollar coin not be proceeded with by the Hawke Government, and no future Government proceed with this proposal for several years.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron and Mrs Sullivan.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Two Dollar Coin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously oppose the proposed introduction of a two dollar coin to replace the Australian two dollar note. We feel that an additional coin would not only cause additional inconvenience and confusion to the public but is totally unnecessary as we have ample coinage in circulation and we ask that the Government revise its decision to implement this currency change.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives.
The petition of the undersigned do respectfully showeth that pornographic material relating to children is deleterious to the health and welfare of children and society as a whole.
We respectfully urge the Government to ban all child pornography from entering or from being produced in Australia.
And your petitioners in duty-bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, call upon the Government to:
1. obtain from the French Government some form of commitment, which is recognised under the international law, that they will not test nuclear devices at the Kerguelen Islands
2. bring this matter to the attention of the United Nations Assembly, if no such commitment is obtained
3. impose trade restrictions on France, including a ban on uranium sales, until a legal commitment is obtained.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned by the threat to social morality and the welfare of children, posed by the unrestricted importation, distribution and sale of X-rated pornography video material in and from the Australian Capital Territory.

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and reverse its amendments to ACT legislation and Customs regulations which have resulted in Australia wide distribution of material restricted under State censorship laws.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Killarney Heights Post Office Agency, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows that the closure of the Killarney Heights post office agency is opposed by local residents and businesses.
Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and permit the continuation of the Killarney Heights post office agency.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowance Payments
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
The costs of raising children are rising and the value of government provided economic assistance to families is declining.
Families raising children are providing a vital function to society and are deserving of government provided economic assistance.
Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
1. Restore family allowance payments to their 1976 real money value.
2. Provide for the regular and automatic indexation of family allowance payments.
3. Increase the value of the Dependant Spouse Rebate to $1851 per annum, and convert it to a cash payment given directly to the non-income family spouse.
4. Amend the Family Income Supplement Scheme so that its value is increased, its eligibility provisions widened and its withdrawal provisions eased.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members in the House of Representatives assembled, the undersigned citizens call upon all Members to pay due respect to pensioners and other recipients of Social Security benefits and to Commonwealth Superannuitants and to cease the constant erosion of our entitlements by the Government.
We call upon the Prime Minister and his Government to take the following action when considering budgetary changes to be announced in May this year.

1. They ensure there is no further erosion of existing benefits to Pensioners and other Social Security recipients and further that they honour their promise to Pensioners made before the last election that pensions be increased to a level equal to 25% of average weekly earnings.

2. That the Government reconsider its action in reducing by two per cent the level of superannuation paid to Commonwealth Superannuitants, retired members of the Defence Services and other eligible Commonwealth Superannuitants.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-

(1) A cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons would break the cycle of research, development and deployment of nuclear weapons and prevent the acquisition of new and ever more lethal weapons of mass destruction. It would thus be a major and significant step towards ending the arms race and beginning the disarmament process; and
(2) The Soviet Union has extended its unilateral moratorium on nuclear weapons testing until August 6 this year and has again invited the United States to cease its nuclear testing program.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Australian Government to put the strongest pressure on the United States Government to join the Soviet Union's nuclear test ban.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australian Card'' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Footwear Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

We are concerned that the decisions to be taken by Government with regard to the footwear industry in which we work may not recognise the continuation of a form and level of assistance which will maintain the security of our employment.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
Every consideration and support will be given to this matter so that we are able to maintain our employment in this industry.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Pacific Highway Improvements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain electors of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the North Coast section of the Pacific Highway, from a point just south of Port Macquarie and just north of Woolgoolga, is in urgent need of major road improvement works in order to bring it up to road safety standards.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
The Federal Government immediately divert National Highway funds or make available other funds towards the improvement of this section of the Pacific Highway.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-

Any proposals to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concern ex-servicemen, ex-servicewomen and their families, because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to properly care for Australia's Veterans.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to-
Ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of Veterans and their families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal its anti-business anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Mortlake showeth concern for current and future funding for road construction in south west Victoria. Your petitioners therefore pray that-

The Commonwealth Government increase the moneys allocated to the Victorian State Government for road funding, so as to allow adequate funding for the construction and maintenance of roads within south west Victoria.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat to the living standards of all Australians, particularly families, posed by Labor's failed policies and its unwillingness to disclose the contents of the 1987 Hawke-Keating Budget.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the next 6 1/2 weeks go by, there will be many questions asked by the Australian public, but no question will be more pressing, more persistent and harder for the Government to answer than the question which is on the lips of every Australian, particularly the head of every Australian household this morning. That question is: What on earth is the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) hiding from the Australian public? Why is it that this Government, seeking to be re-elected on the basis of its economic record, did not have the courage to go to the people after it had brought down its annual Budget? Why is it, for the first time ever, that a government within striking distance of the annual economic accounting to the people should decide to cut and run, scuttle its responsibilities and have an election virtually on the eve of bringing down a Budget? No matter what the Prime Minister says, no matter how much he bobs and weaves and seeks to shift responsibility, the truth is that he did not have the guts to bring the Budget down before he had an election. That is a fact that every Australian family will be aware of.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another question they will ask with increasing persistence which is very basic to the well-being of every Australian family. It is: Is someone, or someone's family, or if one runs a business is one's business better off now than four years ago when Hawke was elected? The resounding answer all around Australia is that they are not better off. Over the last four years we have had a Hawke-Keating government-and it is a Hawke-Keating government. If ever a person deserved to carry the economic blame for what has happened to this country over the past four years it is the present Treasurer (Mr Keating). He is more preoccupied with the machinations of the money market than he is with the living standards of ordinary Australian families. Over the next 6 1/2 weeks he will find out that his priorities have been wrong over the last four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Reuters screen.

—Yes, he will find out that the Reuters screen means nothing to struggling families in electorates such as Barton. The Treasurer's mate, the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), will find out that paying the mortgage bill of the St George Building Society is far more important to the families of Barton and other swinging seats around Australia than the flicker of the Reuters screen, which the Treasurer is so very fond of talking about. Increasingly, the Australian public will be asking: `Why have you run before your Budget? What is it that you do not want to tell the Australian people? What have you got up your sleeve? What new taxes and charges and what new attacks on the living standards of Australian families do you have in mind that have deterred you from bringing down your Budget before the election?' It is not good enough for the Prime Minister to say: `We have already brought down the Budget. We had the May economic statement'. It may have escaped the Prime Minister's attention that half of a Budget is comprised of a revenue side-although in the case of this Government it comprises an increasingly large slice-and the other side is for expenditure. All the Government did in May was to make an expenditure statement. It put some taxes on Telecom Australia which will react against people living in rural Australia far more than on any other section of the Australian community. By and large the economic statement related to expenditure and the sale of assets but said nothing at all about revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: In the unlikely event of this Government being returned there is absolutely no guarantee at all that there will not be savage taxation increases in the August Budget. The Australian public must understand that. In fact, on a radio program this morning the interviewer said to me: `There cannot be any increases in taxation because the Prime Minister said that there would not be'. We cannot expect anyone to believe, on the basis of that kind of statement, that there will be no increases. I can recall all the Prime Minister's statements in 1984 when he said, for instance, that interest rates would fall in 1985. The Prime Minister said that he had sown the seed and that we would all reap the harvest. Of course we have reaped the harvest, all right-Australian families have got it in the neck, because over the past 2 1/2 years interest rates have risen to the tune of about $152 a month for the average Australian family. That is the degree to which that promise has been delivered.

During debate on a matter of public importance in the last session of Parliament I produced a document entitled `Labor's top 10 disposable promises' which detailed the best of Bob's disposable promises. It began with the immortal and never to be forgotten line: `There will be no capital gains tax'. Or course, that went out the window. Then there were the promises about interest rates. Then there were the promises about family living standards. There was a promise about reducing the fuel excise-and that was an absolute whopper. During the 1983 election campaign the Prime Minister campaigned on the basis of reducing the price of fuel immediately he was elected to office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three cents a litre.

—Yes, he said 3c a litre. He went around to the Australian people and said: `I will cut the price of fuel by 3c a litre. There will be no assets test and there will be no capital gains tax. I will reduce the price of fuel by 3c a litre. There will be lower interest rates'. And so it went on.
—Tone it down!

—Well may the Minister for Social Security ask me to tone it down. He is waving, trying to get me to stop talking about this because he does not like to be reminded. To the top 10 disposable promises we can now add the most disposable promise of all; that is, the current Prime Minister of Australia on the subject of early elections. And if ever there was a disposable Prime Minister, it is the present occupant of that office because he has misled the Australian people through his teeth on the subject of early elections. The Standing Orders of this Parliament prevent me from saying what is on the lips of every Australian voter about the Prime Minister's credibility on early elections. That credibility has been torn to shreds. The Prime Minister has demonstrated the most abysmal political cynicism and the most abysmal political opportunism on this issue. The Prime Minister has dishonoured everything that he has ever said about early elections. By running without a Budget the Prime Minister has completely dishonoured his capacity to run on the issue of economic management.

SPEECH.PARA: In this election campaign we will have this extraordinary spectacle: Everybody will know what is in John Howard's taxation policy but no one will know what might have been in Bob Hawke's 1987 Budget. The supreme irony of that will haunt the Prime Minister throughout the rest of this election campaign. I can tell the Prime Minister that he will be hearing a lot more about that along with his colleagues in seats like Chisholm, Dunkley, Calare, Hunter, Cowan, Stirling, Barton, Phillip, Lowe, St George, Hughes and all the other marginal seats around Australia. They will be hearing a great deal about the fall in family living standards over the last four years. They will be hearing a great deal about the fact that when they have been in government for four years, two months and 17 days-or whatever it might be-they can no longer pass the buck to somebody else.

There are two people in Australia who must take the rap for the fall in family living standards over the last four years, and they are the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). No longer can they hide behind the alibi of blaming the foreigners; no longer can they hide behind the disgraceful, dishonest alibi of blaming the former Government; and no longer can they cast the blame to everybody other than themselves. The reality is that these two men have presided over the biggest fall in Australian family living standards for the last 40 years. Deliberate policy acts, failures and omissions by those two men have been directly responsible for the fall in family living standards. The Treasurer does not even try to deny the fact that an average family with two children is now about $41 a week worse off than it was in March 1983. The Prime Minister pretends that it is all the fault of the foreigners. He talks about the decline in our terms of trade. It is a wonder that he is not blaming the great plague for some of the economic problems that we have at present.

I remind the Prime Minister and his colleagues and the Australian people that the present Prime Minister and the present Treasurer are not the only people who have ever had to grapple with adverse international economic circumstances affecting Australia. They carry on as though they alone have been the sole victims since Federation of the rest of the world turning sour economically on this country. I remind the Prime Minister that the fall in our living standards caused by the international economic recession and the drought of the early 1980s was greater than the loss in national income caused by the adverse terms of trade. Never let it be forgotten that the impact of that on the Australian economy in the early 1980s was infinitely greater than the impact of the adverse terms of trade of the past couple of years. Did we hear anyone from the then Opposition make any kind of allowance for that? Did we hear them saying: `If you have to grapple with a drought and if you have to grapple with an international economic recession, of course that will have an impact'. Of course, we did not.

The reality is that the Government cannot hide behind its alibis. It has failed on four essential economic fronts. The first is that this is by any measure a big spending, big taxing government. The Treasurer parades himself as a born again expenditure cutter. The reality is that in his first two years as Treasurer he spent money like the proverbial drunken sailor.
