In the first two years that this Government was in power, spending rose by between 6 and 7 per cent in real terms and, even after the so-called great expenditure effort of the mini-Budget, the level of government spending as a proportion of national product is now higher than the average level during the seven years of the Fraser Government. The rate of increase in government spending under this Government is greater than it was in the seven years of the Fraser Government.

The other great failure of this Government on the economic front was that it sat on its hands in 1985 when the Australian dollar began to fall. Instead of immediately responding to that fall and instead of immediately adjusting our fiscal and monetary policy, what did the Treasurer and the Prime Minister do? They caved in over the MX missile. They sat on their hands for the rest of the year and watched the crisis get worse and worse until that infamous day, just over a year ago, when the Treasurer said that we were on the verge of becoming a banana republic. The people principally responsible for bringing that about are the two people who are going to be in the political dock of Australia over the next 6 1/2 weeks-that is, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. They are the men who have sought refuge behind alibis. They are the men who, by their deliberate policy decisions, have imposed a greater fall in the living standards of Australian families than should have occurred. They are the men who spent big in their first two years. They are the men who have imposed new punitive taxation levels on Australia. They are the men responsible for the highest interest rates since the Great Depression. They are the men who cower before their union bosses and do not have the courage to fight this election campaign on the validity of the Industrial Relations Bill.

If that Industrial Relations Bill does not put Australian unions above the law, as we claim it does and as the Government knows it does, why does the Government not have the courage to fight the campaign inter alia on that Bill? Why does it pretend that the Bill does not have that consequence, that it will put it aside? In the unlikely event of the Government being returned, it knows as well as everybody else in this Parliament and as every single member of the Australian business community knows, that it will put it through immediately. When wheat and maize are rotting on the wharfs and when the trade union movement has taken over the Government and the foreign policy of this country, why does the Government not have the courage to use section 45d of the Trade Practices Act to get that wheat shifted to Fiji? The Government condemned the coup in Fiji because it supported the right of elected governments to govern. Therefore, I ask one concluding question: If the Government believes in the right of elected governments to government, why does it not tell the trade union movement to get lost on that issue? Why does it not govern and take control of our foreign policy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The failed Treasurer, who is now a failed Opposition Leader, has not understood in any real sense the mood of the Australian electorate. The dual offering of a fistful of dollars and industrial confrontation represents a recipe which says a great deal more about the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who has rushed from the chamber, than it does about any credible policy with which the Opposition might go to the Australian people. One of the fundamental problems that the Opposition faces is simply the character of its Leader. Its Leader is a whingeing, whining, carping critic who once again has shown no capacity to develop any alternative policy worthy of any consideration whatever by this Parliament. He has put up a smokescreen of tax cuts because he is unable to carry through, and would be quite unable to carry through, what represents the underlying reality of the policies he espouses.

SPEECH.PARA: Those policies boil down to two things: Firstly, massive industrial confrontation and, secondly, the most significant round of public expenditure cuts that we have ever seen in this country. Does anyone in this Parliament seriously believe that either the current Leader of the Opposition or the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), is capable of carrying through the kinds of policies that they espouse? It is very easy for them to talk about tax cuts. However, it is much more difficult for the Australian people to imagine that they are capable of carrying through the fiscal restraint that would be necessary to deliver the tax cuts that have been offered.

We have laid the Leader of the Opposition's credibility very clearly on the line. We have considered the commitments that have been not repudiated by the Leader of the Opposition but made by him or his various spokesmen at various times, and what they all add up to. They add up to more than $14 billion in terms of tax and expenditure policy. None of those commitments have been repudiated so far by the Leader of the Opposition. There is no clarity in terms of where the Opposition stands, except the commitments on the table that add up to the order of $14 billion.

On the other hand, we are promised by the Leader of the Opposition that the Opposition's taxation policy will be made clear. We know from the Centre of Policy Studies, by way of a leaked document which represented a significant late draft of that policy, that the policy will cost at least $6 billion. We also know that the Leader of the Opposition has said that, to have any credibility, one needs to make it clear where the money will come from. On the AM program on 12 February the Leader of the Opposition said:
Any politician who thinks he can be a credible national figure without telling people where the money is coming from is absolutely kidding himself.
That is the position we have. The Leader of the Opposition comes in and carps, gripes, criticises, whinges and whines like a mangy dog. However, when it comes down--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not think that the Minister should use those words.

—I withdraw the last phrase. When it comes down to putting on the line where the Leader of the Opposition's commitments are with respect to expenditure cuts, which are quite fundamental to his taxation policy, we have never had a clear statement of where the Opposition stands. Indeed, it looks as though we will not get one. The reason we will not get one is that, fundamentally, the Leader of the Opposition and the Opposition as a whole lack courage. It is probably the most gutless opposition we have ever seen in this national Parliament.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I ask the Minister to withdraw and to acknowledge that our tax policy will be released. It is his Government's Budget that is not being released.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The Leader of the Opposition has failed to deliver, in terms of expenditure restraint, the cuts that will be necessary to deliver any kind of taxation policy along the lines that we understand a taxation policy runs. Where will the Opposition's credibility be when it goes to the Australian people without detailing its policy in terms of expenditure restraint? Where is the Opposition's credibility in terms of its own policy? It has been suggested today by the Opposition, over and against tax bribes of $5 billion or $6 billion, that the Government has not delivered in terms of the living standards of the Australian people. According to a recent report from the Economic Planning Advisory Council, a family of two children with two parents earning $30,000 as a result of this Government's policies, receives public expenditure on health care worth $34 per week. If the children are at school, the family receives benefits worth $110 per week. If the children are in higher education, the family receives benefits of about $473 per week.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the thrust of the Opposition's statements, many of the major programs that are essential to the living standards of Australian people would be at risk if the Rambos in the Opposition, who I contend would be fundamentally weak in government, had their way. I refer to programs relating to child care, housing and transport.

I turn to the Australian Labor Party's commitment to reduce taxation paid by Australian families. Taking a one income family on $32,000, since November 1984 they would have received from this Government nearly $28 per week in tax cuts, or a two-income family with a combined income of about $47,000 would have received tax cuts worth $37 per week since this Government came to office.

In relation to the Opposition's credibility, quite clearly one of the options-it is an option that has been ruled out by the National Party of Australia and will presumably depend for its implementation on the numbers between the Liberal and National parties in terms of any future coalition government-is a consumption tax. In terms of what has been assessed by the Treasury, the Leader of the Opposition would need a broad-based consumption tax to raise about $8m after removing wholesale sales tax and compensating pensioners. That would require a 12 per cent consumption tax. Under such a policy inflation would rise to 15 per cent. That is one of the options, although at the moment it is a hidden option. After the Leader of the Opposition makes his statement, it may well be an option that is still there below the surface, depending on the balance of forces between the Liberal and National parties after the election. On 4 May Mr Andrew Hay said:
Business expects a commitment from the Opposition to fund the majority of its income tax reform by expenditure reductions.
The implementation of a new broad-based consumption tax can only be seen as a device for avoiding spending cuts.
On 26 March, when being interviewed by Mr John Tingle, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen said:

They have a very, very poor policy-when you think of the consumer tax of 8 per cent. Now it would probably be 12 per cent and, once you have got it, it will not go down . . . it will go on like Britain . . . 8 per cent, 10 per cent, 12 per cent and 15 per cent.

In terms of expenditure cuts, I suppose that the one clear area that has been staked out by the Opposition relates to health policy and Medicare. When Labor introduced Medicare in February 1984 it meant health insurance for everyone. Before the introduction of Medicare no one received a fair deal. People paid the same for health insurance, regardless of income. About two million people had no health insurance cover. It is that which the Liberal Party wants to go back to. As announced in April, the Opposition's policy is to cut Government health spending by $3 billion by cutting the Medicare benefit to the majority of families, saving $1.3 billion, and by cutting Commonwealth hospital grants to the States, saving $1.7 billion. To cover the costs of such proposals the majority of families would be forced to take out more expensive private health insurance. The Commonwealth Department of Health costed these proposals and this was the result: Under the Opposition's proposals, 2.6 million families will have to pay an average of $7.90 per week per family in order to cover costs in Medicare changes. Similarly, the proposed shift of $1.7 billion in hospital and community health costs would add an additional $19.60 per week to basic hospital insurance for the average family. This means that, under a Howard Government, for a family on average weekly earnings with a basic contribution of $9.90 per week, the total cost of basic medical and hospital insurance would be $27 per week per family. As if that is not bad enough, the Department of Health has estimated that the cost of the Medicare levy would increase to 5 per cent and the effect of these policies on the consumer price index would be nearly 4 per cent.

I think that when one looks at this Opposition the thing that strikes one most strongly is its lack of capacity to deliver what it talks about. I do not believe that anyone in Australia seriously believes that the current leadership of the Liberal Party is capable of carrying through the kind of tough and hard-headed policies that have reduced forward estimates within the last 9 months by more than $8 billion. I do not think that anyone in Australia seriously believes that the wimps who lead the parliamentary Liberal Party but who promise such tough policies would be able to deliver or to handle, not only the confrontation which would follow from its industrial relations policy, but also the confrontation with so many sections of the Australian community which would result in the kind of draconian cutbacks which must be involved in the strategy about which the Leader of the Opposition has spoken. I think that Australian people perceive the Opposition as being hopelessly divided. The Liberal Party is divided between the wets and the dries. Only today, when Mr Howard spoke, most of the dries were present while most of the wets were absent. In addition, there are divisions within the National Party. There is a Queensland National Party led by Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and, essentially, it has the majority of numbers. But there is a rump National Party which is currently led by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair); so effectively, in this Parliament at the moment, the Opposition is represented by four separate parties constantly in competition with each other for the leadership.

The former Treasurer in the Fraser Government, and now the Leader of the Opposition, has been quite unable to gain control of the Liberal Party during his period as leader. In that time we have seen constant speculation about the possibility of a change in leadership; indeed, only yesterday, the President of the Liberal Party, Mr John Valder, in forecasting Mr John Elliott's entry into the Federal Parliament via a seat which nobody knows about, hinted also at a possible future change in leadership. We know that, throughout this campaign, Andrew Peacock will be waiting and hoping that the Opposition loses so that he can have another attempt at the leadership. He will do that after the campaign is completed and the Opposition is defeated. We know that the moment this election campaign is completed, the honourable member for New England will be dumped by the Queensland National Party. We know that Sir Joh aspires to lead the country in a direction which really he is past understanding.
Having taken the tough decisions in relation to the May economic statement and having laid the foundation for the year ahead with the confidence of the business community and all Australian people--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it quite extraordinary that in a debate on the subject of the living standards of Australian families, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), of all people, should spend only two minutes out of his 15 minutes actually talking about the Australian family. I find it doubly interesting that in those two minutes he referred to a family that had an annual income of $30,000 or higher and gave some examples. I dare say that the Minister was embarrassed by the fact that families on average weekly earnings or lower, families for which he has a primary responsibility, after four years of a Hawke government, are worse off than they were under a Liberal government. This matter of public importance refers to the threat to the living standards of all Australians, particularly families, posed by the Australian Labor Party's failed policies and its unwillingness to disclose the contents of the 1987 Hawke-Keating Budget. In the few minutes available to me, I hope to point out some of those areas where the living standards of all Australian families have fallen and to indicate that, without a doubt, the reason why the announcement was made yesterday concerning an early election is because this Government does not want to put the facts to the public and what will happen to it in future under a Labor Government. It was only 13 days ago that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:

SPEECH.PARA: I can't envisage any circumstances in which there would be such an early election.
In answer to a journalist's question, he said:
It can't be July in any circumstances I can imagine.

What has changed in the last 13 days? What has happened is that we have had a Premiers Conference and all the Labor Premiers advised the Prime Minister to go for an early election before the effects of the $1 billion cuts in grants to the States are felt by the people-before the hurt starts, as they said.

Plenty of hurt was inflicted by the Government's cuts in the economic statement, in its mini-Budget. But, when that is compounded after the States make their decisions, it will be all the more clear. In any event, the economic statement has returned Commonwealth expenditure to only the 1984-85 level. So, while Government members talk about fiscal or monetary-I am not sure which word it is these days-responsibility, they do not show any signs of it. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said, this is the highest taxing, highest spending government in Australia's history. Fifteen years ago public spending represented 32 per cent of gross domestic product. Today it represents 45 per cent. This Government has added $24 billion to our debt in four years. The last Fraser Government paid $3.3 billion in interest payments. The 1986-87 Budget will see $8 billion of the people's money paid in interest on the nation's debt. Who knows what the figure will be for 1987-88. We are in economic difficulties. If the Government is to continue on its high spending way, spending basically on itself and the Public Service, it will of course have to borrow more. Interest repayments are now the third highest item of expenditure in the annual Budget. That is the basic reason why we have higher taxes-not because of the social benefits to which the Minister referred ever so fleetingly.

The average family in Australia has experienced a fall of at least $31 a week in disposable income and a fall in its living standards. Low income families, about who the Minister should care and should have had something to say, are no better off. In fact there are more and more low income families and more people living in poverty. The middle income families are considerably worse off under the Labor Government. The Australian Labor Party has forgotten its roots and it is frightened of the effect that its policies will have in the next few months on the people most vulnerable to them. Nearly three and a half million people live on pensions or benefits in Australia today, including nearly 800,000 children-a figure which should dismay everyone. There are now 2.6 million people living in poverty. That is a rise of 700,000 people since March 1983.

Twenty years ago a middle income family could expect to retain 60 per cent of its income after paying its tax and paying for its housing. It now retains 40 per cent to 45 per cent of its income. Housing is one of the areas in which the effects of the Government's policies are most felt. I can only conclude that the Ministers of this Government are now so insulated from their constituents that they are not aware of the reality of the situation, which presents itself day after day in honourable members' offices as people, particularly low income people, are faced with an enormous dilemma in housing. They face higher rents, at least part of which are directly attributable to this Government's abolition of negative gearing and the capital gains tax. They face interest rates which have risen from 11 1/2 per cent, when the Hawke Government was first elected, to 15 1/2 per cent. In fact this week the Commonwealth Bank announced that for new customer housing loans the interest rate will go up to 16 1/2 per cent. But that is not a one per cent increase; it is a 6 per cent increase over time.

Of course, the middle income earner, who hopes to own a home, faces the fact that came out recently, namely, that home loan repayments, as a proportion of gross median family income, have risen in the 12 months from December 1985 to December 1986 from 23.1 per cent of gross family median income to 26.9 per cent. If we take after tax income figures, the result is even worse. In the last 20 years the amount spent by people earning one and a half times the average weekly earnings on home loan repayments, as a proportion of after tax income, has risen from 18.2 per cent to 32.7 per cent. They are not the $30,000 a year people that the Minister talked about. For people on average weekly earnings, the amount of their disposable income spent on housing has risen from 20.9 per cent to 37.1 per cent. To go a little further down the line, to the people in whom the Minister should be most keenly interested, the people on three-quarters of average weekly earnings-that accounts for many families in this country-the amount of their after tax income spent on housing has risen from 24.4 per cent to 43.5 per cent. They are blood-chilling figures. At the same time, according to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation figures provided by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) to an honourable senator in answer to a question recently, in the 12 months from December 1985 to December 1986, the number of defaults on payments had doubled. Those are the facts as they present themselves in our parliamentary offices. Low income people walk in and say: `I took a loan and could afford it. Interest rate increases mean that I can no longer afford it. I have to walk out of my home and lose all of the equity that I have in it'.

We often hear people talk about how the interest rate on Bankcard has increased from 18 to 23 per cent under this Government. The Minister will be aware that bank interest rates are largely irrelevant to most low income people because they have to deal with the hire purchase companies. It is in the housing estates of this country that the hire purchase companies make their money. The low income earners are sent off to those companies and are paying interest rates in excess of 20 per cent just for consumer goods.

The Minister referred to the medical situation. These days a low income earner cannot afford health insurance after paying for housing and paying tax. But, into the bargain, as well as not being able to afford private health insurance, low income earners also have foisted upon them even lower standards of health care. Those people who previously had to stand in the queues for free hospital treatment are now in longer--

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! That is the States.

—Oh! The Minister refers to the States as though they are not affected by the Federal Government. We are still to find out what the cuts of $1 billion to the States will mean in terms of hospital queues, hospital manning and health treatment for low income people. Of course, for the middle income earner, the cost of private medical insurance is prohibitive.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today the Minister referred to the benefits in education for the low income earner. Two years ago this Government spread the expenditure on the participation and equity program for one year over two years; in other words, it halved that expenditure. In this economic statement it has reduced spending on technical and further education by $30m, at the same time as keeping young people in the education system because of the reduced payments to young unemployed people. The Government has reduced the forecasted expenditure on Austudy payments. The very people who need education and training, and who need financial support in order to afford it, have been the most hurt by this mini-Budget. If that is the much vaunted mini-Budget, heaven help us in the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) speak on this matter of public importance, I can understand the predicament of Mr Valder, the Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia. He has a predicament, which I will refer to later in my speech. When I read the wording of the matter of public importance raised by the Opposition today, I was amazed at its wooliness and its irrelevance to the real issues facing Australia. The Opposition talks of the threat to the living standards of all Australians, particularly families, posed by Labor's failed policies. What nonsense! It is, as the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) stated in this debate, not this Government's policies which pose a threat to the living standards of all Australians; it is the policies of the Opposition.
—Where is your Budget?

—All we get is those sheep-like bleats from the Opposition benches-and from the front benches, too. I would expect a little more from the honourable member opposite. The policies of this Government are designed to overcome the adverse movement in the terms of trade for our primary products. We all recognise that that is one of the prime aims. Yet these policies have been designed on the basis of fairness to the average Australian. Yesterday's national account figures are illuminating because they show, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us in this Parliament yesterday, that the Australian economy grew at a rate of 2.3 per cent in the year to March. This is confirmation, and strong confirmation, that the Government's economic strategy is working. —I wish the honourable member would shut up. If he has a contribution to make, perhaps he could seek the leave of the Chair.
—Where is your Budget?

Under the Hawke Labor Government we have seen a growth of 759,000 jobs. If we look at wages, we note that in 18 of the last 20 national wage cases the Opposition sought freezes. SPEECH.PARA: It is quite true that because of the economic difficulties that this Government has faced we have not been able to do all that we wanted. Mr Valder went on to say--

—I find some substance in the point of order. The honourable member for Moore will come back to the matter before the Chair.

—I will. We, on this side of the House, have reason to be proud of our social achievements. Solid progress has been made by the Labor Government in the key areas of family living standards, employment, housing, education, health and prices. SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report examines the formal response to the Committee's 250th report, `Australia Post-An Audit Discontinued', which was tabled in the Parliament on 17 September 1986. That report examined the events surrounding the discontinued efficiency audit of Australia Post's administration of counter services. The Committee is generally satisfied with the response. However, the Auditor-General has taken a different view from that of the Committee in respect of the reporting provisions of section 48f (1) of the Audit Act 1901.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee concluded that previous Auditors-General should have reported under section 48f (1) and that the Auditor-General should comply with that provision. In the response, the Auditor-General states that he considers that there are no unfulfilled requirements imposed on the Auditor-General by the Audit Act in relation to the discontinued audit. DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory I present the Committee's report on metropolitan Canberra together with minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Committee considers that the major issue underlying this inquiry is that of urban consolidation as opposed to continued expansion of the built-up areas in Canberra. In the preface to its report, the Committee addresses the issue of urban sprawl and its associated costs: High infrastructure, servicing and social costs. The Committee is keen, therefore, to see greater emphasis placed on urban consolidation in Canberra's future development. The Committee in its report has suggested ways in which the National Capital Development Commission, that is, the planning authority, and the Department of Territories can improve the present land administration system and, with the benefit of a more comprehensive data base, achieve a metropolitan Canberra which can realise the benefits of increasing density in established areas. This will make full use of existing service capacity and also limit, for the time being, further peripheral expansion of the urban area until this is considered appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis of available information, the Committee considers that the environmental and social costs of dispersed growth are greater than the costs associated with concentrated development. As a consequence, the Committee recommends that the development of Gungahlin not proceed according to the timetable previously proposed by the NCDC. The Committee, in its final recommendation, proposes that the NCDC and the Department of Territories implement an urban consolidation strategy with community consultation which seeks to increase residential density in existing suburbs and make detailed information publicly available regarding the costs and benefits of such a strategy. This strategy will be successful only if the Department of Territories, as the administering authority, and the NCDC work together to achieve the objectives set out in this report. It is expected that high levels of co-operation and improved communication will be achieved, along with a better plan for Canberra's future development, if recommendations in this report are carried out.

The Committee also considers that a crucial step in overcoming the shortage of critical data on which to base informed planning decisions is the establishment of a land development account. This has been recommended in previous inquiries by both this Committee and other review bodies. It is encouraging that some progress has been made in this direction, and the Committee recommends that such an accounting system be established as soon as practicable. This should also allow judgments to be made concerning the costs and benefits of urban consolidation as opposed to further peripheral expansion.

The Committee further recognises that the development process is hampered to some extent by a lack of commitment from government for longer term planning initiatives. At present, while the Commission conducts assessments on the basis of 12-month and three-year programs, the lack of certainty regarding continuing commitment to long term construction programs has implications for the private sector in terms of investment potential and maintenance of predictable levels of construction activity in the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee is of the view that a longer time frame for planning would, in the end, result in cost savings and a more efficient allocation of resources and therefore recommends that the NCDC should be supported in its proposals for longer term planning and programming, particularly for major capital works. Where the Government has agreed to a particular planning initiative which requires the expenditure of funds over a longer period than one financial year, consideration should be given to a five-year program of commitment.

Another issue related to accountability for planning decisions raised during the inquiry is the present lack of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee has adopted a de facto role as a major public consultative mechanism in the planning process and is seen as such by residents of the Australian Capital Territory. I must say that the Committee has reluctantly taken on that role. It therefore recommends that all future policy and development plans prepared by the NCDC be referred to the Committee for its consideration. Thus the Committee can comment on planning initiatives where this is considered appropriate in the public interest. The Committee recognises the serious nature of traffic and parking problems in and around Civic and to avoid compounding the problem recommends that the Commission and the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services provide greater impetus for the development of other town centres by locating government departments and authorities not already placed in central locations in the new town centres. This is particularly important in the growth of the Tuggeranong area. This has already been addressed in the Committee's report on the eighty-ninth series of variations relating to the development of section 38 in Civic and the Committee reiterates its support for an undertaking from the NCDC that a review of the civic centre policy plan be completed by June 1987.

During the inquiry the Committee was alerted to problems concerning the system of land tenure in the Australian Capital Territory and the administration of the leasehold system. The Committee has decided to pursue this by commissioning an independent study of the system. The Committee was specifically asked in one of its terms of reference to report on the impact of the plan upon the south-east region of New South Wales. Any discussion of regional co-ordination and consultation should include the impact of Canberra's development on the surrounding region of New South Wales, and the Committee notes that the recommendation of a report by a joint Commonwealth-State and local government committee in September 1976 that a Commonwealth and south-east region advisory committee be set up has not been acted on. The Committee recommends that priority be given to the formation of the organisation proposed in 1976 realising that the need for such a regional body is now becoming acute as problems relating to the expansion of Canberra and its increased population levels are already having greater and greater impact on the region as Canberra continues to expand. In that context, on behalf of the Committee I would like to express appreciation to one of the Committee members, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), for his contribution and his understanding of the impact of Canberra's growth on the nearby region.

The question of the availability of appropriate land for residential development in the Australian Capital Territory was also raised during the Committee's examination of the metropolitan plan. In investigating the scope for large-scale redevelopment, the Committee was made aware of the potential for such redevelopment in areas presently occupied by the Department of Defence, such as Belconnen, Jerrabomberra and Harman Bonshaw. I am happy that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is in the House to hear this recommendation. The Committee tried to pursue this suggestion by asking for information and co-operation from the Department of Defence. The Defence Department declined to appear before the Committee and did not respond to subsequent requests for information. The Committee is extremely critical of this lack of co-operation and, as no evidence was given to the Committee to justify continued use of the areas by the Defence Department, and because of the high opportunity costs of such continued use, the Committee recommends that the Department relocate from the areas of Belconnen, Jerrabomberra and Harman Bonshaw, thus releasing these valuable sites and redressing the high cost in lost opportunity for this land. Obviously, much discussion is still required to ensure that there is effective use of that land by the Commonwealth and the local community.

Finally, I would like to stress that this is a very important report and the first major public review of the Y-plan which has shaped the development of Canberra since 1970. The Committee's report makes recommendations which will influence the future of Canberra in the next century and marks another stage in the planning and overall development of Canberra as the national capital. I would also like at this stage to record the Committee's thanks to our staff, particularly to the clerk, Bjarne Nordin. I would also like to thank my colleagues for their support in preparing this report. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to draw attention to one of the conclusions of the report which the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) has just mentioned and to emphasise its importance. It became apparent to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory during the inquiry that the leasehold system, while it served the Territory well in its first phase of development, is experiencing problems in the redevelopment of the city's growth. The chaos resulting from the lack of parking places in Civic is a direct consequence of the current approach to the redevelopment of land in the Australian Capital Territory. Unfortunately, although it may be the most visible consequence of the present system of administration, it is not the most serious consequence.

SPEECH.PARA: What is far more worrying is the possibility that businesses may be making a lot of money out of the low betterment tax at the expense of the taxpayer when lease purpose clauses are varied. It is essential, too, that the determination and administration of lease purpose clauses and the process for their variation and enforcement, as well as appeal mechanisms, be examined, because there have been complaints and problems with all of them.

The Committee considered various ways of making an inquiry of this kind. We thought of doing it ourselves, but we felt that we were not in a position to make such an inquiry because of its technical nature and the time it would take. A judicial inquiry was another possibility, but we really felt that the simplest, most straightforward and shortest approach was to ask a consultant to write a report for us. We have been very fortunate in that Professor Max Neutze, the head of the Institute of Urban Studies at the Australian National University, has agreed to conduct the study. Professor Neutze is eminently suited for the task. He is one of Australia's leading urban economists. He is the author of Australia's two most authoritative books on urban policy and planning.

His terms of reference for the inquiry will be, first, to examine the nature of the leasehold system of land tenure and the opportunities it creates for planning management of the Australian Capital Territory; secondly, to examine the consequences of the current approach to administering the system in relation to both development and redevelopment, including such aspects as the determination and administration of lease purpose clauses, enforcement of lease purposes, the process for variation of lease purposes, the nature and rates of betterment tax when lease purposes are varied, and the appeal mechanisms. He will also look at institutional arrangements for managing the leasehold system by the National Capital Development Commission and the Department of Territories, although it is possible that because of a recent initiative by the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) that issue may be resolved by the time he gets to that part of his inquiry. Finally, he will look at policy relating to the expiration and renewal of leases. Of course, an issue in a leasehold system is what happens when the leases expire.

This inquiry will be quite important in the development of policy on the leasehold system and leasehold administration in the Australian Capital Territory. I am very glad that my colleagues on the Committee supported the conduct of this inquiry. I look forward to seeing the final report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There has been a great change in the relationship between the Australian Capital Territory and south-east regional New South Wales since I became a member of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. I can only take some of the credit. Credit must also be given to my colleagues the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) and the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). They have both been very co-operative in including the importance of the south-east region in any proposed changes or any proposed planning discussions for metropolitan Canberra. It has been particularly important in regard to the report that is now before us. Previously there were attitudes both within the region and within Canberra that the two were separate and must be seen as separate. There is now much more emphasis on the fact that both areas need to be seen as partners in the development of the region, and recognition of the fact that Canberra is a natural regional centre.

SPEECH.PARA: We have included in the report a lot of attention to regional considerations, as the honourable member for Canberra said. I particularly mention roads. We have given attention to the need for improvement of many of the access roads into Canberra. I must say that I am delighted that my friend and colleague the member for Monaro in the New South Wales Parliament, the Minister for Corrective Services, the Hon. John Akister, has had included in his electorate the area between Queanbeyan and Bungendore along the road to the coast. I am absolutely confident, having regard to his record regarding roads in the rest of his electorate, that New South Wales will raise the level of priority given to the coast road in future allocations to road budgets from Federal funding which is made available to that Government. The honourable member for Canberra and the honourable member for Fraser have both given me strong support regarding improvements to the road between Tharwa in the Australian Capital Territory and Adaminaby in New South Wales. I thank them for that. The honourable member for Canberra came on a tour and the honourable member for Fraser attended a meeting with local people in Parliament House.

There are many other matters which I do not want to go into because time is short. But I would not want this Parliament to conclude without thanking my colleagues and the many citizens in Canberra and south-east New South Wales who have looked for a promotion of the common cause that exists between the two areas, rather than looking for differences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the third and fourth reports of the Committee for 1987, relating to the construction of the Department of Aviation Central Training College in the Australian Capital Territory, and the construction of an air movements cargo hangar at Royal Australian Air Force base, Richmond, New South Wales, respectively. I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Because of time constraints I will not test the indulgence of the House by addressing the cargo handling facility at RAAF base Richmond, that being a straightforward referral. On behalf of the Committee, I would like to make some remarks in respect of the Department of Aviation Central Training College, Australian Capital Territory. The proposal referred to the Committee in January this year was for the construction of a Central Training College at Pialligo, Australian Capital Territory, for the Department of Aviation. In April the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) requested the Committee to extend the scope of its inquiry to include an examination of the cheaper alternative of locating the college at Watson High School, which will close at the end of 1987. It is intended to accommodate the Department of Aviation air traffic control, flight services, search and rescue, flight standards, administrative and ADP training schools in the Central Training College. A new air traffic control and flight services simulator is being acquired by the Department for training air traffic control personnel. It is due to be delivered in September 1988 and Aviation required completion of the simulator building by that date. However, the Department of Housing and Construction has advised that the earliest date by which a simulator building can be completed at Watson High School is November 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: At present air traffic control, flight services and flight standards training is carried out in Melbourne. The other three schools are located in leased premises in Canberra. The Department of Aviation submitted that there would be advantages in collocating all training schools in Canberra. Whilst Aviation's future responsibilities are unclear due to the establishment of the Civil Aviation Corporation, there will be a continuing requirement for specialist air traffic control personnel to be trained.

Accordingly, the Committee recommended that the air traffic control and flight service schools should be relocated to Canberra and colocated in the one complex with the other training schools already here. The Watson High School buildings are basically sound, although it will be necessary to construct a new building to house the simulator because none of the existing buildings are considered suitable for that purpose.

The limit of cost estimate for the Pialligo proposal is $11.2m. Indicative costs for the Watson High School are $9.115m. Both costs include the provision of a simulator building at $2.45m. The indicative costs for the Watson High School proposal are based on achievement as closely as practicable to the requirements on which the Pialligo design was based. Cost reductions could be achieved if the Department of Aviation altered its briefing requirements. The Committee accordingly agrees to the conversion of Watson High School provided that significant reductions in costs are achieved resulting from the Department of Aviation re-examining the scope of its briefing requirements. The Committee will hold a further public hearing to examine the limit of cost estimate for the conversion of Watson High School.

In conclusion, I would like to address a number of matters relating to the reference about which the Committee is not entirely happy. They relate to timing and the consequential urgency attached to the examination of what was a most complex subject. The Committee believes that the requirement for the continued training of air traffic control personnel, the arrival of the simulator in September 1988, the time taken by the location of the Australian Government Employment Committee to examine the proposal and the need for the Public Works Committee to consider the Watson High School proposal after the work had been referred, placed considerable time constraints on the Committee and have given it very little option but to agree to the work proceeding. I thank the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was adjourned on this Bill, the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, I was speaking about the changes in the bounty payable on phosphates and I was referring particularly to its impact on wheat in Australia. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is in the House and he will be aware that the decline in wheat prices has put considerable strain on the wheat industry in Australia. In the coming season these sorts of prices will probably place additional pressure on the wheat growing areas of this land. Yet this decision has been taken in the light of these conditions, and it will fall very heavily on the shoulders of the wheat farmers as a further cost burden.

SPEECH.PARA: The cost of fertiliser has already increased by 14 per cent in the last 12 months. At the same time the price received for grain has fallen by almost 30 per cent. Since the Budget decision some fertiliser prices have fallen, and this is rather interesting. However, the price of all fertilisers will be lower only while stocks last. After that, the imported fertiliser will be significantly more expensive than it was before the Budget. This leaves a margin for the Australian manufacturers to put up their prices. The farmers who use imported fertiliser will be $13m worse off under this legislation. The Opposition will be moving an amendment in the Committee stage, but it does not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus measure covering amendments to various bounty and subsidy Acts. As was pointed out by the Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Mr Barry Jones) in his second reading speech, one of the amendments covers the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981. This relates to the extension of eligibility for bounty for a proportion of the overhead costs associated with the production for export. This applies only to companies which produce at least 50 per cent of the local market. It will enable them to claim 30 per cent of the overhead costs associated with the export component of their business. I believe this is fair and equitable and, even more importantly, that it will help to encourage export development.

SPEECH.PARA: It is acknowledged in part by this Government that we, as a nation, must export or perish. This is not putting it too strongly. Unless we, as a nation, become more enthused about exporting, we will inevitably become a Third World country. Whilst this sounds simple, it is not so, for as a nation we must be selective about what we export. We should be seeking to develop exports in areas where we have a natural or intellectual advantage and we should be seeking niches in the export markets around the world, for we must diversify our trading base. Japan and America are apt to act with extreme caprice, and I believe they will do so even more in the future.

This particular amendment allows the manufacture of yarn at the lowest possible cost to downstream users, while correcting export anomalies. It at once helps the yarn producers by spreading their costs over bigger production, but places no impediment in the way of the producers of cloth or clothing who, through their excellence of quality or design, can sell on the export market and thereby give Australia the benefits of value added exports. Clearly high fashion is an option and run of the mill clothing manufacture is not. I would not like to be working for Third World wages, and I certainly would not like my children to be working for Third World wages. It is interesting to reflect on the policies of the Opposition, which seem to hinge very much on making Australia competitive by reducing our wages to the level of those in Third World countries. Clearly, this is not the way to go. We should be looking for the innovation and excellence of design that will help us to sell on those markets.

The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) has been lamenting the problems of the rural sector. It seems to me that he has not thought through his arguments particularly well. The particular amendments mentioned in the Bill to the Fertilisers Subsidy Act 1986 are really a machinery measure to allow the payment of the subsidy to producers of the local product. It is true that the National Farmers Federation claims that this bounty decision is going to raise an additional $40m in costs for Australian farmers. I do not believe it has ever documented that claim. Even if it is true, it is also true that if there were an impost on imported fertiliser, there would be the potential for a corresponding decrease in local production. In other words, what was lost on diammonium phosphate, DAP, was gained on the monoammonium phosphate, MAP. Because of this legislation Australian manufacturers are already moving into the manufacture of diammonium phosphate.

Another extension of this legislation is the long term security of phosphate supplies for farmers. It is quite clear that the world supply is insecure. Supplies from Florida will not always be available, only on an opportunity basis. The other large production potential is in Morocco. I certainly would not like to see Australian farmers locked into a supply from an area of the world that is prone to troubles from so many sources. For instance, the interdiction of the Suez Canal could cause havoc to the supply for Australian farmers if they depended on phosphate from the Mediterranean or from the edge of the Atlantic.

The future security of Australian farmers lies in Australia becoming much more self-sufficient. Our traditional supplies are running out. There is no doubt that the Christmas Island supply is running down and that Nauru is suffering the same problem. But we have enormous potential in Mount Weld and in other places. Farmers must have security. I believe that this legislation will help to make supply from Mount Weld a certainty. It will go ahead, in part because of this legislation.

The implications of this legislation go far wider than the farming community. The overwhelming environmental problem facing Australia today lies not in forestry regrowth in Tasmania, so beloved by the middle class trendies, but in soil erosion. It is a problem that this Government has addressed. But it is interesting to note that our contribution to the solution of the problem is small compared with the amount of money we are prepared to pay Tasmania for its loss of profits.

Through this legislation I believe we can help maintain the fertility of our soils, and thus do something about soil erosion and salinity. It must be recognised that soil erosion and salinity are environmental problems that affect all Australians, whether they live in the city or in the country. They also have enormous implications for our foreign exchange. There is an element of long term thinking in this Bill that was not recognised by the honourable member for Ryan.

This Bill addresses the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act. When the Government moved to introduce the subsidy-a subsidy demanded by farmers-an anomaly developed. At the time of the enactment of the legislation the then bounty did not apply to equipment that was already manufactured and in the dealer's yard. It was clear that the equipment manufactured during the life of the bounty would be dearer. This amending legislation is designed to cover that anomaly.

The Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill is a very straightforward, common-sense piece of legislation. It is for that reason that it is not meeting a great deal of opposition from honourable members opposite. I note that the honourable member for Ryan read extensively from the second reading speech of the Minister for Science. One must therefore assume that he is, in large measure, in agreement with the legislation. It is the sort of legislation that has characterised this Government. It is common-sense, straightforward legislation. It tidies up existing legislation and it shows that this Government is prepared to look at issues as they arise and consider them on the basis of the facts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) was fast asleep when the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) was speaking to the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. Although the honourable member for Ryan said that he did not oppose it, he foreshadowed a major amendment to be moved at the Committee stage which will remove Part V from the Bill. If the honourable member for Kalgoorlie sees that as being in substantial agreement one can say only, as I said before, that he was asleep. SPEECH.PARA: Let it not be said that we agree with all aspects of the Bill. TALK.START.PARA: —Another broken promise.

—Another broken promise. They are the costs that Australian farmers have to bear in one form or another. We might say that those costs are rebatable, but people working in the bush do not have access to a rebate. For the farming community, those costs are inbuilt. —Very little.

—I am glad of that interjection because I can recall a comment from the miners of Australia that the fringe benefits tax would cost them $2 per hour extra.
