—I will because we have in front of us a confession by the Treasury that the fringe benefits tax has taken more than was originally estimated. I assume that the miners are paying more, the financial institutions are paying more, and so on. Does the honourable member want to talk about the capital gains tax? I invite him to make an interjection on that. It is a further cost borne by our producers, who are trying to cope with the inconsistency of our overseas markets.
—The big increase is due to the players in the stock markets.

—The Minister for Primary Industry interjects because he, amongst many others, says that our problems are all international; that we are in a bad way and have to suffer a decrease in the standard of living purely because of the international markets. I do not deny that the international markets are tough. I would like to talk about what subsidies and bounties, applicable in other countries but not available in Australia, are doing to our market. The Minister for Primary Industry will not convince me, the people in the bush or the small businessperson that many of the problems now facing people have not been imported from outside. They have been a result of this Government's--
—Tell the sugar industry about that.

—All right, I will talk about the sugar industry if the Minister so desires. The same thing applies to the sugar industry in relation to the centralised wage system, the cost of fuel, the fringe benefits tax and the cost of everything else. So the sugar industry is not exempt, unless I have misread the legislation, from the implications of all those things that the Minister now tries to deny. I believe that I do not have to repeat what the then shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), said in connection with the Fertilisers Subsidy Bill in November 1986, but I refer honourable members to Hansard of that date and to the situation put by the honourable member for Gwydir at that time, even though it was an amendment only to clear up some inconsistencies about the reduced competition that would be available in the work place in trying to bring down farming costs and provide assistance to manufacturing.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we must admit that a tariff or bounty puts a crutch under some businesses which they are not prepared to throw away. If it were denied that crutch, I am sure that manufacturing business in Australia would be a lot stronger than it is today, that is, if it had to get out and compete on an even playing field. I note that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is nodding his head and I suppose he is doing so from the point of view of the 1960s, but I remind the Minister that the 1980s are a lot different from the 1960s. We need policies applicable to the current decade and not those from back where the Labor Party likes to languish-in the pre-World War I era. In that context I point out that the centralised wage system gives to a section of the community an advantage which is not available to others.

I will not go on at any length about what the honourable member for Gwydir said last November, but I will make a few comments about a question I asked of the Minister for Primary Industry about the parliamentary delegation to the United States of America. I agree that Australian parliamentarians should be face to face with both European Community and American legislators because of the difficulties being faced by the rest of the world in these market conditions as a result of massive subsidisation and bounties available in those countries, and particularly on sugar. Under the pricing system available in America, increased production of sweetners has been encouraged-although not necessarily from sugar cane-to the extent that I believe in a very short while that country will be exporting and not importing sugar. I must say that, to the credit of the Australian sugar industry, it has coped with that very well. As I understand it, just a few years ago Australia enjoyed a quota of some 250,000 tonnes. Within three years the Australian sugar industry has had to cope, and has coped, with a reduction in the quota to 74,000 tonnes. Of course we are now looking down the barrel of the complete elimination of the quota within the next few years. I understand that within the last decade, and certainly within the last 15 years, the preferential quota has been reduced from 800,000 tonnes to 74,000 tonnes. The Australian industry has been able to cope because of its efficiency and the manner in which it has been able to react to this, and due credit should be paid to it.

The main problem is again emphasised through the payment of these subsidies indiscriminately for electoral purposes to keep a certain sector within the power of the Government. But what will be the effect? While Australia can cope with a decrease in the quota, it may not be able to cope with America becoming an exporter as far as these subsidies are concerned. What effect will that have? That will mean that, as a result of the overproduction, the market price will be decreased and as a consequence Australia will find itself fighting for traditional markets quite apart from the United States as that country applies import conditions. We can again see an exacerbation of the situation currently facing Australia due to the EEC subsidies and the American push so that Australia will be fighting harder and harder out there in the traditional markets. That is another effect of tariffs and bounties. At least a bounty is probably preferential from the point of view that it is a taxpayer cost and not a consumer cost. A tariff becomes a consumer cost. It is certainly not a level playing field out in the market-place.

The wording of the legislation suggests that it is a collective Bill. As we understand it, the other amendments are put through at this time of the year to accommodate quite a few of the other aspects of Industries Assistance Commission reports and other amendments that are required, and I will mention a few of them. This Bill proposes to amend the Bounty (Textiles Yarns) Act 1981 to give effect to a recommendation arising from the Government's textile, clothing and footwear decision of 27 November 1986. I have already mentioned the Fertilisers Subsidy Act 1986 and the effect of amendments to that Act. There are amendments to the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act 1986 to correct eligibility for subsidy provisions in the Act as a result of legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department. There are amendments to the Bounty (Books) Act 1986 and to the Bounty (Bedsheeting) Act 1977 and small technical amendments to the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984 and the Bounty (Ship Repair) Act 1986. As the Minister for Science might say, it is terribly rivetting stuff, but unfortunately we must go through this process and it is just as well that it is an omnibus measure.

I return to the whole question of tariffs and the protection being offered by the Government of the day. I know that there is a long history in Australia of raising tariffs for different reasons and in different circumstances at different times. But the basic effect is that the primary producers of Australia particularly would count the cost of protecting local manufacturing industry as being one of its major input costs against which they have no redress. While we continue down the line of what I might describe as indiscriminately offering tariff protection without looking at the whole problem that this creates for Australian producers, particularly those who have no redress against the costs and imposts that they must face because of it, their costs will become higher and they will increasingly scrap for their share of a toehold in the international market. Interest rates are part and parcel of what this Government has bequeathed to particularly the primary industries of Australia, but that is a factor that the Government will have to face up to at the July election. We have no intention of opposing the Bill but the honourable member for Ryan has foreshadowed an amendment to delete Part V of the Bill. We are being consistent with what we argued six months ago on 26 November, and we will support that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual when the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) speaks, we hear the real dilemma of the National Party of Australia. The National Party is keen to pull away the props from industry in Australia, but it does not say much about existing procedures in the sugar industry, for instance. That has always been a National Party problem-it is socialist in bad times. Quite frankly, it has never been able to resolve that dilemma. It is happy to have privatisation, but it would like to see another word for it because it does not want to hear that word used very often particularly as there are Commonwealth banks in most towns; it does not want to see the word used very often in relation to Telecom Australia because privatisation would mean that telephone rentals would cost an extra $300 to $700 per year; and it does not want to hear it used in connection with Australia Post because it knows that there would be no postal service or higher taxes would have to be paid and charges would have to go up astronomically to provide that service. With the more lucrative parts of Telecom, Australia Post, the Commonwealth Bank and other government instrumentalities being in the major cities, there is a cross-subsidisation to country areas. This has always been the National Party's dilemma.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer briefly to the amendment in the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill to the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981. The amendment provides that producers' overheads which have been associated with export production may be included in an amount on which bounty is paid from 1 July 1987. If at least 50 per cent of the production of textile yarn is sold in Australia, a bounty will be claimable on 30 per cent of the bountiable costs associated with production for export. There was an anomaly which penalised yarn producers who were exporting. This important measure acknowledges the importance of exports in terms of economic recovery.

Our exports are bringing $9 billion less into our national economy. This explains many of the measures which have had to be taken by the Government and explains to quite an extent the Government's economic strategy. There are a number of answers to this reduction in overseas sales. One is to increase exports and another is to reduce imports. Another alternative is to increase the processing products before they leave our country. My colleague the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) mentioned this when he spoke on other legislation earlier today. We are now considering the future of the timber industry in the south-east region of New South Wales. We need to consider the possibility of increasing local processing of timber before it leaves the country. We need to consider the possibility of pulping woodchips before they leave Australia. This would mean that more jobs were created in Australia in the production of processed or semi-processed material. It would also mean that we received a much higher amount from the sale of the export. How much better it is to export processed leather rather than unprocessed cattle hides, as we do to quite an extent at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can't afford to process it now.
—We are gradually becoming able to afford to process it. It is interesting that Japan is now looking to other countries to process its products.
—Have you seen the cost of the yen?

—The value of the yen is very high, so it is more inviting for the Japanese to process their products in Australia. We should be saying to Japan: How about processing some of your woodchips and other products in Australia? Japan is taking the matter seriously. The Japanese are now exporting the Nissan motor product to Japan from Australia. In addition, they are looking to major car cities in the United States of America to manufacture for them. It is a good time for us to be talking to other countries about processing to a much greater extent in our country.

SPEECH.PARA: Goulburn, which used to be in my electorate, has a semi-processing plant for wool. How much better it is to process wool in this region than to export the raw wool to other countries. We could get a much higher price for it and, in the process, employ many people in Australia. I have recently been helping people in Wapengo, near Bega. Don and Anna Fern manufacture a pillow called `Beautiful Dreamer'. I was delighted to try out the pillow. It was a delight to sleep on. It is resilient and very comfortable. Those people need a little encouragement from government, I believe, to make what would be a very valuable export. Anyone who uses the pillow would agree that it is a great innovation. It is resilient and comfortable and very few people would be allergic to it.

When I started producing mohair in 1971, there was almost no mohair produced in Australia. At that time Australia was importing about $2m a year worth of mohair. There are processing firms in Australia-in Victoria, at Launceston in Tasmania, in South Australia and in other areas. This is creating more jobs. It is linking up with a growing industry in Australia-the angora-mohair industry. This is particularly important in terms of the situation in South Africa. In my view, the situation will continue to deteriorate and a major mohair producing country will have one of its major exports threatened. We are in a position to produce good mohair and to take a place in the world market. That is important when South African production could be affected. I commend the general thrust of the legislation, particularly the amendments to the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981. It is important that we encourage exports as a part of our economic recovery, and this legislation does just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill covers a number of aspects that are of significance in my electorate of O'Connor. I wish, therefore, to speak to the Bill in two sections. In particular, I wish to talk about the amendments to the Fertilisers Subsidy Act and the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act which, of course, deals with farm machinery. Mr Deputy Speaker, you are probably aware that when the original legislation regarding fertiliser, which this legislation now amends, came before the House, Opposition members and the coalition opposed the Government's proposal. Traditionally, subsidy, not bounty has been paid on fertiliser in Australia. Subsidy was paid to farmers, to agriculturalists. It was accepted that the fertiliser was needed on what are very unproductive soils in many areas. Large quantities had to be used and consequently farmers needed some financial assistance. So a subsidy was paid directly to farmers. Originally, it was paid only on product manufactured in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: However, times changed. Farmers started to move to what was known as high analysis fertiliser, of which Australia did not produce a large amount. Originally, the fertiliser companies that manufactured within Australia imported the product. However, as time went by it was realised that other people could import it, and some rural co-operatives in my State-groups of farmers-got together to reduce the price in the very difficult circumstances that confronted them at the time. When they started to import this product, we found that literally hundreds of dollars a tonne could be taken off the price and delivery schedules started to be designed to get it as close as possible to the point of consumption.

At that time I represented the area of Esperance and regular shipments of DAP, diammonium phosphate, which is a high analysis fertiliser, were being shipped straight into that port. Farmers who lived only short distances from the port were able to overcome the substantial transport costs with which they were confronted when that fertiliser had to come from Kwinana in Western Australia where the bulk of it was being manufactured or imported by the fertiliser company. Consequently, the Government of the day-the Liberal-National Party coalition-decided that, to follow its policies of subsidising the farmer and encouraging him to put the necessary fertilisers on the ground in order to increase production, the subsidies should be paid equally on the imported product and the locally manufactured product.

The principle was simple. It was not a subsidy to assist manufacturers in Australia who, as we know, had to put up with all the demands of the union movement; rather, it was assistance to farmers. In the past couple of days this Government has demonstrated that it has been unable to get Australian wheat out of the country. I have sent a facsimile of my letter to the Trade Practices Commissioner asking him why he has not taken action in relation to the shipment of grain which is blocked at Geelong and which should be on its way to Fiji. I have reminded him that, without consulting anyone, he has the power to address breaches in his Act, and he frequently does so where it applies to the business community. Frequently, we read of substantial fines amounting to tens of thousands of dollars being imposed by the Commissioner. Where is he on this issue?

We know that a secondary boycott, in terms of the trade union movement, relates to an action by trade unionists that does not relate to their employer and that is not in the interests of the workers employed. In other words, it does not relate to a pay increase or to the redress of some safety issue, which is a primary boycott and that is permitted. A secondary boycott relates to a situation where people stick their noses into other people's business and they do so with bad intent.

I note-and I wonder why it has taken so long-that the Australian Wheat Board is now contemplating taking action under section 45d, but the real responsibility lies with the Commissioner and not the Wheat Board. It would have to charge the farmers of Australia for the legal costs, which are never fully recovered, and it should have to act on this matter. I intend to put pressure on the trade unionists to ensure that we do not lose our Fijian market. The military rulers in Fiji know the old adage that one never lets the populace go hungry. Under the current conditions in Fiji, that would be a disaster. The military rulers will ensure that Fiji receives its grain by purchasing it from America where the trade unionists encourage democracy. But they are nationalists; they will support their American farmers while our Australian trade unionists thumb their noses at the farmers who generate the income which they need to survive. That is what will happen. I have called on the Trade Practices Commissioner.

I make the point that this Government made the decision that only Australian industry must be supported. As a consequence, it has moved from a subsidy to a bounty and the bounty is paid now to local manufacturers. We are advised that that will reduce the price of the fertiliser provided, and so it will. But it has no effect whatsoever on their growing costs because they have been given a competitive advantage and they will gradually absorb the cost of the advantage that is given to them in that bounty.

This legislation seeks to tidy up a couple of points, but as a matter of principle we sought to have those clauses removed. We did not like the original idea and we do not favour any amendment to it. Today, I obtained some figures, which I know to be correct, relating to the increase in the cost of superphosphate. In 1975 a tonne of superphosphate cost a Western Australian farmer $54, but the price has continued to escalate and today it is substantially higher than that. Single superphosphate costs about $113 a tonne. In fact, in 1984-these are the latest figures I have-it cost about $113 and I think it is now more in the order of $140. That is a huge cost increase.

When comparing those figures on a percentage basis with the value of a tonne of wheat, in 1982-83 a farmer received $187 for a tonne of wheat and paid $86.35 for a tonne of superphosphate. The superphosphate represented 46 per cent of the value of a tonne of wheat. Today, the farmer receives $145 per tonne of wheat, which is a decrease of $42 per tonne. I think that figure is more like $140, but using the figure of $113, that represents 78 per cent of the value of the tonne of wheat. In other words, as a percentage of return on his product, a farmer now pays almost double the price for the superphosphate, the Australian manufactured product, when compared with the other product.

That is what is wrong with this country. One sector of the economy cannot be exposed to the ravages of foreign markets and then be expected to carry the country's internal problems. Over the past two years the international price of money has decreased to one-quarter of what it was. The international price of fuel has decreased to one-half. These are probably two of the greatest inputs to farming today. Because of that fact, the price of other commodities such as wheat has fallen, but our farmers have to accept the fall in the price of wheat without receiving the advantages in the fall of those other two products.

In relation to the price of money-interest rates-it is the first time in the history of Australia that our interest rates have been so far out of kilter with international interest rates. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) can tell the public time and again about the levels to which interest rates rose under the Fraser Government, but the reality is that, generally, they were still lower than those in many other countries, including Japan, the United States of America and Great Britain. Today, the American farmer pays about 8 per cent for his money, the Japanese farmer pays about 4 per cent for his money, but the Australian farmer, if he can get it, pays 22 per cent. Of course, this year many thousands are unable to obtain the money and, as a consequence, they are being driven off their farms.

I ask the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) for an assurance in relation to the amendments of the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act 1986. The reason for amending the legislation is to ensure that machinery that is still in stock-in other words, manufactured before the due date-should be considered as being manufactured after the due date. Traditionally, a lot of this machinery is carried in stock by machinery dealers and that is a matter that I want to address in particular. Any stock that was unused-was unpurchased by farmers and was not put to work-should therefore be considered as being manufactured after the due date. I commend the Government for this initiative and I thank it, because this provision will be of some help. The amendment states:
Section 9 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsection (8) and substituting the following subsection:
``(8) Where:
(a) the last substantial process in the manufacture of subsidised equipment was completed by a manufacturer before 15 April 1986; and
(b) the equipment had not, before that day, been:
(i) sold, or otherwise disposed of, to a person for use by that person in commercial agriculture; or
(ii) used in commercial agriculture; . . .
be deemed to have been manufactured on that day at registered premises;

The amendment does not say it, but I assume that if the goods had left the manufacturer and had been sold to a machinery dealer the subsidy would still apply if they were still in the hands of the dealer. That is a matter that I would like clarified. The amendment makes it very clear that, if the machinery is not being used in commercial agriculture, it will be eligible and, therefore, I assume the same thing would apply if it were still in the hands of the dealer. If that is not the case, there will still be huge disadvantages. Unfortunately for the machinery dealers in Australia, who today are generally worse off than even farmers, the reality is that they have been the repository of the manufacturers' production. They retain their agencies and they have been forced to take large amounts of stock from the manufacturers and to carry it in their yards. When sales were high, that was not such a bad arrangement. As we all know, the interest rates for carrying that stock on hand are very high, but they are discounted relative to the amount of sales that are put through the finance companies. While sales were booming, that stock was held on hand and the ploughs and other items that are dealt with in this legislation were handled at very low interest rates. The reality is that now the sales have dropped dramatically; machinery dealers are being asked to pay rates as high as 33 per cent on what is known as their floor plan. I do not think that that shows the finance companies in a good light, but I have to admit that it reflects the current interest regime for which I hold this Government totally responsible. I have pointed out that this reflects an interest regime that is purely the responsibility of this Government, and it is unique to Australia. Nevertheless, it is creating many problems.

The Farm Machinery Dealers Association has put out quite a lot of information in recent times which highlights a problem that the Government has to consider. In the first case, government has done quite a lot to assist farmers by way of rural reconstruction funding, drought loans and other things of that nature. But, unlike in the past, the same rules have not been applied to farm machinery dealers. Those dealers have been collapsing at a surprising rate. They certainly feature prominently in the bankruptcy statistics that I mentioned earlier today when I highlighted the fact that we are now approaching a record of 8,000 bankruptcies in any one year.

Very large businesses do not go bankrupt; they are liquidated. Bankruptcy applies to small businesses. Without even any proper investigation of the figures, we know that when bankruptcies are growing, it is people in small business, the consumers and the wage earners who are going bankrupt. It is a matter of major concern. My office deals with these matters constantly. It really requires the effort of the State Government in Western Australia-I have approached it on the matter-to give to machinery dealers and other country businesses the same opportunities as farmers to be able to get low interest loans, messy as they may be. The Government must deal with the problem.

I will highlight just some of the problems for the machinery dealers in my electorate. Nearly one-third of them have disappeared in the last couple of years. They have either literally gone broke or have seen that there was no future in the industry and that they had to get out of it. People who were employing 15 to 20 workers are now employing two or three. I am aware of the time constraints today but it is my obligation to put this fact on the record because these people are really suffering. Small businesses in rural areas are at the coal-face of the rural recession. There are still a number of farmers who have good financial resources. There are many in huge difficulty. But the ones who have the financial resources have, quite predictably, put a staple in their cheque books. They are making do with the old equipment and all they are buying are the spare parts. Although that business is what many of these dealers are being obliged to live on today, that is not the business that they need. They are not geared for it; they have been in the habit of selling new machinery.

Other factors apply. For instance, this Government has thrown out the income equalisation deposit scheme and the investment allowance. Of course, the investment allowance was a major source of business for machinery dealers. Many farmers, when they had a good year, particularly after they lost the income equalisation deposits, were anxious to minimise their tax by investing in new plant. I do not think that was dishonest. It created work for many Australians. They have been the big losers in all these things that are happening in country areas. Generally, the machinery dealers were the biggest employers in any single country town. I do not have the time but, if I did, I would cite some of the figures provided to me by the Secretary of the Farm Machinery Dealers Association, Mr Sandy Lewis in Western Australia. He has given me figures just to show the sorts of things that are happening. His report states that the losses in this year were caused mainly by high overheads, taxes and interest rates; they have been the main contributors. Interest rates were up by at least one-third.

Of course, these dealers have also been hit by the fringe benefits tax, because they are obliged to provide housing and those sorts of amenities to their workers in country areas. They have to provide the workers with vehicles to go out and do the work, so they have been hit by the fringe benefits tax at a time when most of them are making losses. That is a disaster. Nevertheless, this amendment will ease their burden a little and therefore I must support it and congratulate the Government for taking that step. It is time that the Government recognised that small country businesses are in a disastrous situation, particularly machinery dealers because they have lost their business as a result of this Government's policies, the slow-down in business and the inability of the Government to do something about the cost structure that is being forced on them. The Government could do something. There is no need to have fuel prices or interest rates at their present level. Once farmers have the proper rates, the international rates, they can get back to buying in their country towns; they can afford to re-equip their farms and do the sorts of things that prosperity demands. I ask the Government to take serious note of the matters that I have raised today. Even though it may not be here much longer, it could do something about them in the next couple of weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Part V of this exhilarating piece of drafting to the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 comprises amendments to the Fertilisers Subsidy Act 1986. When the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) spoke in the second reading debate it was alleged that if there were removal of the subsidy on imports without the competition from imports there would be no assurance that domestic manufacturers would pass on the benefit of the subsidy, which they are required to do, to the domestic end users and that a monopoly situation would be created amongst the local manufacturers. I think the reply to that is that the current legislation requires the manufacturers to pass on the full benefit of the subsidies. Eligibility for the subsidy for manufacturers is expressly dependent on the full benefit of the subsidy being passed on to the purchaser or end user of the product in the price charged for it. As for the local monopoly argument, there is no evidence of this, nor is there any evidence of effective barriers to entry. A desirable rationalisation is occurring and new prospects are being considered.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Ryan also expressed doubt as to whether local manufacturers had the capacity to produce sufficient high analysis phosphate and nitrogen products to meet current farmer demand with the claimed removal of competitively priced imported fertilisers. However, both the Industries Assistance Commission and the Department of Primary Industry have concluded that there is sufficient capacity to manufacture all the high analysis phosphatic fertiliser used in Australia. DEBATE.TITLE: PROCEEDS OF CRIME BILL 1987[COGNATE BILL:PROCEEDS OF CRIME (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Upon which Mr Spender had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that-
(1) it comprises a major and novel legislative package of 104 clauses;

(2) it was introduced on Thursday, 30 April 1987, and has been called on for debate on the second reading on 11 May 1987, a period which allows less than adequate time for examination and consultation by the Opposition, and

(3) it imposes on financial institutions heavy obligations for the retention of records concerning financial transactions, yet no statement from the Business Regulation Review Unit of the cost of such measures has been provided to the House'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I last spoke on the Proceeds of Crime Bill and the Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, prior to the debate being adjourned, I referred to the Government's record of attack on serious crime in this country. Because of the actions of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who rightly deserves the title of the Eliot Ness of Australian crime, that record stands unsurpassed in the history of this country. Never before in this country has such a large number of Bills that go to the heart of organised crime been introduced by a single government. This goes back to the establishment of the National Crime Authority. The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill, the Proceeds of Crime Bill and the Cash Transactions Reports Bill form part of this Government's attack on crime. Collectively, these measures form the weapons that any civilised nation needs to stop the tentacles of crime infiltrating the communities that we in this House should all hold so dear. They should be seen as a very strong collective package.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very proud to be part of a government and a caucus-I am Chairman of the legal and administrative committee of Caucus-which have worked so hard and done so much to assist the Attorney in bringing these Bills forth. That committee sat for many long hours and went through each of these Bills clause by clause. It did that for a very serious reason. These Bills, quite rightly, start to impede on what would formerly have been regarded as the rights of individuals. They create new rights. They infiltrate commercial activities and require commercial institutions to do certain things to ensure that proper tracing procedures can be carried out to tackle the proceeds of crime. Because of those changes-because, in fact, there is perhaps a diminution in the rights of some corporations and individuals-the committee spent long hours going through each paragraph and clause of the Bills to ensure that the rights of individuals and corporations were not unduly impeded and that the legislation would be able to perform its function quite rightly and properly without going that little step too far.

The reality we must all recognise in Australia today is that crime strikes at the very heart of the financial structure and that organised crime can operate successfully only if it can permeate and gain the respectability of normal commercial financial institutions. That has been done, and it is still being done. We know from the history of the Mafia in the United States of America and from the research and the investigations that have been carried out there that organised crime operates first at the lower levels in the purely criminal activities of prostitution, narcotics, the numbers game and SP bookmaking, where it firstly gains its cash proceeds. Organised crime operates in cash notes, which are readily transferable. A criminal organisation, having got its cash, then finds it necessary to move that cash from the back streets-from the brothels, the street walkers and the narcotics dealers-into the respectability of normal commercial institutions. Of course, that has been done in many ways. Those who are interested in the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union would be very interested to learn how Mr Costigan discovered organised crime does this.

One of the ways in which it is done is through casinos, where one can quite properly change cash into betting chips. That might be done by one person transferring chips to another person and then recashing them for a cheque. There is nothing illegal in that at all, but it does turn cash into a commercial cheque. It can also be done through the Totalisator Agency Board, and Mr Costigan clearly outlined how that can occur. A person can open a phone betting account and transfer into that account a large amount of cash, running a series of transactions but ultimately drawing from the credit account cash in the form of a commercial cheque from the TAB. The cheque then goes into a banking institution. It has been laundered, and quite legally.

TALK.START.PARA: —And backing horses you know are going to be scratched.

—Yes, and we have the bookmakers. We were told that on one day at a Sydney meeting many millions of dollars were transferred into the bag of one bookmaker and back out again. It is very difficult for governments to control that cash movement. I suppose there are limits to the way in which governments should impede the normal activities of bookmakers and gambling activities generally. Whatever method may be used to make that dirty money-if one can call it that-clean money, the reality is that those proceeds, once laundered, are put back into normal commercial investments. They may be used to buy shares; they may be invested in normal financial institutions in long term bonds or interest bearing deposits; they may be used to buy real estate. Whatever may be the case, they are transferred from cash at the bottom level to a normal and quite respectable commercial transaction. Of course, in the past it has been very difficult to trace the movement of that money from its original cash source through the laundering process into the financial institutions. Much of the work that is needed to achieve this purpose will be done by the cash transactions legislation, which will be a very important part of a group of Bills that will be debated in the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Proceeds of Crime Bill deals with cases in which a criminal is apprehended and evidence is obtained that large sums of money from illegal means have been laundered and put back into quite respectable and normal commercial structures. It will enable orders to be made so that those proceeds can be taken off the criminal, the criminal's family and those who have benefited from the movement of the illegal cash funds. The proceeds will be put back into the Commonwealth purse. On many occasions it will be possible, no doubt, for those who have been aggrieved by the criminal activities to make a claim against those funds.

This measure is long overdue. We should all remember that when this Government came to office in 1983 the taxation system was one of great rorts and frauds. The previous Government, to its eternal shame, had not tried to do a thing to stop that tax fraud and other frauds. (Quorum formed) It is of interest to note that when one attacks members of the Opposition and shows what a disaster they were, they call quorums. Of course, if we look around the chamber, we see that there are no members of the Opposition present, except for one gentleman sitting on the front bench and one who I think is a National Party member. The others are probably in the corridor looking for their tax policy which they have not yet found.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good point. They are looking for their tax policy.

—They are certainly looking for some sort of policy because they have not yet found one. The reality is that the previous Government did nothing about public fraud or criminal fraud. The previous Government, to its eternal shame, did not attempt to do anything. The Hawke Government has tackled the tax fraud which occurred in this country prior to its term of office. It is the Hawke Government which is tackling criminal fraud. It is the Hawke Government which is taking on the serious crime elements in this country. It is the Hawke Government which is concerned about the effect of crime on families. We hear a lot about families from some honourable members opposite, but they never produce any legislation to assist families. The Hawke Government is concerned about families and the effect of crime on families. It is concerned to ensure that those who infiltrate our society, who would use illegal activities to raise wealth, those who would use the public purse for fraudulent purposes, will not keep the proceeds of that crime. This Government will make sure that those proceeds will be taken from them and returned to the public purse.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the House that this Bill, in dealing with fraud, includes frauds on revenue. It covers those areas which occurred during the time of the previous Government. It enables the Government to bring back to the public purse money which was gained through illegal acts against the revenue of Australia. Those funds will be recovered and placed in the public revenue, which is where they should be.

These Bills are a credit to the Attorney-General. They are a credit to the Government. I have been very proud to serve as chairman of the Caucus legal committee. I have been very proud to assist this Government in putting forward these Bills. I know that my constituents will be pleased with these Bills. In fact, all Australians will be pleased to see them. People like the late Mr Trimbole will not be able to use their ill-gotten gains and pass them back to their families. Such funds, as a result of this legislation, will be put back in the public purse, where they belong. Again, I congratulate the Attorney. He is one of the best Attorneys that this country has seen. I again say to the House that he deserves the name of the Eliot Ness of Australian crime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party of Australia is willing and prepared to concede that the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987 and the Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987 represent a major milestone in the fight against organised crime. But we certainly stop short of the embarrassing praise heaped upon the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) by his colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland). I wonder how the Attorney-General likes being described as the Eliot Ness of Australian crime-an ambiguous piece of praise if ever I have heard it.

SPEECH.PARA: More particularly, as the Attorney-General knows better than anybody, it was the Fraser Government which established the Royal Commission into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, better known as the Costigan Royal Commission, from which much of the disclosure, uncovering and revealing of organised crime occurred, leading to the point where this Parliament is in the middle of considering four pieces of very important legislation. The first pieces were passed by the Parliament a fortnight ago. I refer to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill 1987 and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987. They will allow for co-operative arrangements between Australia and other countries which will better deal with the international aspects of organised crime.

We have before us also the Proceeds of Crime Bill, which I will address my remarks to in a few moments. I understand that next week we are to discuss the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987 as well as the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1987. I put the Government on notice that there a number of aspects about those two pieces of legislation which cause the National Party grave concern; so much so that at this stage we are considering moving amendments certainly to the cash transaction legislation and possibly to the telecommunications interception legislation, if we cannot be satisfied on those aspects. But that debate will occur at a later time.

I do not want to canvass matters that may well come before the courts, but I believe that this Attorney-General and this Government have treated Mr Costigan shamefully. Leaving aside the tremendous suspicions that members of the public and certainly members on this side of the House have about the premature and unnecessary winding up of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union back in December 1984, there has been the disgraceful slamming by the Attorney-General of Mr Costigan in a recent Press release, in which he none too subtly suggested that Mr Costigan was responsible for the leaking of information from that Royal Commission, which was to embarrass the person with the code name Goanna, later revealed to be Mr Kerry Packer. But I am unable to canvass it because it may well result in litigation. Both the Attorney-General and this Government have washed their hands entirely of Mr Costigan. They have not only ended his Royal Commission unnecessarily but also proceeded in a scurrilous attack on his integrity and character. If the Attorney-General, in his reply, wishes to place on record this Government's gratitude to and admiration for Mr Costigan, we would certainly welcome that.

I do not for a moment accept that this is the first truly crime busting Attorney-General that we have ever had. I have immense respect for his administration of his Department in so many different ways, and the legislation immediately before the House, the Proceeds of Crime Bill, is something in which he and the officers of his Department can take great pride. It is long overdue. It is part of the continuing attempt by this Parliament to equip our law enforcement agencies with the necessary powers to combat the evils of organised crime. The Proceeds of Crime Bill will empower the courts to order the confiscation or forfeiture of properties acquired by criminals, thereby giving effect to that long held belief that criminals should not enjoy the fruits of their criminal activities and should not have some nest egg put away for them from which they can draw to fight the processes of law or to enjoy on finishing a period of incarceration.

A whole number of royal commissions have advocated the type of forfeiture and confiscation powers contained in this legislation. One major contributor to the final bringing before the Parliament of this legislation was undoubtedly Mr Justice Donald Stewart in his report in 1983 of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, better known as the Mr Asia inquiry. That Royal Commission examined the activities of the Clark syndicate in Australia and, amongst other things, the use of institutions to disguise the flow of funds associated with the drug operations of that syndicate. That report, better than many, illustrated the complexities involved in tracing funds and the use of companies and financial institutions to disguise the flow of funds which, more or less, made it impossible, with the powers then existing and then available to law enforcement agencies, actually to follow the money trail.

This is complex legislation. It is a credit to all involved in its drafting, but I very much suspect that we will have to move amendments to it at a later time. We are breaking new ground in so many different ways with this legislation. It is no criticism of the draftsman, it is simply that I can imagine that at one point or another some of the provisions will not prove as effective as we would want them to be. I hope that is not the case. If it is, I have no doubt that the Attorney will seek amendments to the legislation without any delay.

Not only will this legislation empower courts to order the confiscation or forfeiture of properties, but also it will empower them to restrain a suspect from disposing of property. That is very important because too often criminals are able to arrange their affairs in the expectation of facing court action or conviction, and thereby appear to all intents and purposes to have no assets. Moreover, under this legislation a court may impose pecuniary penalties in line with the profits gained by criminals. The money or assets will go to a fund to fight organised crime.

In summary, the Proceeds of Crime Bill has five purposes. As I say, its principal purpose is to empower a court to grant orders for the freezing and confiscation of property used in or derived directly or indirectly from the commission of an indictable offence against the law of the Commonwealth, or naturally, of a Territory, other than the Northern Territory, I hasten to add. Furthermore, the Bill confers on the police new powers to facilitate the following of the money trail and to require financial institutions to preserve their records so as to maintain a record of that money trail. Moreover, it creates new offences of money laundering and organised fraud.

Turning now specifically to some of the provisions, I should say by way of introduction that in 1985-86 federal agencies seized 62.3 kilograms of heroin and 12.2 kilograms of cocaine. At best, we can only guess that law enforcement agencies seize between five and 10 per cent of all imported drugs. Supposing we allow for ten per cent, we can therefore calculate that if we seize 62 kilograms of heroin, 620 kilograms of heroin entered this country, and that if we seized 12 kilograms of cocaine, 120 kilograms of cocaine entered Australia during the year 1985-86. That gives us some idea of the enormity of the drug trafficking problem that we have in this country. Moreover, it gives us some idea of the extent of the value of the evil of drugs. It is estimated that heroin has a street value of $700,000 for every kilogram, and that cocaine has a street value of $300,000 for every kilogram. So again estimating-and that is all we can do as we cannot be any more definite-that 620 kilograms of heroin and 120 kilograms of cocaine enter Australia, at those street values they are worth something like half a billion dollars-$500m. That, of course, is not taking into account other illegal drugs. There is obviously an enormous pool of finances from which increasingly sophisticated and more organised criminals can draw to frustrate the legal processes of this country.

This legislation attempts to cover most of the different aspects of the money trail as well as to deprive criminals of their ill-gotten gains. For instance, the Director of Public Prosecutions will be able to apply, in respect of a person convicted of an indictable offence, for an order that tainted property in respect of the offence be forfeited and that a pecuniary penalty be imposed in respect of the benefits derived from the offence. I should say at this stage that a number of States have passed corresponding legislation, not in the same form, naturally. New South Wales, perhaps surprisingly, was the first State to enact such legislation in 1985. South Australia soon followed and the Victorian Act was passed in 1986.

Clause 17 interested me because it deals with a confiscation order where a person is believed to have absconded. Under that clause, orders are not to be made unless the court is satisfied, on the balance of probabilities-that is the test-that the person has absconded and, firstly, that the person has been committed for trial or, secondly, that a reasonable jury could find the person guilty. Where the Director of Public Prosecutions has made such an application, the court may order that the property be forfeited to the Commonwealth. In considering whether to make such an order, the court may consider any hardship that may arise if the order is made, and the ordinary use of such property. We should not lose sight of the fact that if the conviction is quashed the forfeiture order is discharged. That is provided for in clause 22. There are a number of other specific aspects of this legislation with which I could deal, but I very much fear that my time is limited, so in conclusion I will seize upon one or two aspects of the legislation which do not deal with forfeiture and confiscation of property. Let me deal with the new offences of money laundering and organised fraud.

Much of the legislation deals with information gathering powers. Under clause 66 police may apply for a production order to gain property tracking documents. It will be an offence to fail to comply with such an order. There are also clauses which deal with monitoring orders. Under these clauses the police may apply for an order which will direct a financial institution to give information to a law enforcement agency on transactions by a particular person. Such orders are not to be made unless the judge is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the person has committed, or is about to commit, a serious offence.

I turn now to those clauses which deal with money laundering. These clauses deal with cases where a person directly or indirectly engages in a transaction that involves the proceeds of crime, or who possesses, receives, disposes of or brings into Australia the proceeds of crime, and the person knows or ought to reasonably know that the property was derived from unlawful activity. Organised fraud is taken to have occurred when a person engages in acts or omissions that constitute three or more public fraud offences and the person derives substantial benefit.

The Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, which is being debated cognately with the Proceeds of Crime Bill, makes consequential amendments to pieces of legislation that are affected in a very material way by the Proceeds of Crime Bill. In summary, the legislation is supported by the National Party. We congratulate the Attorney-General and his Department on the, I would think, countless days of work that have gone into drafting this complex and, I believe, urgently needed legislation. I am sure that almost all of its provisions will be successful. They have to be successful, given the size of the task of fighting organised crime. I look forward to reassurances by the Attorney-General that Mr Costigan was a valued and highly respected royal commissioner and that a Press release some weeks ago-causing many people within the legal fraternity uneasiness and some of them outright rage-was not intended to slur that man's character.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to support the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987 and the Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987 which the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has brought before the House. The major legislation with which we are dealing is the Proceeds of Crime Bill. As the Attorney-General has put it, it provides some of the most effective weaponry against major crime that has ever been introduced into this Parliament. Its purpose will be to strike at the very heart of organised crime in Australia by depriving those people engaged in crime of their profits and the instruments of their crime. That is a commendable objective. In doing that we will be suppressing criminal activity by attacking the primary motive, which is always profit, and preventing the reinvestment of that profit in further criminal activity. I do not think that we could ask for legislation to come before this House on a better basis.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that all honourable members share a common objective-the need to fight organised crime. Some honourable members of course, have taken a partisan attitude to this objective, and I may return to that theme in a moment. The Age newspaper earlier this month commended this legislation when in an editorial headed `Making crime no longer pay' it said:

The control of organised crime in a democratic community calls for effective measures beyond the normal bounds of criminal justice. First, it requires techniques of investigation that are not usually available or entrusted to conventional police forces. And second, it warrants penalties that take both the motive and the profit out of organised criminal activity. The two approaches are complementary. The threat of tough penalties is no deterrent if criminal conspirators can be fairly confident that they will not be caught or convicted. And effective detection alone will not protect society if the guilty can avoid just retribution or keep their ill-gotten gains.

This legislation is described in a number of similar newspaper editorials as important and indeed crucial to the fight against organised crime. An earlier speaker mentioned that this legislation was part of a package of Bills which the Government has introduced to this Parliament. One of those Bills is the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill which passed through this Parliament earlier this month. That Bill provides for improved arrangements and co-ordination between Australia and overseas government agencies so that we are better able to deal with the problem of organised crime that occurs on a national and an international level. That legislation has already gone through this House.

The Proceeds of Crime Bill, as I have said, is a major weapon-probably the most effective weapon ever introduced-against organised crime. We are debating this Bill at the moment, and next week, the last week of sitting of the Thirty-fourth Parliament, we will hear debate in this House on two other fundamental reforms in the area of criminal law reform and organised crime-the cash transactions legislation and the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. These Bills and earlier measures taken by the Government represents a major attack on organised crime in Australia. I think all Australians would share the aspirations that this Government has in making an all-out attack on organised crime. In looking at the fight against organised crime we can go back some years. It is worthy of note that the reports of Stewart, McCabe-Lafranchi, Moffitt, Woodward and Costigan, delivered in the 1970s and the 1980s, have all showed that crime is not simply a matter of small isolated pockets removed from the mainstream of society.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Martin report?

—I have just been reminded by my colleague of the Martin report, the report of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception. That report has also contributed to the fight against organised crime in Australia. This Government has identified several areas of priority for the attack by the Australian Federal Police upon organised crime. The most important priority is drug trafficking. As part of the Government's commitments which we gave priority to the 1984 election, Australian Federal Police numbers have been increased very substantially. We have set more than $10m aside for that purpose. We have also provided more than $7m for the Australian Federal Police to upgrade its computer capacity. So it simply cannot be said by any speakers in this debate that this Government has not put its money where its mouth is or that it has not matched its rhetoric with resources, because in every sense it has, and it is determined to fight organised crime.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the extra resources that it has given the Australian Federal Police, the Government has also established the National Crime Authority which I think in a very good way has carried on the work of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. To date the National Crime Authority has been very successful in charging a number of people with very serious criminal offences. As a member of the Joint Committtee on the National Crime Authority, I know that the NCA is often reluctant for good reason to publicise its achievements. I can say that its achievements to date have been considerable and significant and they are part of a wide-based attack by this Government on organised crime in Australia.

As I said, next week we will be debating legislation for telecommunication interception. That legislation will also assist in the fight against organised crime. The legislation we are debating at the moment also forms part of that package and enables the Federal Government to confiscate the ill-gotten gains of convicted criminals. Other things that we have done in our fight against organised crime include legislation which has passed through this Parliament to establish an independent Australian Customs Service with its own Comptroller-General to provide an appropriate focus for the management of that Service, and we have also approved additional resources for the Service so that it is better able to intercept illicit drugs entering Australia. We have established the Director of Public Prosecutions, streamlining the Government's prosecution system to overcome the deficiencies in the earlier arrangements noted by the Costigan Commission in its fourth interim report.

I guess the final thing amongst a range of measures that I have described that this Government has introduced to fight organised crime is the further tightening of measures in legislation to limit, to prohibit and to make illegal blatant tax evasion in this country. I do not think honourable members in this House should forget too soon that it was this Government when it came to office which found that there had been blatant tax evasion and avoidance eroding the tax system through the 1970s, haemorrhaging the tax system so that it was ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers who were paying for the profits of organised criminals in relation to tax evasion. Those people who follow the newspaper reports would know that this Government has been thorough in its efforts to track down those who have unscrupulously evaded their rightful and legal responsibility to pay tax. They are some of this Government's commendable and very solid achievements.

Earlier in the debate the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) suggested that this Government had in some way sleighted or not adequately reflected on the work of Mr Costigan and the Costigan Royal Commission. I think I can answer that criticism fairly simply be referring to a Government statement in the Senate on 21 May 1985, as follows:

Two words probably best sum up the public's view of the Costigan Royal Commission's work-`organised crime'. The Opposition has repeatedly tried to accuse this Government of a lack of commitment in fighting organised crime. Nothing could be further from the truth: We ensured the Costigan Commission had appropriate resources-
and I ask the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and other Opposition members to note this-
out of a total cost of more than $14m over five years, this Government-
the Hawke Government-
provided $8m in only two years.
So it can hardly be said that we did not provide adequate support in that area. The statement continues:

In particular, we increased the Commission's budget from just under $3m in 1982-83 to just under $6m in 1983-84; we have established the National Crime Authority to lead the fight against organised crime; we have established the Director of Public Prosecutions to streamline the prosecutions area and overcome earlier problems; and we have substantially increased resources available to the Australian Federal Police . . .

The statement then goes on to list a whole range of other measures which I have already described. So in no way at all can it be suggested that this Government has in any way lacked the commitment or resources to fight organised crime in Australia. Indeed, we have matched our rhetoric with action, and we have put money where our mouth is. We have enabled law enforcement agencies in Australia to get on with the job of tracking down organised criminals.

The legislation before the House is good legislation and it is historic legislation which will permit a number of actions to be taken against organised crime, and I will describe some of them. It will permit, after conviction, the forfeiture of property used in, or obtained as a result of, the commission of an indictable offence against the law of the Commonwealth. It will require for more serious offences the statutory forfeiture of an offender's assets six months after conviction. It will permit, prior to conviction, the tracing and freezing of property that may be subject to forfeiture. It will create new offences for `money laundering', which is the process by which profits of crime are disguised in order to make them appear legitimate. The legislation will also require the keeping of certain financial records by financial institutions and will permit, subject to certain safeguards, access to those records. It will provide for the proper identification of all persons and corporations opening bank accounts. For those States which have enacted proceeds of crime legislation, it will provide for discretionary, court ordered forfeiture for any indictable offence; and the Commonwealth legislation will do the same. So it is very powerful legislation, but I think it is justified because Australians in this Parliament and of all political persuasions are united in wanting to strike at the very heart of organised crime in Australia.

We should not forget that at the basis of the vast majority of organised crime is the profit motive, the intention and desire in an organised way to make excessive and considerable levels of profit which are put towards personal gain at the expense of other people. Of course the most common way in which organised crime flourishes in countries around the world and in Australia is through drug trafficking, and those gains are ill-gotten. They are made at the expense-not just financial but also emotional, personal, and physical-of those from whom the gains are made. We are all united in wanting to strike at the very heart of organised crime in Australia. I repeat: It is the profit motive which generates the basis or motive for organised crime. It is those who take part in organised crime who often wish to launder money from their profits and put it back through what seem to be legitimate businesses to make those profits and their way of life appear to be legitimate.

This legislation really does attack directly the basis of organised crime because it gives Australian law-makers the ability, the capacity, the right and the law to attack the ill-gotten proceeds or organised crime. I reiterate: This Bill is one of a number of Bills that we have put before the House to attack organised crime. We have already passed the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill and the Cash Transaction Reports Bill, and the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill will be debated in this House next week. Improved resources for the Australian Federal Police, the establishment of the National Crime Authority to take over from the work of the Costigan Royal Commission, the establishment of the Director of Public Prosecutions, and the revamping of the Australian Customs Service all indicate that this Government has made the fight against organised crime a top priority in its policies. I have pleasure in supporting this legislation and I am pleased that it has the bipartisan support of all parties in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation is one of the most pungent pieces of innovative action against major crime to come before this Parliament. The legislation makes it possible for people engaged in lucrative illegal activities to be deprived of their ill-gotten gains. It is just not enough that people be imprisoned for their wrong doing. It is also important that those who have acquired assets through their dishonest practices should be deprived of the benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: The origins of the legislation are to be found in the work of the Costigan Royal Commission. We all know that Mr Costigan was appointed to investigate the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. He found that it had become a notorious centre for criminal activities with all the bully-boy incidents that go with crime. We talk about big crime to distinguish the sophistication of big money-buying favours to ensure big returns which are then squirreled away into personal wealth. As we know, all crime has a very nasty side to it. We know that the Mafia has been the centre of social devices for corrupting public officials, judges and the like in the United States of America and that this has involved the use of standover men, drug traffickers and all the nasty, indeed brutish, bases of an integrated criminal business.

When the Fraser Government initiated the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, there were the obvious trappings of petty crime, thuggery and murder. What the Commission found, as it followed what the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) referred to as the money trail, was a vast enterprise of tax evasion and fraud-some petty, some very significant. In other words, the culture of the trade union being investigated was a culture of crime, thuggery, bribery, drug trafficking and the forging and uttering of official documents.

One docker prepared 40 fraudulent returns to the Australian Taxation Office. The same man used seven false names to defraud the Department of Social Security of $64,000. An illegal scheme concerning 220 Commonwealth officers for fraudulently promoting mineral exploration had involved four chartered accountants and one financier. A merchant bank had raised a scheme to evade tax by allegedly trading in commodity futures, with false names and multiple bank accounts. The plan was to launder large sums of money. In separate actions in one bank, a Melbourne bank manager was dismissed for his part in dealings with a corporate criminal. This is the sort of thing turned up by Commissioner Costigan when he investigated, by following the money trail, the painters and dockers union. What is alarming is that the trade union base enables all kinds of action to be devised which have nothing to do with the legitimate role of the trade unions-the interest of the worker or trade unionist.

In the United States, the unions have proved a successful base for organised crime. The Mafia used the truckers union to install Jimmy Hoffa, and that union was used to coerce the whole economic system dependent on trucking to pay protection fees and the like. Clearly, Commissioner Costigan has had concerns that the Mafia was developing a pattern of influence here in the painters and dockers union. Who would have believed that the centre for Mafia drug activities in Australia would be the small town of Griffith in New South Wales? The murder of the anti-drug campaigner Donald Mackay, covered up by clearly corrupt police action for so long, has led to the exposure of Trimbole, a major drug trafficker. He so corrupted our passport issuing system that a whole new, complex and expensive procedure for the issuing of passports has had to be evolved. It now costs the citizen $60 for his passport.

For a time there was great confusion in the Government as to what should be done about the need for the Commonwealth and State law enforcement authorities to work together to complete the investigations started by the Costigan inquiry. Two things happened. The Fraser Government's proposal for a crime commission to take over from Costigan was dumped by the Hawke Government when it came to power in 1983. After much umming and ahing, and pressure mounted by the Press and the Opposition, the Government set up a National Crime Authority under Mr Justice Stewart.

The second proposal was to set up a permanent arrangement for a public prosecutor to work closely with the Authority to ensure effective court action to deal with criminal activity. An office of Director of Public Prosecutions was established in 1983 which brought to active life the idea that ways should be found to pursue civil remedy, as distinct from criminal prosecution, to frustrate the criminal's money-making activities. One process has been to take court action to recover money not declared as income. Mr Temby, in his first report, says:
Effectively rendering a criminal enterprise profitless creates a disincentive for like-minded persons to engage in similar activity in the future.

The Proceeds of Crime Bill is a development of the thinking to emerge from the Costigan Royal Commission and from the Director of Public Prosecutions. As the Attorney-General says, its purpose is to strike at the heart of major organised crime by depriving involved persons of the profits of those crimes. The profit motive is the central motive of highly organised crime. People involved want to make big profits, and to become respected and influential citizens in the process. So the profit motive is to be attacked, just as Commissioner Costigan proposed.

The New South Wales police have had a dreadful record of having people in high places co-operate with those involved in making huge profits from crime. Efforts are being made to clean things up in the force. It is clear that the ordinary police prosecutor's powers would not be adequate to inhibit this kind of crime, or even to investigate it. The National Crime Authority, on the other hand, is able to co-ordinate police and special inquiries to ensure a more efficient process of detection. Now the question is: Having detected the activities, how do we kill it, and recover money and profit from those activities? The Bill confers new powers to follow the money trail; it requires responsible financial institutions to make proper records, and it can freeze and confiscate overseas accounts. It is an important obligation for financial institutions. Banks must retain cheques and payment orders above $200. Such a mechanism is needed to facilitate investigations. Such a procedure makes it very difficult to cover the trail of illegality.

Most importantly, these legislative provisions look behind the facade of legal ownership of property to determine, as the Minister says, whether that property is subject to the effective control of the defendant, having regard to such things as shareholdings or directorships of companies. The legislation comprehends family and business relationships with the property. The legislation proceeds on the theme flowing from Costigan that the ill-gotten gains should be the objective of action. Orders against a defendant may require the court to assess the benefit derived from the offence. So we can see that there will be an incentive for big criminal practitioners to get out of formerly lucrative practices. But we must expect that this action, so necessary and so important, will create a search for new rorts and new dodges. Thus we should not be surprised by, but should welcome, any further amendments to legislation which make it increasingly difficult to cheat the system. As the legislation is put into effect, obviously there may be a need for further amendments. We would look to those amendments to come forward on the basis of their necessity.

One of the important aims of this legislation is to make it difficult to launder money. We know that the Mafia in the United States ends up with raw money. All of its activities involve the use of ordinary dollar bills, which it acquires through street-level crimes. It has set up special offices outside the United States to traffic in dollar bills, unload them in countries such as Australia, and return the money in investable form back to the United States. The most attractive places for money-laundering are the racecourses and the casinos. There the money trail is lost. It is all too easy to pay bribes and favours through this process. Thus the laundering of money involves the corruption of many of the ordinary activities of Australia. There is some doubt whether it is possible to run casinos which do not become penetrated by money-laundering arrangements. The process of following cheques, and how they are paid for, clearly is going to facilitate investigation of laundering activities. It is no good returning to the United States the raw money brought in. I welcome the kind of action designed to provide a framework and focus for investigators. The measures should make investigation easier, more certain and, hopefully, more effective.

Since the Costigan Royal Commission, Australia has been faced with the question: Can Australian law enforcement get on top of organised crime, or will organised crime so penetrate every department of Australian life-the social security system, the health care system, the financial system and the recreational system-that there will be found to be no capability for Australian law enforcement agencies to win through? Those who watched the Australian Broadcasting Corporation screening of the television series on the Mafia saw how terribly destructive big crime is when it permeates the social system. We saw in that series the destruction of a trade union, and even the destruction of a city. The city of Newark, New Jersey, has been destroyed by the Mafia, which corrupts and takes, but never builds. Big crime is terribly destructive; it is economically and socially disastrous.

According to Commissioner Costigan, we have come very close to big crime taking over here. Those who saw the interview given to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation by Mr Justice Stewart will know how public dedication is needed to defeat organised crime. It gave us all an insight into the pressure on our law enforcement institutions and people involved.

I do not wish to be unduly partisan in areas where the national interest demands that Australia is better served by strong and effective legislation. It is true that the Opposition, quite properly, became very vigorous about some of the earlier proposals to have a less effective National Crime Authority. There was no point in allowing weaknesses in the legislation, and the Opposition welcomed the proposal from the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs to provide that the Authority receive relevant information from the Commissioner of Taxation. We were concerned also to ensure that the Authority have effective access to overseas interactions.

As I said, the fact is that big crime lives off international connections. I welcome the recognition in this legislation of the internationalism of organised crime. I support the Minister in this respect when he says that the international measures to freeze and confiscate Australian assets accumulated through international crime activity are vital in the fight against the internationalisation of major crime. This legislation demonstrates the fact that there are rewards to our society for facing up to the dangers of organised crime with its international connections.

The Royal Commissioner, Mr Costigan, stirred up a hornets nest when he persisted with his inquiries, despite much misrepresentation and controversy. With the retrospect of history, his work, and the work of Mr Justice Stewart as a Commissioner, and now as Chairman of the Crime Authority, has given Australia an insight into the dangers, but more than that, as this legislation shows, it has stimulated a public will to see that these matters are adequately dealt with.

Can we hope that the tide against overseas and organised crime in Australia is now turning?
