Does the quietness with which this legislation has been received indicate that the people of Australia are not prepared to be fooled, that out there the Costigan reports and the work of Mr Justice Stewart are winning the minds of members of the public? I, with most Australians, have been greatly exercised in a concern about the existence and blatant bravado of the rogues who can so manipulate our institutions and our society. We know that those efforts, which are bringing success, should not be relaxed for a moment. It is important that there is not only legal provision for an effective attack on crime, but also it is important-indeed, of the utmost urgency-that the material and personnel support systems for the attack on crime be forthcoming, notwithstanding these stringent times. These, of course, are not measures to court popularity, but they are of the kind so gravely needed and justified by all who have come to fear the destructive malignancy of organised crime. I support the legislation.

Before finishing, I raise a couple of matters which have exercised my mind, because this legislation and other legislation have serious implications for the Australian legal and accountancy professions and for corporate executives, some of whom have become deeply implicated in the laundering of money from organised crime. In relation to the legal profession, evidence was given to the National Crime Authority that crime money was being laundered through a trust account of a Melbourne legal firm. In relation to accountants, businessmen and entrepreneurs, the same evidence was given to the National Crime Authority which showed laundered money was networked through a chain involving an accountant, a businessman, a former bank manager and a Melbourne entrepreneur. I refer also to banks, financial institutions and computer hackers.

It is about time that professions throughout Australia-and I refer to all professions-really looked very much to their laurels in terms of their own control over their standards and ethics. If the professional bodies do not move to strengthen further the codes, the morality and the proper ethics which should characterise their professions, then the individual members of those professions cannot complain if successive governments introduce legislation which, in their view, may have the effect of introducing further regulations and further difficulties for them.

It is up to the professions to a much greater extent than they have previously demonstrated to build, not only amongst their own members but also amongst the public as a whole, a greater regard for the sort of business and professional morality that we have come to expect and should expect from these professions which, in the main, have a highly honoured history and background. In the main, people involved in the professions have a greater access to support and to financial reward from the community. In return for that I believe that the professions must do far more than they exhibit to build their own standards of professional morality and ethnics. If they do not do that, then they cannot complain when governments, either at the State or at the Federal level, act to do it for them.
Sitting suspended from 6.25 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker-(Quorum formed). There has been general recognition of the fact that this legislation, the Proceeds of Crime Bill and the Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill that the Parliament is in the process of considering, is extremely important. The very fact that it is the Labor Government which has introduced it probably explains why the Melbourne Herald today has as its banner headline `Labor has a 10% lead'.
—That is conservative, Robert.

—It is suggested by the honourable member for Fowler that that figure is conservative. Almost certainly that figure is conservative. And why should it not be, when this Government has such an outstanding legislative record? If we need any further evidence of the quality of that record we need only to look at the legislation that we are in the process of considering, the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: This Commonwealth has existed for 87 years and for the first time ever a government has had sufficient concern about the fact that organised crime has enabled people to rip off the national community hundreds of millions of dollars and given those people the opportunity to launder those funds and frequently reinvest them into legitimate purposes and thus become the pillars of society. Many of those people out in the community, who vote for the Opposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —They fund them.

—I appreciate that interjection; they certainly fund the Opposition. Under the previous Government, overwhelming and conclusive evidence came before the Parliament and before the Australian community that, as a result of tax evasion and tax avoidance, Commonwealth revenue was diminished to the extent of $7,000m every year. That is only in the area of tax evasion and tax avoidance.

SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned in this legislation about the whole area of organised crime. The Proceeds of Crime Bill is probably one of the most complex and far reaching pieces of legislation to come before the Parliament. It runs into 87 pages and has 104 clauses. It sets out a complex and sophisticated system for the confiscation of property derived from or used in crime, for the monitoring of criminal activities and for the taking of remedies to safeguard the interests that the Commonwealth has in the proceeds of crime. In the second reading speech, the Attorney-General, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), said:

The Proceeds of Crime Bill provides some of the most effective weaponry against major crime ever introduced into this Parliament. Its purpose is to strike at the heart of major organised crime by depriving persons involved of the profits and instruments of their crimes. By so doing, it will suppress criminal activity by attacking the primary motive-profit-and prevent the re-investment of that profit in further criminal activity.

Of course, the significance of that, as the Attorney-General quite clearly indicated, is that the legislation is designed to strike at the very heart of organised crime in Australia. After 87 years of this Commonwealth, this legislation will ensure finally that those people who have been able to benefit from a whole range of criminal activities which unfortunately exist within our society, will no longer be able to retain the benefits of that crime. So many of them have for so long been able to do that. The fact that this has been a matter of concern within the community is indicated by a letter that I sent to the Attorney-General in February of 1985 as a result of approaches that had been made to me. At that time there was concern about Mr Terrence Clark, Mr Asia, and the fact that substantial wealth would be inherited by his son in Sydney as a result of the particular types of criminal activity in which he had been involved. At that time the Attorney-General replied saying that the Customs Act provided for the confiscation of profits derived from illegal drug trafficking. He went on to say:

I believe that a person convicted of an offence should not be able to retain any benefits derived as a result of the commission of the offence . . . Commonwealth legislation provides for the confiscation of profits derived from trafficking in narcotic drugs illegally imported into, or exported out of, Australia.
He went on to say that that was covered by the Customs Act 1901 and stated:

Section 229a deems any `money' or `goods' that are in the possession or under the control of a person by reason of his dealings in illegal drugs to be forfeited goods. A police officer or any other authorised person may, . . . seize `money' or `goods' that are forfeited by virtue of the above provision. Section 243b provides for the imposition of a pecuniary penalty, that penalty representing the gross benefit a person has derived from dealing in illegal drugs.

So there have been provisions in legislation in the past for confiscation of some of those benefits which otherwise would have accrued to, and stayed with, people involved in various types of criminal activity.

One of the encouraging aspects of this legislation is, first of all, the extent to which Commonwealth-State co-operation is involved. The Bill provides a mechanism to enforce orders made under corresponding State laws which affect the freezing and confiscation of property located in a Territory. There is also a very desirable aspect of co-operation with foreign countries. The Bill also enables Australian freezing and confiscation orders to be enforced overseas and orders made in foreign countries in relation to foreign offences to be enforced against assets located in Australia. So there are very significant innovations as far as this legislation is concerned in dealing with these particular types of problems.

We need to keep in mind that, in addition to the $7,000m a year, to which I made reference before, as a result of taxation evasion and taxation avoidance, all these other areas of crime in Australia have made it possible for people to amass vast sums of money. Of course, it is not only in Australia. Recent evidence in Italy indicates that in the first two years of Italy implementing its anti-Mafia legislation, illegally accumulated fortunes to the tune of $US500m-a very significant sum-were confiscated; and half of that amount was seized in just two operations. So there is plenty of evidence of the extent to which these types of crimes have made it possible for people to amass vast sums of money. Even the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union in Australia showed the extent to which some of these funds were reinvested back into legitimate business activities. The Costigan Royal Commission cited one principal involved in those types of criminal activities that Mr Costigan was investigating as having beneficial interests in at least 38 legitimate companies. This was thought to be one of the less significant of those which had been identified. Examples can be multiplied time and again. Even in the area of corporate fraud a recent scheme involved a network of companies spanning six countries and allowed a businessman with addresses in the United Kingdom, Spain and Belgium to milk $13m from one Australian company. Graeme Cantwell, head of the National Companies and Securities Commission compliance and enforcement branch, said:
The object of the exercise was to take 90 per cent of the profits while having 15 per cent (of) the company. When you put it on a chart it went all over the place.

That has been one of the common approaches of people engaged in schemes of this kind. We found the same thing with all the artificial paper devices that were used in order to allow people to avoid taxation-all of the interconnections, all of the relationships, all of the links and the transfers of funds from one place to another. That particular share package was traced first to a Belgian company, then through companies in the Channel Islands in the United Kingdom, the Cayman Islands, Netherlands, Antilles, Panama, a medical trust with properties in the United Kingdom, Spain and Belgium, across to a string of Hong Kong companies and also to a company in New Zealand. These are the types of people who, as a result of their behaviour, their actions and their criminal schemes, have made it possible, in effect, to rip off the whole community. That particular businessman had only 15 per cent of shares in the Australian company over which he had effective control and he was able to arrange for it to buy $1 shares from the New Zealand company he owned at the inflated price of $6. So all of these schemes have various forms of devices that make it possible to pursue them.

I understand that a study for the Special Minister of State's office last year estimated that fraud was costing the Federal Government about $4 billion a year, especially in Customs and income tax evasion. I gave the $7 billion figure before because that was combining income tax evasion with income tax avoidance which occurred under the previous Government. Why has it taken 87 years for any government to do something about this? For 87 years of this Commonwealth, people have been able to engage in these activities, amass these sums of money, launder them through gambling arrangements of various kinds and then suddenly appear as legitimate businessmen, as Costigan found, with legitimate business interests-pillars of society. I would not suggest for a moment that the Liberal and National parties were showing as much concern for these blatant crooks as they appeared to show for the tax evaders and the tax avoiders. But the question remains: Why has it taken this Commonwealth 87 years to do something about it? Finally we are doing something about it. I commend the Attorney-General, the Deputy Prime Minister, not only for the initiative that he has shown in connection with this legislation, but for the initiative and the courage that he has shown in other types of legislation for which he has been responsible.

The role of the professionals too is pretty significant in the rise of corporate crime. White collar criminals are often not adept enough to construct the elaborate schemes they perpetrate on an unsuspecting public. No, indeed they are not. Those schemes are refined by the professionals, the accountants and the solicitors, the people with shingles hanging outside their offices often from the city's most expensive and most prestigious firms. It appears that these professionals have in the past been immune from prosecution; few suffered from the bottom of the harbour blitz although it is well known that Queen's Counsel opinions were a crucial aspect of marketing the schemes and that top accounting firms referred large numbers of clients into the schemes.

Where does the guilt lie? Does the guilt finally lie only with the greedy and the wealthy who are able to pay for this professional advice in order to arrange the schemes and rip off the nation, or does the guilt lie as well with those smart, educated professionals with the bright, polished shingles hanging outside their offices inviting others to come in and to take advantage of the schemes which they devised and for which they get handsome commissions? Does the guilt lie with them? Of course the guilt lies with them. There is a whole range of more sophisticated business schemes and fraudulent arrangements.

The New South Wales Attorney-General, Terry Sheahan, estimates that the mushrooming business of leveraged currency traders attracted $100m from the public and enabled some of those traders-28 at one stage-to rake off huge fees in a little over 18 months. Some companies' policy was to avoid paying out currency profits in cash. Instead, investors with paper profits were persuaded to take new contracts until they lost money, which thus went to the company. Salesmen were highly paid to do this brutal work. One operator is still advertising for salesmen who could expect to earn $100,000 a year. Why? Because the salesmen then go out to the small investors, the genuine people in the community, the vast majority of the Australian community, and encourage them to put their hard earned cash, their hard earned savings, into schemes of this kind and then they rip them off. And do they rip them off! They rip them off with a vengeance. They have been doing it for 87 years in this Commonwealth, they did it in the States before that, and they did it in the colonies before that. They are doing it all over the world. This Government is not going to tolerate it any longer. This Government is now showing the way.

The Attorney-General has introduced this legislation, which serves notice on those people in the community that, while in the past it has been possible for them by various types of criminal behaviour to amass vast sums of money, vast fortunes, and to live in absolute luxury, no longer will it be possible for them to do so in the future. This Government has served notice on them. I am absolutely delighted that the Government has shown this initiative. I am absolutely delighted that this legislation will stand to the eternal credit of the Labor Government. Everyone knows that since Federation we have occupied the treasury benches of this country for far too short a time. Had we been given the opportunity over those many years to represent the Australian people for a longer period, there would have been far fewer abuses remaining in the community and the nation because we would have ripped them out, and our legislative program shows that. We have been in government only since March 1983. The program for which this Government has been responsible will stand as a beacon for future governments, Labor or conservative. In the next election the Australian people will re-elect the Hawke Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that all members of this House would strongly support the principles of the Proceeds of Crime Bill and the purposes for which it is being enacted. However, I have to say that there are some aspects that concern the Opposition and me personally. One of the main complaints-and it is a valid complaint-is that the Hawke socialist Government, now coming towards the end of its all too long term of office, has provided a very limited period for members of this parliament to study the details of this legislation. I strongly support the amendment moved by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), in which he points out that this Bill, which contains 104 clauses, was introduced on Thursday, 30 April 1987 and called on for debate on the second reading on 11 May 1987. Quite frankly, in the last week of the Parliament we now find that there has been less than adequate time for examination and consultation by the Opposition of this important legislation. Frankly, I do not believe it is fair or proper that the Parliament should be required to deal with legislation as complex as this with such a limited time to study the implications.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put it on the line. The legislation comes about as the direct result of the resolution of the Special Premiers Conference on Drugs but, as the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) pointed out in his second reading speech-I compliment him, because he does not fall under any of the criticisms that I will make tonight-it in fact goes much further. As the Attorney-General said, the general regime of the Bill insofar as it relates to the freezing and confiscation of assets is consistent with the approved model. However, this Bill goes far beyond the regime approved by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in providing new effective powers to permit law enforcement agencies to follow the money trail, creating new offences of money laundering and organised fraud-I will deal with those offences later-providing for the statutory forfeiture of property following conviction of certain serious offences and requiring financial institutions to preserve the money trail for subsequent taxation and law enforcement purposes.

There would not be a member of this Parliament on either side who would quarrel with the principle that persons should not be permitted to profit from the commission of crime. There would not be a member of this Parliament on either side of the House who would quarrel with the proposition that the authorities should be given every power to follow the money trail so that those who have committed serious crimes shall not be able, through a process of laundering or whatever, to enjoy the proceeds of those crimes. However, there are aspects of this legislation which involve fundamental principles, and I would be failing in my duty if I did not draw them to the attention of the Parliament.

I deal first with the question of innocent third parties. I point out to the House that under clause 31 the burden of proof will lie on the third party seeking an order under clause 21 (6). Let there be no mistake about this. Clause 21 (6) provides:
If a person applies to a court for an order under this subsection in respect of the applicant's interest in property and the court is satisfied that-
therein lies the rub-the onus is on the innocent third party to satisfy the court-
(a) the applicant was not, in any way, involved in the commission of the offence, or an offence, in respect of which forfeiture of the property is sought; and
(b) if the applicant acquired the interest at the time of or after the commission of the offence-the applicant acquired the interest:
(i) for sufficient consideration; and
(ii) without knowing, and in circumstances such as not to arouse a reasonable suspicion, that the property was, at the time of the acquisition, tainted property;
the court shall make an order:

I put to this House without debating the issue, because I am aware of the time constraints, that this places a burden of proof on a third party who may not, innocent though he or she may be, be able to satisfy that burden of proof. I am not the least impressed by the legal aid provisions in relation to third parties which are found at the end of the Bill, in clause 102. I am not impressed by the fact that the burden of proof may cause a situation whereby totally innocent people will find themselves divested of property simply because they are unable effectively to prove a negative.

I turn quickly to the clauses referred to in the excellent amendment moved by the honourable member for North Sydney, the shadow Attorney-General. Let us look at clauses 76 to 80. They place very substantial obligations on financial institutions in relation to the retention of documentation and records. The cost of this is not adverted to in the Attorney's second reading speech. He believes that there will be a benefit to the Commonwealth from the legislation, and that is so, but the cost to business and to reputable financial organisations, which would wish to comply with the law and would always give the assistance that has been requested in the past in the pursuit of the proceeds of crime, could be very substantial indeed. I join with the honourable member for North Sydney who, in the second part of the amendment he has moved to the second reading, complains that the Bill imposes on financial institutions heavy obligations for the retention of records concerning financial transactions but that no statement from the Business Regulation Review Unit of the cost of such measures has been provided to the House.

I turn to the new offence of money laundering. Let me be quite blunt. I have no problem with the commission of that offence, the creation of that offence and the provision for penalty. But once again we see Commonwealth legislation with, effectively, a deeming provision. I say with great respect to the Attorney that that is not the good way, the right way, to start defining a new offence. Clause 81 (3) provides:
A person shall be taken to engage in money laundering if, and only if . . .

A person is either engaged in money laundering or he is not. A person's having engaged in money laundering should be proven to the standard of proof required by the law, and that is proof beyond reasonable doubt. I object to the use of the word `taken'. Again, I have no truck with those who are involved in the commission of crime and the laundering of the proceeds of crime, but this legislation says to the prosecution: `You don't have to prove that a person actually did it. If you can prove those sets of circumstances set out in clause 81 (3) paragraphs (a) and (b), that person shall be taken to engage in money laundering.' When we turn the page, we come to our old friend `reasonably be suspected of being the proceeds of crime'. Any lawyer in Australia will tell us that that is the sister or brother of the summary offence of being found in possession of property reasonably supposed to have been stolen. That is precisely the charge brought by the police when they cannot prove that a person actually received stolen property. I suppose that the Attorney's answer will be: `Look, the penalties are not all that high. An ordinary, natural person will be fined $5,000 or imprisoned for a period not exceeding two years or both, and a body corporate will be fined an amount not exceeding $15,000'.

I object to words such as `reasonably be suspected'. We will have all the arguments again. Is a test objective or subjective? What authorities will apply? It is not good to introduce new legislation dealing with a serious social problem. It creates a legal minefield. There have been arguments and brawls in the courts going back to the courts of the colony about what has been meant by the words `reasonably supposed'. Again, I would have preferred to see the legislation clear on this point.

In conclusion, because of the time constraints, I have made it very clear that I believe no member on either side of the House would have anything but strong support for the motives of the legislation. But we have heard a bit of hypocrisy in the last stages of this debate from honourable members opposite. I cannot conceive that they could have spoken such cant and hypocrisy. It was almost as is if they did not believe that the State of New South Wales existed and that the things that have been going on there for the last 20 years had been happening. I do not blame any member of this House. But what a paragon of virtue the Australian Labor Party has now become! One could not believe that this was the same Party which cut short the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union when Premier Cain was prepared to give it an extension of time. One could not believe that this was the same Party in respect of which there was a full inquiry about the transfer of funds from the Nugan Hand Bank to the coffers of the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party.

We should be able to debate properly in this House the unsolved crimes in New South Wales, such as the bashing of the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) and the incidents at the Boulevard Hotel on the night of 21 February 1981-the unsolved robbery involving a person occupying the Lady Nelson Suite-which involved the taking of money, including United States dollars and travellers cheques, the source of which could not be identified. I have the police report here. If honourable members want me to, I will go into detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The implications of those comments by the honourable member are quite clear. I think it is inappropriate for him to proceed in that way, as he knows. I think he should be called upon to desist from that line of comment. If he has any matter of substance that he feels is appropriate to bring before the Parliament, he knows the course to adopt. He can do it by way of substantive motion. He chooses not to. He chooses to refer to it in the cowardly way.
—This is frivolous point of order.

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. I appreciate the honourable member's intervention, but I am listening carefully to the honourable member for Denison. I suggest to the honourable member for Mayo that he keep out of it. I call the honourable member for Denison.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. I will simply deal with the facts. One of the ways in which it can be demonstrated how difficult it is to solve crime is when one deals with thefts involving, for example, the sum of $3,600 in Commonwealth bank notes-fifties, twenties and tens-and the sum of $1,000 in United States currency. That is very hard to track in Australia.
—I do not like to interrupt the honourable member, but he will not drop a name at the finish of this.

—No, I will not. How does one track a quantity of travellers cheques, bank and number unknown? These are facts from an actual case which demonstrate not only that the offenders are not apprehended, but also that the proceeds of the crime are not traced. I am keeping the Attorney out of this matter. I do not drop any names. But let us not have any more hypocrisy from the ranks of members of the Hawke socialist Government. Had they been prepared to permit Mr Costigan to continue his inquiry for another six months, who knows who might have been caught in that net and how many fish they let escape. If they had unleashed the forces of law and justice in New South Wales, the thugs and attempted murderers who nearly killed one of their colleagues, the honourable member for Sydney, might now be behind bars. If they had had a clear and honourable approach to the New South Wales Labor Party, the seedy transactions between Nugan Hand and persons acting on behalf of their Party would have been brought to public light and they would have been gaoled. It is a great pity that we have had hypocrisy from members of the Labor Party. We will have a lot more hypocrisy over the next few weeks, but on 11 July they will meet their nemesis.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by commending a great Australian who is present in the chamber tonight-one who, in his own way, has been a stalwart in the fight against crime and a stalwart of decency and law and order in the Northern Territory. On behalf of all honourable members I welcome Mr Peter Paroulakis who is our endorsed candidate for the Northern Territory and who will succeed the present member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) after the election on 11 July. I wish him all the best. For those reasons I support the legislation and the amendment which was well moved by the shadow Attorney- General, the honourable member for North Sydney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only say that I hope the Liberal Party candidate for the Northern Territory starts his political career and campaigning in these matters with a cleaner slate than the current member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham). However, I want to deal specifically with the clauses of the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987. The principle on which this legislation is based is a very good one. There is a considerable sense of sympathy in the community for the victims of crime and for the need for governments to get back from criminals the proceeds of their misadventures, either to compensate the victims or to offset the cost of investigation and trial, and to ensure that they do not benefit from their misdeeds. There is also an understandable sense of outrage when the Mr Bigs of crime continue to benefit from their ill-gotten gains after their convictions or when they skip the country.

SPEECH.PARA: I am more than happy to support the Bill. This legislation will allow the courts to freeze and confiscate property which was used in, or gained directly or indirectly through, criminal activity either in Australia or in other countries with which Australia has agreements under the mutual assistance legislation. It also confers on the police the power to follow the money trail and requires financial institutions to provide information which will enable them to do so. As well, it creates a new offence in relation to the laundering of money and organised fraud.

From my past experience as Attorney-General in the Dunstan Government in South Australia, I know only too well that if these matters are to be adequately tackled, they have to be done at the Commonwealth level. It is virtually impossible for a State government to act alone in this area, as much as any State government might like to. I even have some doubts as to how effective the Commonwealth can be in the area, since the deregulation of the financial system was almost God's gift to money launderers. Nevertheless, if the legislation which is complementary to this-and which we were to debate cognately, I understand-is able to be put into place quickly and effectively, there will be some hope in the success of the measure before us.

Of course, the success of the mutual assistance legislation will depend very much on the success of the negotiations with other governments and the intentions of those governments. It may also depend on further reforms to the national securities and exchange system and, of course, on the willingness of all the States to implement those measures.

There is little doubt that capital is becoming far more internationalised. All governments, this one included, have assisted in this process, and in doing so have made it much more difficult to trace the money trail through the laundering processes converting criminal proceeds to so-called legitimate funds. The interdependence of the international economic system has meant that nation states barely exercise any control over the distribution of wealth, especially when it is hidden in large transnational corporations. It is the diminishing control which governments themselves have in this area which has made it easier and easier for the transfer of funds, with consequent laundering and the subsequent protection of the Mr Bigs who have been involved in organised crime and fraud.

It is worth recalling just a few examples of the ease with which large scale fraud, money laundering and transfer has occurred in Australia in the recent past. Perhaps the biggest of the known frauds was that of the Bartons in New South Wales in the early 1970s. Alexander and Thomas Barton went from being small time shady businessmen to the world of big business. They were able to expatriate millions of dollars overseas and lived on the proceeds of massive frauds in the space of only a few years. Between 1969 and 1972 the Bartons raised some $25.6m through floating public companies. In 1972 they left Australia just as concern was mounting at the performance of their group, leaving $22.6m unaccounted for. After spending time travelling throughout Europe, no doubt enjoying some of the millions they had, they settled in Paraguay. The then New South Wales Liberal Government spent a considerable amount of taxpayers' funds in an unsuccessful effort to extradite them from Paraguay.

More recently we have had the case of one Colin Room, the Tasmanian accountant who managed to defraud his clients of well over $2m. Room got word that he was to be investigated and he managed to spirit both the proceeds and himself out of the country, and he is still strangely at large. There have been numerous rumours of his high living in the United States of America, Europe and South America, and while the cost of the investigations must run into a considerable amount, Room is still at large. Apparently no one knows his present whereabouts.

Now one of the more interesting things about both these cases is the apparent ease with which the persons involved moved among the establishment and big business, and the timing of their disappearances. The Bartons were linked with some of the well known members of the New South Wales business community, and with senior members of the Liberal Party, including the then Attorney-General, whose law firm acted on their behalf. Room not only moved among the establishment, but in Tasmania he was part of it. Many ordinary Tasmanians, no doubt including many of those who lost their savings as a result of his fraud, must be extremely concerned at the secrecy with which the Tasmanian Government is treating that matter.

These are only two of the more notorious cases that come to mind. In the community are thousands of ordinary Australians who have been the victims of criminal activity who are unable to receive any compensation for it, and who must accept that the justice which is meted out by the courts is all that can be done. Of course, these are the lucky ones who actually see a successful prosecution. There are many others who never see justice being done, for whom justice is never done, because the accused absconds. At least with this legislation these ordinary law abiding Australians will be able to see that crime does not pay. I hope that State governments will introduce complementary legislation which also upgrades victims of crimes provisions.

Even though I support this legislation there are a few things about it that I am in an uneasy frame of mind about. Four clauses appear to be reversing the onus of proof, and one appears to overturn the common law principle that a person may refuse to answer self-incriminatory questions. As a civil libertarian I am concerned about these proposals. One in particular seems to me to be very harsh. I refer here to clause 6 (c) (i) which includes in the definition of `abscond', the death of the accused. Others deal with the presumption by the courts that all property gained in a certain period is fraudulently acquired. These provisions are in clauses 19 (6) (c), and 27 (6). Clause 82 reverses the onus of proof for a person charged with receiving. Under clause 48 (5) a person being examined on his affairs by the courts may not refuse to answer questions on the grounds of self-incrimination.

I know that in the fight against organised crime it often appears expedient to introduce exceptions to the general practice of the law. However, I believe quite strongly that the development of the right relating to the presumption of innocence was well founded. It is too easy for a government which does not have to abide by it to indulge in the sort of unsavoury pseudo-legal behaviour which we as a parliament would not condone. No matter what the circumstances, I do not think the presumption of innocence can be faulted. It is a bit like trial by jury. Sometimes things may go wrong, but on balance it is better to trust a group of our peers than to rely on the judgment of one person aided by the full resources of the law. This in no way means that I believe that we should be soft on criminals, especially the Mr Bigs, who are usually the ones who get away with it leaving the small timers to take the rap. On the contrary, I believe that we should bring the full force of the law down on them, and that is what I think this Bill will do when it becomes part of the statutes.

It is high time that legislation such as this was introduced, especially those provisions which require financial institutions to provide information which will enable the money trail to be followed. Only in this way will we be able to have some idea of the ways in which money is laundered, and be able to trace the accomplices in the respectable end of town who are able to live happily off the proceeds of crime with a clear conscience.

As I pointed out earlier, this Bill gives to the police additional powers. This is one of the cases in which I believe that the police have a very real need for new powers, which will enable them to adjust their investigation procedures to bring them in line with modern business technology and practice. That is what is needed if we are to trace the real perpetrators of criminal activity. Most ordinary Australians are law abiding citizens who are rightly upset by the contempt in which they are held by those Mr Bigs of organised crime, who hide under the cloak of respectability while getting away with criminal activities. Unfortunately, the real criminals in our society are not the small time occasional crooks who, through economic circumstances, turn to crime. I do not condone their activities, but I think that they are in some respects less to be condemned than the big time criminals. The people I am talking about are the Bartons and the Rooms in the community who, under the protection of the establishment, are able to defraud ordinary Australians, who are the big drug pushers, and who continually undermine the morals of our community with their hypocritical and anti-social behaviour. This legislation will at last give us the power to start to tackle crime at the highest levels, where it is organised, and for that reason I support it strongly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surprised as I am to get the call so quickly, it gives me a great deal of pleasure to speak to this important piece of legislation. Prior to going to some of the issues that I think it is appropriate to raise, I think it is worth making a couple of comments in relation to the Government's record in the area of the fight against organised crime. There has been a raft of legislative initiatives under this Government. Earlier I heard some of my colleagues referring to the record of this Parliament in responding to organised crime, and that record, until the relatively recent past, has not been a proud one. There may be a number of excuses for that; for example, a lack of knowledge about the way that organised crime has expanded over the years and, by its very nature, a very real difficulty in making judgments about how to respond to it. (Quorum formed) This discredited and divided Opposition, rather than earning government will now go out into the community expecting to purchase government. The one consistent theme that comes out of the bleatings from Opposition members in relation to issues touching upon organised crime is that they embrace the same approach whatever policy area is before this Parliament. When one reflects on initiatives taken by this Parliament in relation to organised crime it is interesting to note the total absence of initiative of any substance by the Opposition when in government. We have not exactly graced the treasury bench for very long since Federation. That has been the province of the now discredited Opposition, and it really has not taken any initiatives of any moment in relation to this most important issue. On the other hand, the Government has taken a whole raft of initiatives. Let me address some of them briefly.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the crime trifecta package. The Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, together with the Bills we now debating, provides one of the most potent weapons that any government has brought to bear in relation to these issues. The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill currently before the Parliament is a matter of great controversy. Nevertheless, on any objective assessment, it is one of the most significant instruments in the fight against organised crime. The Government not only established the National Crime Authority but also seeks to provide it with sufficient resources so that it is able to discharge its very important functions. Drug trafficking offences are the appropriate No. 1 target for all government initiatives in opposition to organised crime.

The Government has increased the number of Australian Federal Police officers and increased the resources available to that police force. I instance the provision of significantly increased computer crime fighting capacity. It will come as no surprise to honourable members that that is one of the most important areas where we can increase the resources available to our law enforcement officers. The now independent Australian Customs Service has a much greater ability to respond in a flexible and potent way to these issues.

The appointment of a Director of Public Prosecutions-once again this was talked about by previous governments but very little of substance was done-was also appropriate. There has been an increase in the resources available to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. In my work as Chairman of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I am able to form an independent judgment about the effectiveness of the increased powers and resources made available to that body. Not only the National Crime Authority but also all other policing agencies now have access to significantly improved criminal intelligence material. I think most honourable members would agree that that of itself is a significant advantage or a significant new arrow in the quiver that represents the whole gamut of legislation and government initiatives that are directed towards the fight against organised crime.

The legislation before the House is similar to legislation that has been embraced overseas but, in some instances, some aspects are significantly stronger. For my own experience, I was a little surprised by some of the power of pre-existing legislation-for example, customs legislation. I had representations made to me by a constituent I think it appropriate not to name to the effect that he owned, in partnership with an importing company, a truck which after the dissolution of that partnership he on-loaned to his former partner. According to the representations made to me, his former partner on-loaned the vehicle to one other who again on-loaned the vehicle to another person. My constituent put it to me that he was completely innocent about the transactions and it came as a great surprise to him when the truck was confiscated because it was transporting illegally imported narcotics.

The interesting thing about the case is the potency of the legislation that we were able to call on in that instance. Of course, it is directed specifically to illegal activity related to the import or export of goods. When looking at some of the case law to make a judgment about the circumstances in which my constituent found himself I found a case where a taxi driver, having been called to a dockyard area and having been implicated in the moving of illegally imported narcotics, had his cab confiscated. The result was that it became quite clear to the taxi driver that, after having some legal advice on the circumstances that he faced, for all intents and purposes he had lost his motor vehicle. So by any definition it is a very potent piece of legislation.

This legislation with which we are dealing embraces some of the cautious sentiments expressed by other members and has made provision to ensure that the property of innocent third parties is not confiscated in that rather draconian way. Of course I make no comment on the guilt or otherwise of my constituent, but I believe the case is an appropriate one for ministerial review. Provided certain other investigations are made in relation to these representations, the Minister may find it appropriate to exercise a discretion in my constituent's favour and to have that motor vehicle returned to him.

There is one particular matter I thought we should raise in dealing with other aspects of the legislation. In this whole area there is a common theme of criminals, hiding their illegally and ill-gotten gains behind the corporate veil or otherwise seeking to shield them from public scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite would know about that.

—That is right. My colleague indicated that a more detailed knowledge of these areas is probably vested in honourable members of the Opposition, but I will not pursue that line of discussion at this moment. Provision is made in this legislation that where the subject property or properties is under the control of a convicted person, or otherwise held for his or her benefit, courts can go behind the corporate veil to ensure that property that would otherwise be kept from public scrutiny is in fact obtained and confiscated by the Commonwealth. That is a very important component of the legislation for this reason: It is common knowledge amongst accountants, lawyers and others who are involved in these areas that it is not a particularly difficult thing to hide property or money in a whole range of ways. This provision is intended to circumscribe the deliberate setting up of schemes to frustrate the fundamental objective of the legislation, which is of course to attack the very basis of organised crime by making it an unsafe bet that many years after the commission of criminal offences criminals can come back to their loot and enjoy it at their own leisure. Over the years there have been many instances where people have done just that. It is quite common to hear of people in the gaols throughout this country who are prepared to do their time, to do their porridge or whatever they call it, with the expectation of leaving gaol at some point and then enjoying the proceeds of their often many and nefarious crimes.

SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated at the outset, this legislation is but one part of the armoury that this Government has brought to bear against organised crime. I listened with some interest to the Opposition once again criticising aspects of this legislation, as is its right in this chamber. The common theme was that the Government does not appear to have gone far enough or is somehow or other soft on organised crime. I believe that any objective observer could only conclude that, certainly on a comparative basis, this Government has done more than any other government since Federation in relation to these issues. That is simply an empirical fact. It cannot be contested, although there are legitimate areas that one can debate about how far the Government has gone and perhaps how far it should go in the future.

The whole raft of legislation to which I have referred and the many and varied initiatives taken by this Government to address these issues are such that I believe for the very first time in many years organised crime figures in this country particularly have been destabilised at least to the extent that they cannot go about their activities with the benefit of the knowledge that the assets that they gain by those illegal activities will at some point be available for their enjoyment even though they may be convicted of offences relating to them. The Proceeds of Crime Bill is one of the most significant issues introduced by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). I believe that his work on organised crime will be one very important acknowledgment of his term as Attorney-General in this Parliament. I hope that in the future he will continue with these major initiatives, which I think are the cause of some jealousy on the other side of the House where there is a lot of sound and fury but very little action indeed on any of these issues.

I believe that this Bill is not the crowning glory of the Government's initiatives in this area but is certainly a major part of its response to organised crime. I believe that the Government should be commended for that and I am sure that that will be the case in the community on a bipartisan or objective basis. I commend the Bill to the House. I think it is a most difficult area of law and one that we have thought long and hard over. It represents an appropriate balance between the civil liberties referred to by my colleague the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) and the very serious challenge that organised crime poses not only to this community but to institutions such as this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Proceeds of Crime Bill is part of a very important package of Bills. I feel that it would be wrong not to say a few words in support of such important legislation and to praise the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for bringing in this Bill to facilitate the recovery of funds raised as a result of any serious offence committed against Commonwealth law. In his second reading speech the Attorney-General mentioned the fact that traditional methods of punishment by imprisonment and fine are not enough. I note that in some cases the penalty is 20 years imprisonment or a fine of $200,000, and in another case it is a fine of $5,000 or two years in gaol. I have complained before that the rule of thumb of a fine of $5,000 or two years imprisonment is not appropriate. If persons are to be denied their livelihood for two years, the alternative penalty of a fine should be at least twice the average weekly earnings for that period. I again draw that matter to the attention of the Attorney-General. It is not a criticism of the Bill; I have found this unevenness between the penalty of imprisonment and the alternative monetary penalty in all legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: My first contact with people succeeding in crime by getting away with fraud was as a young solicitor working in the old Commonwealth Crown Solicitor's office in Sydney. The first job that I was given after being admitted was to go through a suitcase full of material-letters, receipts, et cetera relating to a bankrupt who was living the life of Riley in Sydney selling aeroplanes, making a fortune, and not paying any taxes. I was told that the evidence was in the suitcase and I just had to find it-but no one could find it. There must be other procedures for tracing money or obtaining orders to make banks release details. This man got off scot-free and he is probably still living it up in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you give him back the suitcase?

—I am sorry, but I do not know what happened to the suitcase. I will mention several points in the legislation that have not really been touched on since I have been in the chamber. One is that banks henceforth have to keep records for seven years relating to the opening of bank accounts. That is very important. There is a feeling in the community that banks keep records for three years. I have had constituents who have tried to trace proceedings and have been told that all records were destroyed. Bank records will have to be kept for seven years. There will also be a procedure for monitoring orders whereby a Supreme Court judge can direct that financial institutions give information over a certain period of time to law enforcement agencies concerning transactions on accounts. There have been some appalling revelations of bank managers and other people opening accounts for people even though they knew the names were fraudulent. Such revelations have really shocked the prudent business world.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other provisions in the legislation creating new offences for money laundering and organised fraud. These offences are particularly relevant in relation to solicitors, accountants, bookmakers and people who handle large sums of cash and are involved in cash transactions. As the Attorney-General said, legislation will be introduced requiring certain cash transactions to be reported to a central government agency. Other Bills in this package include the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill. The whole package of legislation in this area will be complementary. Honourable members who have been here for a few years would remember the bottom of the harbour cases, the McCabe-Lafranchi report of Inspectors Appointed to Investigate the Particular Affairs of Navillus Pty Ltd and 922 Other Companies-1983 report on tax avoidance in Australia presented in the Victorian Parliament, the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and the revelations that shocked Australia and contributed to a change of government as a result of the evidence that came forward.

Before concluding I pay tribute to the work of the Attorney-General's Department and its officers led by the Attorney-General himself and the work of the National Crime Authority. My hope is that the work of the NCA will be assisted by this package of legislation. I well remember the allegations made to the New South Wales Select Committee on Prostitution by Mr Anderson, who alleged that in the early 1970s there was so much corruption in New South Wales that anyone who was a rising politician or a barrister who looked like becoming a judge--

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! That is a terrible thing for you to say.

—This allegation was made to the Select Committee. If the honourable member wants to check, let him read the Sydney Morning Herald report of that time. Mr Anderson said that there were attempts to corrupt people and obtain embarrassing details about them along with compromising photographs of people who looked like becoming leading members of parliament or judges. If one reads the Select Committee on Prostitution report, one will see that it disregarded what was said by this man Anderson. I feel that those allegations have never been tested, and I believe the National Crime Authority should test them. The allegations were most serious, striking at the very root of our society, and compromising in a very evil and devious way people who might now be in important positions. That is another reason why I wanted to speak to this Bill tonight and make the point that only by vigilance and total dedication will we ever rid our society of organised crime. I pay credit to Mr Justice Stewart and all those working in the National Crime Authority and other law enforcement agencies of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a wide ranging and lengthy debate and I thank honourable members for their contributions. I am particularly appreciative of the remarks made by my colleagues the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) and the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher). I thank them very much for mentioning the real issues behind the Proceeds of Crime Bill. It is to prevent criminal activity being lucrative. Whilst it might always be lucrative, if we can establish that people have money as a result of criminal activity, we will do everything we can to forfeit that money. It will be an additional penalty. We acknowledge that. When society is so concerned about the increase in crime and the devastation it causes, particularly to young people when they deal with narcotics, and the tragedy that families must bear because of criminal activity, it is only natural that we need laws that are modern, up to date and punitive.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I can understand the sensitivities of some honourable members who have said that we might have reversed the onus of proof principle, I wish to make it clear that a person who has no guilt will not suffer any penalty under the Bill. All that is required in certain circumstances is an explanation as to how assets have been acquired. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) made a contribution in this respect. He said that, whilst he had no truck with criminals, he objected to some of the provisions. I know that he means well, but if people who are asked to explain how they got assets-they could well be asked to do so under the present taxation laws-because it is suspected that they have been acquired through criminal activity and they cannot give an explanation, is it not about time that society said: `If there has been unlawful activity, we will take the assets'? If a person can clearly establish that he has acquired his money or assets through lawful activity, he has nothing to fear. We cannot have a person getting the benefit of unlawful activity and then saying: `Try to prove it against me'. As society knows, people do use money-laundering practices, and they are dealt with in clause 81. A complete defence is given to any accusation if a person satisfies the court that there are proper grounds for his having the property in his possession.

I do not want to go through all the provisions, but I will deal with the matters which the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) properly raised. The honourable gentleman has moved an amendment in the following terms:
whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that-
(1) it comprises a major and novel legislative package-

I thank him for that. He made the point that the Bill contains a number of clauses. He would understand that it has required a fair amount of drafting and instructions. I thank the officers of my Department and my personal staff for their dedication in this exercise. I also thank my previous Principal Private Secretary for having the initiative to talk about how other countries are dealing with these matters and for developing ideas about how we might effectively legislate to prevent criminal activity being of any benefit if we can prove that a person's assets have been gained through unlawful activity.

The honourable gentleman then said that in his view there was not sufficient time to consider the Bill because it was introduced on 30 April and was called on for debate on 11 May. I appreciate the fact that this Parliament has to debate matters within time constraints. It is now 28 May and we have had a pretty good debate this evening. I ask the honourable gentleman to consider the way in which we have to deal with legislation. The Bills passed by this House in the current sittings number approximately 85. The Bills passed by the Senate in the same period number approximately 25. The Senate has dictated to us that, unless we get certain Bills through before a certain date, it will not even deal with them.

I know that the honourable gentleman has some influence with the senators in his Party. It is important for them to recognise that if the House of Representatives works effectively and earnestly in passing legislation, the Senate should also deal with matters as quickly as possible. We should not have a position in which the House of Representatives is able to pass 85 Bills yet the Senate feels inclined to deal with only 25. That is one of the problems we face in modern democracy. Whilst we recognise that the Senate is a House of review, it should not be a house of obstruction.

That is one of the problems we have in this House when we try to confine debates to a reasonable time. I think that we have met that requirement in respect of this legislation. Later we will be dealing with other aspects of what is called the anti-crime package of legislation concerning cash transactions and telephone interceptions. We want to get that legislation passed also. I welcome the Opposition's support in that respect.

The honourable member for North Sydney claimed thirdly that the Bill imposes on financial institutions heavy obligations for the retention of records concerning financial transactions. He suggested that the debate ought to focus on the proposition that the threshold level of $200, in respect of the retention of records was too low. I am advised that the $200 threshold was suggested by credit unions and appears to be supported by the banks. On 6 May Mr Cullen from the Australian Bankers Association advised:

The Australian Bankers' Association now has no major objections to the Proceeds of Crime Bill as a result of the changes made to the initial drafts to meet the concerns of banks about its efficient and equitable operation. We appreciate the fact that our submissions on the Bill were addressed.

The Bill represents a form of compromise between retaining all documents and retaining only those documents that are most likely to be relevant to criminal investigations not only of a major crime but also of more common offences such as medifraud and social security fraud, which usually involve a large number of relatively small transactions and constitute a drain on public funds. The increase of the threshold for retention to $1,000 would not only hamper the investigation of common offences but would also enable criminals to structure their transactions so as to keep them under the retention threshold. I know the honourable gentleman will be conscious of that position now.

The honourable member for North Sydney also raised the question of protection of third party rights against forfeiture. Clause 45 of the Bill provides for any person with an interest in property which is the subject of an application for a restraining order to be notified of the application. Honourable members will note that clause 45 (5) states that the court may direct the Director of Public Prosecutions `to give or publish notice of the application to a specified person or class of persons, in the manner and within the time that the court considers appropriate'. So we could well find that the court has an additional initiative. Clause 46 provides that any person who claims an interest in a property which is the subject of an application may appear and be heard at the hearing of the application. Clause 48 provides that such a person may also seek a variation of the restraining order to exclude his or her property from the ambit of the order. Clause 15 (1) (c) provides that, where there is a suggestion that a person has an interest in property which would be the subject of forfeiture, notification of that application will be given.

Honourable members will see when they look at these clauses that a person is given every opportunity to say that he has a genuine interest that needs to be protected. The court can take that into consideration. Also, the court may well rescind a forfeiture order if a person can establish that he has a bona fide interest in a property and had no knowledge of any illegal action relating to that asset. Most people with interest in property or assets usually have that interest registered in some form, and the registration itself usually provides for some protection of the equity. If it is not registered, there is a difficulty. However, it does not prevent a person from claiming an equity or the whole of an asset, and the court would deal with it on a proper basis.

The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) referred to Mr Costigan. I know that his remarks were not directly relevant to the Bill, but I thank him for raising the issue. As he knows, the matter arose out of the fact that there was a royal commission. I do not want to emphasise it again, but the matters were of some concern. They related to Mr Packer, a man of some significance in the business world, in Sydney particularly, and also in Australia.

In that case Mr Costigan felt quite properly that certain matters should be investigated. Unfortunately, when he prepared, quite properly what is called case summaries, they were published by the National Times and everybody, including the National Times, acknowledges that that should not have happened. It caused untold damage to Mr Packer and his family, and that is of great concern to him, because he had no remedy. At that stage all he received was an apology. At the conclusion of the investigation into those three significant matters, I was left with this situation: The allegations were that, firstly, there had been a tax related offence which was sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions, who then reported that no charges should be brought against Mr Packer; secondly, that quantities of drugs had been imported in a container which, it was alleged, could have implicated Mr Packer and that matter was referred to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police who found that there was no evidence at all to connect Mr Packer in any way with the alleged illegal importation; thirdly, that there was a problem in respect of the death of a Queensland bank manager. The problem might well have been murder and the suggestion was that that ought to be the subject of investigation-which it was-by a coroner, who found that there was no basis whatsoever to allege that Mr Packer might have been associated in some way with the bank manager's death.

They are rather serious matters. I acknowledge that any royal commission would have to deal with them and the Costigan Royal Commission dealt with them properly. When the matters were looked at, there was no evidence. Following those investigations I was in the position of having Mr Packer's solicitors say: `Are we just going to leave it on that basis? Because everybody says that there is no evidence, do we not say any more about the matter? Is it not fair and reasonable that a statement be issued to say that there is no evidence?' I asked the National Crime Minister whether it could issue a statement but it said no, that it was not its function, that its function was only to investigate the matter. It made that point very clear. Usually, when the Director of Public Prosecutions says that he will not prosecute, he does not issue a Press statement. Those allegations involve three serious charges which could have been made against anyone. These were very serious matters relating to taxation, drug importation and murder, but nothing was to be said about them. I make the point that I have the utmost regard for Mr Costigan, who is a man of the greatest integrity. No problem exists there. The problem is that somebody gave summaries of prima facie allegations to the National Times.

I thank the honourable member for Gippsland for raising the matter but, because it has been published in the Press, I can understand Mr Costigan's concern that there may have been an inference that he had released the information to the Press. That thought never crossed my mind; he would not do that. He is an outstanding person, but when royal commissions are conducted and allegations are made, and when the media gets hold of those allegations, irreparable damage is caused. In the Press statement I said:

It is not unreasonable to expect that in future, issues will arise which require the appointment of a Royal Commission to investigate allegations . . . It is essential that, when such proceedings are conducted-
and bear in mind that I am talking about the future-
adequate protection is given to people who are the subject of the investigation.
I further said:

It is incumbent upon those who conduct Royal Commissions and the governments which appoint them and deal with their recommendations, that the utmost care is taken to protect individuals from the damaging consequences of the improper release of material relating to the conduct of the Commission.

Again, I emphasise that that in no way passes any reflection on Mr Costigan or members of his staff. The important thing is that the National Times knows from whom it was obtained and it had a responsibility not to publish it. It is equally incumbent upon the Press to show some respect for the rights of individuals when reporting on the conduct of royal commissions, particularly when, as occurred in this case, and as was acknowledged subsequently by the National Times, it had no evidence and nor was it aware of any evidence which would support the allegations in the material that it published. Publication was not justified. In this case the publication of an apology is not a remedy.

I thank the honourable member for Gippsland for raising the matter, but I want him to understand that this is a unique set of circumstances. We created the National Crime Authority, the Fraser Government set up the royal commission and the Press decided to publish something for which there is no foundation. Mr Costigan made the point-and I emphasise it-that he would not have approved in any way the release of the information, but I have to say that it was released. In future, we have to be very careful about these matters, because Mr Packer is perfectly entitled to feel that irreparable damage has been done and that apologies do not satisfy the situation.

Any person, particularly a member of parliament, could suffer the greatest damage as a result of allegations. But we can imagine what it does to the wives and children of people who have to live with this sort of accusation. I thank the honourable member for Gippsland for raising the matter because, if there is still some concern, I want to put it to rest. I believe that we owe Frank Costigan a great deal. I think that he was one of the few counsel who had the courage to take on the commission given to him by the Fraser Government in respect of the painters and dockers. I think that it appointed him for a purpose which it did not foresee, and we were delighted with the results. I make the point-I have put it on record many times-that the issue with which I am dealing is somebody saying on behalf of Mr Packer that he is completely innocent and that those accusations should never have been published.

TALK.START.PARA: —We stuck with him. Despite that, we stuck with Costigan.

—Yes, I think that honourable members opposite did and I have never said that they did not. What I am trying to say is that I think he stuck with the Fraser Government because it had a lot of difficulty in obtaining counsel to undertake this Royal Commission. It required Mr Costigan's courage to take it on and that is the point. We had a lot of difficulty in getting the then Government to table the Costigan reports and I can understand why. That is the position.
—But you sacked him.

—No, I refer to when the Liberal Party was in government. It would not publish the reports. On many occasions we had to obtain the reports from the Victorian Government in order to find out what the then government had in its possession, because those matters related to its incompetence in being able to deal with bottom of the harbour and tax evasion schemes. That was its problem. However, I thank honourable members for their contributions. A couple of amendments will have to be moved and I will discuss those in the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, page 1, line 7, omit ``the twenty-eighth day after''.

This is a machinery amendment which has been circulated. The reason for this amendment is that the amendment to clause 2 of the Proceeds of Crime Bill provides that it may come into operation on the day when it receives royal assent. The legislation originally was to come into force 28 days after royal assent. It was originally assumed that the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987 would be enacted before the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill 1987; but the reverse has occurred. It is therefore now intended to proclaim the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill as soon as the Proceeds of Crime Bill receives the royal assent so that Australia can give an assurance of reciprocity to certain foreign states which have frozen assets located in their jurisdiction in anticipation of that assurance. I think that is a satisfactory explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We accept the amendment. But, since we are now at the Committee stage and addressing the whole Bill, there are one or two things that I want to say about the Bills as a whole and about one or two things that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has said. I pointed out in my speech on the amendment to the second reading motion that this is a very complex Bill. The Attorney-General acknowledges that. It is a Bill of some 104 clauses and debate has been far too rushed in this House. It is a major package. It is a well-drawn package and I commend those in the Attorney-General's Department whose job it was to draw up this Bill. But, when one is dealing with legislation which is so novel and so far reaching, it is very much better for the legislation to be introduced and allowed to lie on the table so that we can assess it, so that we can consult and so that we can have a very much better view of the intricacies and possible difficulties that a new complex legislative package presents, especially when here we are dealing with something quite new.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that there are forfeiture provisions in existing legislation. But, as I pointed out in my speech on the second reading, they are of a peripheral and archaic nature. It does not do very much good to be able to forfeit the tools that a burglar uses in his crime or to be able to forfeit implements used in gambling. We have here a proposal which we in the Opposition have urged for a long time and which royal commissioners have urged for years. This Government has now been in power, I am sorry to say, for 4 years, 2 months and a few days--

TALK.START.PARA: —We will probably go on to eight years.

—The Attorney-General says that he will go on for eight years. There is no prospect of that because the Australian people will deliver a verdict on 11 July. The point that I make is that, in opposition, the Australian Labor Party talked a great deal about organised crime, the Fraser Government and the failings of that Government. I remind the Committee that the Fraser Government put up the National Crimes Commission Bill, which was the genesis for the National Crime Authority Bill, which became the National Crime Authority Act. That is the first thing. The Fraser Government established the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The Fraser Government extended the terms of reference of that royal commission. These things should not be forgotten.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General, in referring to Mr Costigan, referred to what took place with regard to Mr Packer. I entirely endorse what he said about Mr Packer and the irreparable damage done to him by the leaking of the so-called prima facie allegations to the National Times and their publication by the National Times. If any newspaper does that, it should understand very clearly that what it is doing is perfectly indecent because the remarks once made, the publicity once given, can never be compensated for. I was glad when the Attorney-General published his views, which I endorsed at the time, that Mr Packer should be able to feel that his reputation was entirely unsullied. But that is damned little recompense to a person who has had as much unfavourable publicity as Mr Packer drew from the publications in the National Times.

Returning to one or two things that the Attorney-General has said about this Bill, I remind him that he says, in answer to questions raised concerning the rights of innocent third parties-questions which were raised from his side of the chamber as well as from my side of the chamber-that interests in assets usually have some form of registration. That was the gist of what he said. Of course, that is largely wrong. If one is talking about interest in real property and land, of course there is a system for registration. But, if one is talking about bullion, diamonds, cash or bank accounts, no registration system exists and therefore those who come to courts are faced with the prospect of proving what their interests are.

The point that must be stressed is that, when we are dealing with a legislative package which is quite new and which confers the most far reaching powers of forfeiture on courts-and rightly so because criminals should not be able to retain the proceeds or the profits from their crimes-one must understand that new legislation in unexplored territory will poise problems for the administration of justice and the rights of third parties. These are things which we all need to address. There is no politics in it; there is no basis for contention. I am sure that the Attorney-General will agree that, if problems arise concerning innocent third parties, he as the shadow Minister for legal affairs in the next Opposition and I as the Attorney-General, or whoever is the Attorney-General from our side of the chamber, should be able to get together and agree upon sensible amendments that will overcome any injustice.

For the purpose of the record I will list a few possibilities. The first is the need, perhaps, for a requirement that there be some form of advertising by the Director of Public Prosecutions of an application for forfeiture. That is not an answer in itself because we know that advertisements that appear under the legal notices are not scanned daily. But at least we have to look to the means of publicising them so that innocent third parties may be put upon notice.
