I know that the Attorney-General has referred to a clause which provides that a court may direct that there be some form of publicity given-but I think we need to go beyond that.

Next, it may be that the court, in deciding whether to grant a forfeiture order, should be required to consider the interests of third parties, together with the hardship of other persons who have the ordinary use of property. Next, property subject to forfeiture orders should vest in the Commonwealth subject to every charge or encumbrance to which the property was subject immediately before the forfeiture order was made. This may be intended by the legislation. However, I think that is something that we need to bear in mind so that, if it turns out that the court interprets the legislation so as not to give effect to every charge or encumbrance, for example, an equitable charge which is unregistered or an equitable interest which is unregistered, we may need to look to overcoming that at some time in the future. I do not say that it is a necessary defect. I say that it is simply a potential problem.

Next, it may well be that the Commonwealth and the official trustee in the case of restraining orders should be obliged both in the case of forfeiture orders and restraining orders to preserve the value of property, including taking positive action where necessary. Where, for example, assets which are used in a business are the subject of a restraining or forfeiture order, where does that leave the business, what are the consequences for that business and what damage is done to the value of the business? These are questions that need to be addressed. Anyone who has had any experience in receiving orders, in winding up orders in the courts, knows that once a business is closed down, the goodwill vanishes and the capacity to reinvigorate the business is marginal at best. Again, this is a matter that we need to look at carefully when we study the operation of the legislation through the courts.

Other possibilities for consideration are the possible need for provisions as to the date which is to apply in assessing the value of property. It may be that a provision similar to clause 27 (3), which deals with pecuniary interests, should apply to property valued under forfeiture order provisions. We should remember that property may be valued, there may be an appeal and it may be a long time before there is a determination. And what then? These are questions that have to be worked out by the courts and they are questions which as parliamentarians we may have to address without, as I have said, any sense of contention.

Lastly, there are limitations on time for the purposes of making an application to establish an interest in property which is the subject of orders under the Act. I believe that it is very important that people not be shut out if they neglect their rights simply because time has expired. That again is something that we are going to need to look at in the course of the operation of this Bill. But allowing for the delay of the Government in bringing forward this package, it is a Bill which the Opposition supports. I commend again those who had the job of drafting a very difficult Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to reply briefly. I acknowledge what the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) says: There may be circumstances where the court has to give special consideration because the rights of people may not be clearly evident at the time of forfeiture. He mentioned though that there were some assets such as cash, bank accounts, diamonds and bullion, et cetera, that there would be some difficulty about. One thing he did not mention was possession. The Commonwealth would not have those assets in possession in the initial stage. I would be very surprised if those who did have them in possession were not aware that there might be some person who would certainly have another interest in them. I accept the view that there might be special circumstances where that would not arise. If there were circumstances where a period had elapsed and somebody, for some reason that I do not understand at this stage, felt that he should have had an opportunity to declare an interest, I am sure we would need to consider that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: We want to make the point that there are a number of provisions giving opportunities for people to appear and adduce evidence. The honourable member acknowledges that if land or real estate are involved there is likely to be a registrable interest. I can understand that, but I am very conscious of the fact that in the taxation area at present the Taxation Office is able to actually take assets on the basis that it feels they are able to be taken at that stage because of tax due. There is an opportunity there for a person to rebut that presumption.

I thank the honourable member for his understanding of the difficulties in this matter. We are entering into a new area of punitive action. I think it will require all the judicial capacity for which our courts are noted. I am sure that, if there is any suggestion that a person has an interest and if that person is not known, every effort will be made to try to find that person through the relevant provisions, particularly considering clause 45 (5) and other such matters. We will do the best we can in accordance with the knowledge that the courts now have as to how to try to find people who may have an interest.

We are getting near the end of the parliamentary session. The honourable member was gracious enough to suggest that he may be shadow Attorney-General or Attorney-General, but he was not confident enough to suggest that he alone would be. I notice that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) is smiling anxiously. Honourable members will notice that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) talks every time the honourable member for North Sydney speaks. He has the field-marshal's baton in his knapsack, so be very careful of that.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen)-by leave-read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 11 May, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 13, page 6, line 37, omit ``cheque'', insert ``payment order''.
(2) Clause 13, page 6, line 38, omit ``cheque'', insert ``payment order''.

This basically is a printer's error. The Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill has a number of clauses. Clause 12 deals with how cheques are to be dealt with. Clause 13 refers to how payment orders are to be dealt with. Due to inadvertence in the printing of clause 13, on page 6, honourable members will see a reference to `cheque' when it actually should be a reference to `payment order' in accordance with the title given to it. It is purely a machinery amendment and is self-explanatory.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen)-by leave-read a third time.
Debate resumed from 14 May, on motion by Mr Young:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill has been brought on suddenly in the House. Of course, we heard about it only just prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner this evening. I think it is symptomatic of the Government's actions that we should not have any real knowledge of if coming in at this stage. It is a great pity. It has been brought about by the fact that the Government is going to an early election. I remind honourable members of this House and anybody who may be listening to the broadcast that we all knew from the many statements made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), particularly the one on April Fools Day, 1 April this year, that we would not be having an early election. That was followed earlier this month by other statements that he could not see any reason why July would be a month in which an election could be held.

SPEECH.PARA: We find yet again that the Prime Minister's statements and words simply cannot be believed because here we have again an early election being thrust on the Australian people with no basis or real reasons at all, brought about merely because of political opportunism. The Prime Minister obviously believes-he has been duped by some of his Ministers-that this may be the most advantageous time for him to go to the people. He has no basis at all or any real reason such as problems with the Senate or anything else. The fact remains that the people of Australia really will have to look very closely at the reasons why the Prime Minister has chosen to go to an early election and has required this Bill to be brought on early and very quickly without adequate knowledge by the Opposition of its being brought forward. One would have to be very suspicious of what the Prime Minister and his Ministers have up their sleeves in relation to the coming Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Arms; that is what we've got up our sleeves.

—The Minister at the table is a notorious Minister, if I can use that phrase kindly. He knows all about having things up his sleeve. No doubt he is one of those who said to the Prime Minister: `Now is the time to go before the people really wake up to what we are about, before they understand what is in the industrial legislation that we have relegated to the bottom of the Notice Paper so that it will not be debated'.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no doubt that the people of Australia will not be duped by the absolute insincerity of the Prime Minister's statements in relation to the reasons for the early election. I am always fascinated when I hear the Prime Minister say that his integrity is untarnished. I am always fascinated by someone who protests so loudly about his integrity, about how his word can be relied upon. No doubt during the election campaign we will instance to the people the many statements he has made which have been subsequently and very quickly repudiated by the man himself. The Bill is a consequence of the work of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. This Committee has been operating for some four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —A hard-working committee.

—It is a very hard-working committee and it receives a tremendous amount of information and many submissions from a wide variety of people. Some of the submissions are given great consideration, and some befuddle the mind. Nevertheless, the work of the Committee has been very important. There have been strong disagreements between members of the Committee but, hopefully, those who have worked assiduously on it have come down to a largely agreed view on a great number of very contentious issues.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill comes from the work that the Committee has done largely following the experience of the last general election in 1984. Some 156 recommendations came forward in the most recent report of the Committee, and I understand that this legislation is the first part of two packages of the Government's response. The Bill is needed to give effect to recommendations that the Government has taken up involving a legislative requirement, and thus is before us at present. As I have said, most of the recommendations of the Committee have been accepted by the Government. But one in particular has not been accepted. I am told that it was rejected in Cabinet, and I would like to know why. Perhaps the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who is at the table, can give the reason. As a member of the House of Representatives, he would know how important it is for members of parliament both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate to know the gender of people coming on to the electoral roll. The Committee recommended that gender, occupation and date of birth be included in the details of people whose names appear on the roll.

I can understand a rejection of the recommendation for date of birth being included, but for the life of me I cannot understand how noting on the electoral roll the gender and occupation of the individual elector is any invasion of privacy whatsoever. I must say that it would be extremely helpful to all members of Parliament in their dealings with their electors, particularly in writing to them to welcome them to the electorate, and in relation to so many other matters that take up the work of members of Parliament, if those details, particularly gender and occupation, were included in the information supplied on the electoral roll. I ask the Government to reconsider its views on that recommendation.

The legislation deals with a number of matters. I will not go into them all. It deals with the responsibility of electoral officials, the return of postal votes from overseas and advertising by governments and individuals, and it deals at some length with the redistribution process. It deals particularly with the status of the officials involved in the redistribution process and the need to aim at absolute equality of enrolment at the 3 1/2-year mark following a redistribution of boundaries. This is a most important area. Some difficulties arose from the redistribution process prior to the last election, particularly in the country areas of New South Wales. Those problems have been addressed by the Committee and recommendations have been and, to a great degree, accepted by the Government. The Bill also deals with arrangements to ensure that as many eligible electors as possible may vote. It deals with the registration requirement of candidates, the simplification of the nomination process, the scrutiny of votes, and a definition of election advertising.

This Bill has become an extremely complex document. Hopefully, the Government will develop a document that simplifies the requirements of both parties and candidates. That would be particularly helpful for candidates who are not members of established political parties because the requirements now encumbered on a candidate, other than a candidate for an established political party, as outlined in the Bill, are quite extensive. The Bill is a fairly weighty document and, as I said, the requirements are very detailed. They must be understood. If not, a candidate, inadvertently or otherwise, may transgress them.

The Bill has already been debated in the Senate at considerable length. The issues have been canvassed by the major and the minor parties there. I must say that the contribution of the Australian Democrats was as confused as I find most of their thinking on the majority of the issues that come before the Senate. There was some disagreement. Amendments were moved by the National Party, and an amendment was moved by the Opposition and subsequently accepted by the Government. I understand that the National Party will move further amendments in Committee in this place. The Opposition understands the reason why this Bill has come before the house, but we do not understand why it had to be rushed in so precipitously tonight. We do understand, of course, that the Prime Minister and his Ministers may be smarting a little at the public reaction to the decision to hold an early election, a decision, I reiterate, that was made against the background of a categorical denial of an early election by the Prime Minister as recently as 1 April of this year. We regard the Bill as having been dealt with in a detailed manner in the Senate and therefore as not requiring an extensive debate at this stage in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like the previous speaker, am a member of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. With several other members in the chamber at present, I have had the pleasure of hearing evidence from many expert witnesses on areas in which people believe that the Commonwealth Electoral Act can be improved. Honourable members will be aware that the Act was overhauled in the last Parliament; in fact, in many ways the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill will simply fine tune the alterations made then. The Committee has been very ably chaired by Senator Robert Ray from Victoria.
—A good numbers man.

—Yes. He is not only an excellent numbers man but also an excellent Chairman of the Select Committee on Electoral Reform. That Committee made 156 recommendations and this Bill will implement the first stage of the reforms recommended by it. In the area of redistributions of electorates, this Bill will give the public and other interested parties greater opportunities to participate in the redistribution process. I think it is very important that local communities have an opportunity to express their views to the Electoral Commissioners as to the directions which that redistribution should take. It is very important that if, after the preliminary boundaries are released, the local community believes that it has been badly treated, that community should have the right and the opportunity to explain its objections to the Electoral Commissioners so that they can give those objections fair weight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will also give the Electoral Commissioners an additional degree of flexibility in determining the redistribution timetable. Of course, whenever a redistribution takes place it is only as good as the quality of the electoral rolls. That is why it is very important that habitation reviews be carried out annually. In fact, the Committee has made that recommendation. The Bill also abolishes the requirement for absolute future equality which was established under the previous Act. Under the previous Act the Electoral Commissioners had to carry out an estimate of what the population would be in electorates three years and six months after the date of the redistribution. Of course, no one can see clearly into the future. Those estimates often had associated with them a certain percentage of error. It was quite ridiculous to expect the Electoral Commission to divide electorates to within very small numbers of voters when its figures were based on estimates and projections. The Electoral Reform Committee has recommended that the Electoral Commissioners be given the power to vary the absolute future equality by plus or minus 2 per cent. I endorse that change.

On the question of redistributions and the way in which boundaries are drawn, I would like to make a few comments about what any future government comprising National Party, Queensland National Party or Opposition members would seek to do to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I would like to recount to the House an interview on the AM program involving a member of the Opposition front bench, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). In the transcript of that interview Mr John Highfield, the commentator, stated:
. . . Mr Reith outlined a conversation he had early last year with one of the Premier's-
that is, the Premier of Queensland-
chief supporters in the Federal Parliament, Queensland MP Mr Peter Slipper.
Mr Reith stated:
We had a general discussion, there were a number of us sitting down after dinner one night last year and the subject got on to electoral reform, and the proposal that he-
that is, Mr Slipper, the honourable member for Fisher-
was putting was that a National Party government in Canberra would be justified in rearranging electoral boundaries so as to ensure their continued political success.
The interviewer asked:
And you take that seriously?
Mr Reith answered:
Well, I didn't take it very seriously at the time although I believed what he said, but I must say I rather considered it with the contempt that it deserved.

So there we see once again divisions amongst the Opposition parties. A member of the Opposition front bench, the honourable member for Flinders, had a conversation with a member of the Queensland National Party and was totally outraged by that National Party member's plans if that Party were ever successful at a future election, which I know is very doubtful. If it were ever successful, of course, the National Party would intend to introduce its version of the Queensland gerrymander at the national level. Throughout Australia any region which voted for the National Party would be given an unfair advantage over areas that voted for the Australian Labor Party or for the Liberal Party. The National Party would simply seek to rig the boundaries in the same way in which they are rigged in Queensland.

This legislation also implements a number of reforms which govern the conduct of the election. One of those alterations is the provision for overseas polling officials to be subject to the same penalties for the neglect of duty as other polling officials. I received a number of complaints from constituents who sought to vote overseas at Australia's various embassies. Subsequent to the election they received letters from the Electoral Commission in which they were asked why they had failed to vote. In fact, they had voted at the overseas diplomatic missions. After investigation it became apparent that those overseas polling officials had failed to ensure that the votes of those constituents were rapidly forwarded to the Electoral Commission. Because they had failed to carry out their responsibilities properly, those Australian citizens who had taken the trouble to cast a vote had been denmied the opportunity of having that vote count towards the result of the election. That is totally unsatisfactory. The Committee has been advised by the Electoral Commission that the amendment which is being proposed will ensure that if those officials do not carry out their instructions properly, they will be subject to the normal penalties which apply to employees of the Electoral Commission.

The Electoral Commission is also given the power to extend times and deadlines which are established in the legislation by up to 48 hours in emergency situations, so that we do not have a situation where, due to some unforeseen circumstances, the electoral process is thrown into confusion. I suppose the most important reform in this legislation is the alterations to the Senate scrutiny. That is not of much interest to many people who are not experts on scrutineering votes and determining the results of Senate elections--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or senators.

—Or senators, as the Minister suggests. But it is very important to Australia as a country if we have an election and we fail to get the result of that election reasonably quickly. We all remember what happened in 1975 when the elected Government was dismissed. We had an election, and one can imagine what would have been the position if we had failed to get a result in the Senate because of some complication in the Senate count.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1984 amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act replaced the original random sampling process which had been used from 1948 to 1984 with a fractional transfer system which is used in the Tasmanian State elections. That means that every ballot paper remains in the count. It means that if an elected candidate's surplus is distributed, the Electoral Commissioner must go back over every single ballot paper to allow the count to continue. As a result, in one of the larger States such as Victoria or New South Wales, if a large number of candidates seek to nominate for the Senate, it is possible that it could take several months to get a result in the Senate. I think it is very good that this legislation will be on the statute books to ensure that we get a speedy result in the Senate election.

Before I conclude my remarks I want to touch on one final matter-that is, the question of disclosure of political funding. I believe it is the fundamental right of every Australian citizen to know who is supporting political parties and political candidates throughout the country. I believe that the debate on whether we should disclose political funding is the result of disclosures by many different newspaper organisations after the 1972 United States presidential election campaign, when it was exposed that various fundraising groups involved with President Nixon-through the famous CREEP Committee, the Campaign to Re-elect the President-sought to launder funds and donations which had been made anonymously to the organisation. The funds were laundered and, as a result, people were not aware that often shady organisations were making donations to the different candidates to seek to buy influence. As a result, to give the Americans credit, they pioneered legislation in this area. In many ways I believe that they have set an example which other countries around the world can investigate .

Our Committee received evidence of loopholes in the current legislation. Of course, the current legislation seeks to ensure that wherever donations over a fixed limit are made to candidates or political parties, people must declare who those donors are. Every Australian if he wishes to take the trouble can see who is making donations to the different political parties. Our Committee received evidence that a group called the National Free Enterprise Foundation made a substantial donation of six figures to a party in Queensland, which was not the Australian Labor Party-it was not from my side of politics. That foundation was able to use a loophole and to avoid disclosing who provided those funds.

In our Committee's second report we made a very important statement at page 172, which I would like to read into the Hansard tonight. It refers to people seeking to avoid the provisions of the current legislation, and it states:
In Recommendation 1 we recommend that the Committee be re-appointed as a Standing Committee with a general function of reviewing the Electoral Act and the work of the AEC-
that is the Australian Electoral Commission-
Such a committee would be well positioned to investigate suspected abuses and would have undoubted powers to do so.
It goes on to state:
It can be anticipated that such a committee would not hesitate to exercise these powers where it suspects the aims of the legislation are being subverted.

Organisations that are making donations to different parties in the belief that they can remain anonymous should not forget that in the next Parliament a committee may require them to attend a meeting of that committee. That committee could have the power to require answers to questions and the production of records and documents. If there is any evidence that people are seeking to subvert this legislation and to find loopholes in the provisions which require the disclosure of political donations I hope that our Committee will investigate that.

We should not forget the call by the `Joh for PM' campaign or the `Joh for Federal Parliament' campaign or the `Joh for the Senate' campaign, whatever it is tonight, for donations of up to $25m to fund his hit campaign, his attempt to take over the national Parliament and then introduce his gerrymander at the national level. The President of the Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia, Sir Robert Sparkes, said that it would be his intention for any future National Party government to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act retrospectively so that donors to the National Party's campaign would not have to be declared publicly. They could remain anonymous and in the shadows. It is quite interesting that Sir Robert Sparkes has proposed this retrospective legislation. I thought that the conservative parties were opposed to retrospective legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except when it suits them.

—As the honourable member for Charlton suggests, except when it suits them. In my view they oppose retrospective legislation only when it is legislation that a Labor government has introduced to seek to recover funds from the tax cheats who have abused the law of the land. But of course Sir Robert Sparkes has no moral objection to retrospective legislation if it will allow the white shoe brigade and all the other faceless men to continue hiding in the shadows. I believe the Australian people have a right to know who is bankrolling the Liberal Party and the National Party campaigns and for that matter, who is donating to the Australian Labor Party. We will make sure that the Australian people do know because we are not afraid of their knowing who makes a donation towards the re-election of the Labor Government. Once the Australian people know who the members of the white shoe brigade are and once they know who these faceless men in the shadows are, they will judge the Opposition's actions and reach the correct verdict. I support the legislation which is before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Mr Blunt) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Families-Queensland Government-Industrial Relations-Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education-Home Care Services-Member for Gippsland-Visit to Parliament House by High School Students-Chlorinated Hydrocarbon Chemicals-Australian Sportsmen: Taxation Liability-Transport of Ammunition

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Barry Jones) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since coming to office in 1983 the Federal Labor Government has snatched nearly $2 billion from Australians and, in particular, Australian families. This Government has abolished the tax rebate for health insurance premiums, terminated housing interest rebates, cut the children's tax threshold, abolished the concessional expenditure rebate, abolished the family allowance for dependent students aged 18 to 24 and means tested allowances for 16 and 17-year olds, and it has failed to increase and index dependant rebates and family allowances. Average Australian families, the traditional Australian battlers, are reaching new heights of desperation. High taxes, high interest rates, high costs for health care and the decline in the real value of the family allowance and dependent spouse rebate have all taken their toll on the Australian family unit.

SPEECH.PARA: Just what is this Government's approach to preserving the family unit and the family way of life? Since 1983 the Government's approach has been nothing short of contempt for the Australian family and the values it espouses. This Government has continually propped up programs and policies for alternative lifestyles while at the same time neglecting marriage and the family as being the basic unit of our society. Labor's shameful track record includes: Encouraging family breakdown through the welfare system; awarding dubious grants and financial assistance to minority groups; allowing the power of the Equal Opportunities Commission and the Human Rights Commission to intrude on the rights of individuals; permitting the screening of blasphemous and offensive film materials such as the film Hail Mary; and failing to act on the expanding X-rated film industry currently operating from the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. In the 1986-87 Budget Labor saw fit to introduce a young homeless allowance for 16- and 17-year olds. Families throughout Australia are now finding that for some 16- and 17-year olds this allowance provides an incentive for them to leave home.

The Government's contempt for the family unit can be clearly seen in a recent proposal to allow girls under the age of consent and yet living in de facto relationships to receive social security benefits at the married rate. It was only after considerable pressure from the National Party of Australia that the Government was forced to back away from this unjustifiable action. How could this Government have considered for even one minute that it had a right to use taxpayers' funds through the social welfare system to subsidise and encourage immoral behaviour? The sad fact is that Labor has continually shown that it has no hesitation in squandering public money on groups whose activities are not acceptable to the vast majority of Australians. Instead of providing young people with the incentive to stay with their families and to gain an education or employment, this Government is encouraging them to leave home early and to rely on Commonwealth assistance.

At the same time, this Government has seen fit to neglect the real needs of Australian families. It has awarded taxpayers' money to way-out groups. Millions of dollars have been spent on projects that to the majority of taxpayers would be highly questionable. People are also fed up with the ridiculous manner in which the Human Rights Commission and Equal Opportunities Commission Act and the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act intrude into their everyday lives. Under this Federal legislation it is not now possible to place an advertisement in a newspaper asking for a married couple to fill employment or accommodation vacancies. A constituent writing to me on this matter stated:
It appears we Australian citizens cannot now legally advertise for married people, but we can legally advertise for gay mates, friends, partners-you name it.

Clearly, this sort of Government interference should not be tolerated. This Government should come clean and inform Australians why it objects to the term `married'. As I have said previously in this House, perhaps given its preoccupation with social engineering, it has failed to realise that the vast majority of Australians believe in the institution of marriage. Ordinary decent Australians and their families are being placed at the bottom of this Government's priorities. Twelve months ago, a large number of Australians approached this Government over the screening of the film Hail Mary. The Government did nothing. The then Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said:
But I think the issue is probably best dealt with in the sense that those who want to see it will see it and the majority who, perhaps, do not want to see it should avoid it.

The Government seems to have adopted a similar attitude towards allowing X-rated videos to flourish in both the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. All States have banned X-rated videos, and yet, the Federal Government will not act to stop this material being sold through the post from the Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory. Our nation's capital is now the porn capital of Australia and yet Labor allows this degrading industry to continue to grow.

This Government should hang its head in shame at its neglect of the rights of Australian families. Australian families cannot trust this Government. The rhetoric does not match its actions. The National Party is committed to ensuring that government programs, policies and grants do not encourage alternative lifestyles which are repugnant to the community at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been detailing some of the strange developments and events in Queensland. I am up to item 27 which I have identified as `the former Press Secretary'. Allen Callaghan, a former Australian Broadcasting Association journalist, joined Premier Joh as Press Secretary in 1971 and departed in 1979. Despite strong opposition from the Public Service, Callaghan was appointed to the newly created position of Deputy Co-ordinator of Culture, National Parks and Recreation. Five years later, in 1984, he was promoted to head the Department and was appointed a member of the Queensland Day Committee. His wife Judith was the Committee's Executive Officer.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, Allen and Judith Callaghan were corrupted by whatever it is that pervades some areas of public life in Queensland. In November 1986 Judith Callaghan was released from gaol after serving three months of a two and a half year sentence for misappropriating more than $44,000 of public money. Most of the money had been acquired from the Queensland Film Corporation while her husband was Chairman.

In April 1987 Allen Callaghan was gaoled for four years for dishonestly applying $43,574 of public funds to his own use between October 1979 and October 1985. Callaghan has pleaded guilty to 124 charges. As head of the Arts, National Parks and Sport Department, he had been earning over $1,000 a week. The Crown Prosecutor said that the expenses which Mr Callaghan had claimed `could only be described as extravagance, luxury and self-indulgence'.

Item 28 concerns a Minister. The National Times in 1986 said that Queensland Government Minister Russ Hinze had been labelled by some as `conflict of interest personified' in a State where conflict of interest had become institutionalised. It said:

As Local Government Minister, he is also a developer. As Main Roads Minister, he doubles up as a major gravel supplier. As Racing Minister, he owns more than 100 race horses. In response to criticism he says `Too bloody bad'.

Russ Hinze's companies have had remarkable luck in raising loans. In addition to a loan from the Moscow Narodny Bank, loans have also come from the International Pacific Corporation and the Euro-Asian Bank which also lent $3m to a Bjelke-Petersen company. The Hinze racehorse stud company, Waverley Park, has been able to bypass financial institutions. The Lesley Corporation's Coral Gardens Waterways Estate in the Albert Shire where Hinze lives stalled in 1981. As Minister for Local Government, Hinze approved the rezoning of a further 80 hectares, and land sales resumed. In 1984 the Lesley Corporation lent Waverley Park $35,000.

Eddie Kornhauser, the developer of the $120m Paradise Centre in Surfers Paradise, lent Waverley Park $50,000. Kornhauser said that the loan carried a commercial rate of interest but he was not sure when it had to be repaid. He said:
Hinze said at the time it would be if he retired from parliament or something.
An $80,000 loan in 1981 from a company called Cowrie Corporation was written off in 1984. The newspaper Times on Sunday has been unable to establish the identity of the Cowrie Corporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two central issues, apart from tax, that will dominate the forthcoming election. First, there are the severely reduced living standards of Australians, especially one income families, under this Hawke Labor Government. Ordinary Australian families are hurting, and only Ministers who have completely lost touch with the grass roots of what is actually happening out there to Australians, and especially to one income families, could be unaware of this.

SPEECH.PARA: The second key issue is the boost to the power of the trade unions-more correctly the union bosses-which will inevitably occur if, unhappily, Labor were to win the election. The clear intent of the Labor Party can be seen in the Industrial Relations Bill which was introduced into the Parliament a fortnight ago, but hastily relegated to the bottom of the Notice Paper on Tuesday last as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) psyched himself up to call an early election.

The Industrial Relations Bill was no hastily conceived measure. Rather, it was the product of long and exhaustive deliberation by the Government dating right back to when it assumed office in 1983. The Minister responsible for the Bill, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), clearly set out the process by which the Bill came into being in his speech introducing the Bill. He recounted how the Government established a tripartite committee of review into Australian industrial relations law and systems soon after the Government came into office in 1983, how the Government in its charter to the committee was concerned that all avenues should be explored to ensure that Australia would have the most appropriate industrial relations law and systems, how the Hancock Committee Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems reported in April 1985, and how since then there have been extensive consultations on its recommendations not all of which, after due consideration, are taken up in the Bill. After all this, the Bill was finally introduced into the Parliament a fortnight ago making changes to the existing system which are `extensive without being a ``leap in the dark'' ' and so on.

My point is that there can be no question that the Bill truly embodies Labor's considered authentic views, its policy, on what should be the shape of Australia's industrial relations law and systems. As I have said, the policy is a central issue in the forthcoming election because the Labor Party policy is to put the trade unions above, outside, the ordinary law of this land, to create in effect one very protective set of laws and courts, the so-called Labour Court jurisdiction for the unions and another set of law and courts for everyone else. It is a system of industrial apartheid as it has aptly been referred to. In particular, the policy is to emasculate the very important sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act, the `John Howard laws' of 1977 against secondary boycotts. These are the laws under which was enforced the abandonment of the enormously disruptive industrial action by the plumbers recently which was fouling up work on a range of major building sites. By an action in the Federal Court of Australia under this section of the law leading to the granting of an injunction and the imposing of fines there was a quick restoration of industrial sanity and normal work. The Mudginberri situation, well known to honourable members, was another notable case in point, where an employer under blatant union attack gained redress via a section 45d action.

The policy of the Labor Party embodied in the Industrial Relations Bill is an abject sell-out to union muscle. It is clear evidence that for the Hawke-Keating Labor Party, as for its predecessor Labor parties, when it gets down to a choice between what is good for the trade unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and what is good for Australia and Australians as a whole, nothing has really changed about the ALP-the unions win hands down. So at the 11 July election Australians have a clear choice to vote for the Prime Minister and return the Labor Party, and the trade unions will be put above the law, which is bad for businesses, big and small, and bad for the majority of Australian workers, bad for investment and for the country itself-or to vote for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr John Howard) and all Australians will be treated equally before and under the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of parliament for a number of years now, I realise that some aspects of life in politics are ugly. I have seen some people walking around with knives in their backs, and I am aware of the intrigue and treachery that from time to time goes on around us. However, I am shocked to learn that such things, and even worse things, are going on in our universities and institutes of higher education. One would expect that such places are centres of learning and excellence and that intrigue and back-stabbing are not prevalent in the world of academia.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, however, I came across an interesting memorandum sent to the Director of the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education, by the Head of the School of Engineering, Dr Ken Spriggs. Before I read the memo, let me first inform the House of the circumstances which prompted Dr Spriggs' letter. In mid-1986 the Head of the School of Social Sciences at the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education, Mr Peter Harwood, informed the Institute's academic staff association that he could not recommend tenure for Dr Hicks at the end of his two-year probationary period. The grounds for his decision were: Firstly, Ron Hicks' coolness towards students; secondly Ron Hicks' unavailability for consultation with students; and, thirdly, Ron Hicks' refusal to talk to or follow instructions given by Peter Harwood.

After a number of meetings, in December 1986, Mr Peter Harwood finally admitted that all the concerns he had raised earlier about Dr Hicks had been satisfactorily resolved. However, he advised the meeting that he still had a `feeling' about Dr Hicks and for this reason could not confirm tenure. Consequently, Dr Hicks approached the Director of the Institute and suggested the establishment of an independent inquiry into the matter. Dr Kennedy agreed. The inquiry was made up of one academic, Mr Bill Battersby, Senior Lecturer in Economics, and the Assistant Director of the Institute, Mr Jerry Smart. The inquiry confirmed that the concerns expressed by Peter Harwood had been resolved and suggested confirmation of tenure for Dr Hicks.

However, the Director refused to make a decision and now denies that any such inquiry took place. In addition, Peter Harwood has been working behind the scenes in an attempt to prejudice Dr Hicks in any redress that he may seek in this matter. I will now read to the House excerpts of the memorandum from Dr Ken Spriggs, Head of the School of Engineering, to Dr Kennedy, the Director of the Institute, which was prompted by these developments. I quote:

Thank you for your reply of 20th February, 1987 to my memo expressing concern as to the Institute's present industrial relations. You expressed some worries as to what I only attempted to allude. I will spell out my concerns in greater detail.
I was referring to the following when I said some heads of schools generously interpret institute policy in their favour . . .
Dr Spriggs then went on to say:

Heads of schools do not teach students. We are allowed actively to pursue financially profitable outside activities . . . heads of schools earn close to $60,000 per annum in salary. Additional income can be earned with other salaries as in the case of Peter Harwood as Chairman of the LRC (Latrobe Regional Commission) . . .

I have already received complaints from students that the heads of School of Business and Social Sciences have been soliciting them to issue complaints about their academic staff. Life for the administration could become difficult if the student union or the staff association obtain this information.
Dr Spriggs concluded his memo by saying:

`Our activities would not stand up to close scrutiny' refers to the four or five presently aggrieved academic staff or the staff association or even the student union who could take issue with any or all of the above mentioned topics. If our political masters learn of our work practices some embarrassing questions could be asked. I believe it is essential to maintain a lower public profile with regards to industrial issues. I repeat let's forget about these `Jewish trouble makers' and allow us to continue to enjoy a peaceful profitable existence.
All the factors that I have put before the House lead me to ask why Mr Peter Harwood hates Dr Hicks? Is it because Dr Hicks is a Jew or for some other reason?

However, be that as it may, the central point to be made in this instance is that this episode at the Institute is revolting and it is time that an impartial external commission of inquiry is established without delay to look into all aspects of anti-semitic and other victimisation at the Institute. Only such an inquiry can ensure and put to rest criticisms and allegations of discrimination, nepotism and blatant anti-semitism at the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education. It is also the only way the taxpayers of Australia can be assured that money earmarked for education is spent appropriately on teaching and advancing knowledge and not on the promotion of personal vendettas and racial hatred and bigotry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that I wish to raise tonight concerns the home care service in New South Wales. It is most important to the aged people of Australia that they have the assistance of the home care service, particularly in view of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 that was adopted in this Parliament only a week or so ago. I commend the service because over a period of years it has certainly contributed towards the care of the aged in the community. Tonight I will briefly refer to a concern that I have in relation to the Nelson Bay area within my electorate of Lyne. I have been concerned for quite a while with regard to the financial assistance available to the home care service at Nelson Bay. The area is very close to Newcastle, is one of the most prominent retirement and seaside areas of Australia, and is an area that attracts many aged Australians. For the past 12 years a local home care group has operated in this area to assist and arrange for labour force assistance to the aged within this community. I am concerned that over the last few years little extra funding, if any, has been made available to that group to meet the demands of the local area.

SPEECH.PARA: I was in Nelson Bay only about a week ago and I spoke with representatives of the local home care service. They are ladies who speak on behalf of a committee comprising at least 12 people who represent all the service groups and health groups within this community. They are concerned about the great number of aged people and others within the community who cannot be assisted by the home care service simply because not enough money is available to them. They pointed out to me that they are able to meet the requirements of only about 120 residents in the area, although there is a demand approaching nearly 180 in the community. They have on staff 20 ladies who are very familiar with the needs of the community and are very satisfactory workers so far as the committee is concerned.

I appeal to the Minister for Community Services (Mr Hurford)-and I have written to him putting the case of the Nelson Bay Committee-to have a particular look at the needs of this area in view of its growing significance and the fact that there are so many aged people in the community and in view of the hard work that has been done by the committee and staff and because of the general demands that must be met in future years. I do not take to task the Government's policy in this area, but I think we need more care for the aged in their own homes. If the Government is going to meet the needs of the community in this respect, that assistance must be made available because meals on wheels, the home care service and other health assistance agencies are most important to these people. Many of these people have come from the metropolitan area and from other States to live in Nelson Bay because of its geographical situation and because of the medical services available both there and nearby at Newcastle. Therefore, it is important that we do our utmost to assist this voluntary group of people within the community who have meant so much to the aged. I understand from the ladies involved that there is a move to actually create a full time office of home care within the Port Stephens Shire area. That concerns me. I have no great objection to that as long as the autonomy of this group of people at Nelson Bay is maintained because they have a history of being able to cater for this area. Their demands are such that I think they need as much assistance as possible. I appeal to the Minister for Community Services and ask him to do what he possibly can to assist in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was outraged and somewhat surprised at the smut purveyed by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) early this evening in the guise of moral rectitude.
—Order! The honourable member will be careful not to impugn or cast any aspersions on honourable members.

—I am sorry about that, Madam Speaker; I will reword it. I am trying to make a direct comment about something which outraged me. I was outraged at the false accusations against the Government made by the honourable member for Fisher this evening in the guise of his own moral rectitude. How dare he even suggest, let alone declare, that members of the Government have not supported the institution of marriage or the family; even more, that he should declare that we on this side have in some way encouraged degrading practices within Australia. He is wrong and his logic is twisted. The honourable member for Fisher giving of an allowance to homeless 16- to 17-year-olds who lack the privileged position which he implied creates a privileged position for them which somehow equates with moral superiority.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is aware of the position of parents of children of that age who are trying to afford to bring them up; and it is also aware of the number of young people who have come from rural areas and who are out on the streets without parental support. It was for this reason that the Government introduced unemployment benefits for 16- and 17-year-olds. When the Government was forced because of the financial situation in Australia to cut back that unemployment benefit, we introduced a $25 job search payment and an additional payment of $25 for those young people who are in a bad economic situation. In some ways, the comments by the honourable member for Fisher equate with the National Party's attack on supporting parents in Queensland. Statements have been made in Queensland that single parents who stay by their children instead of going off to follow a larger and more comfortable wage are somehow not part of a real family. The National Party has not considered the situation of a young man or woman-most often a woman-whose partner deserts or whose family breaks apart. One day he or she is a respectable part of the community, attending parents and citizens meetings, belonging to the local tennis club and paying off a house, car and furniture. The next day, he or she is suddenly placed in the horrific position of being a supporting parent. Such people can no longer afford to pay off the house, the car of the furniture. Their income is reduced to about $100 a week, plus the child allowance that is payable. Because such people stay by their families, they have been attacked by the National Party in Queensland as being somehow immoral and not up to the standard of other people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you give the honour- able member for Gippsland notice?

—Is this to be a part of the National Party's campaign in the 1987 election? I did not have time to give the honourable member for Fisher notice. He has only just made the statement. I did not intend to speak, but I was really upset at the way in which he attacked people on this side without giving us notice. The honourable member linked the Australian Labor Party with video pornography. In the 1984 election campaign, the Hawke Government's attempts to restrain the flow of hard porn into Australia and its blatant sale over the counter were misrepresented as actually opening the floodgates. The opposite of the true situation was put forward. That campaign was actually carried out in churches and community organisations which, in good faith, believed the things that were said.

SPEECH.PARA: What is moral about misrepresenting the assets test on pensioners? Again in the last election campaign, pensioners who were able to retain their full pension were told by Opposition members in Lilley that they would lose their full pension. I have mentioned before that I know of pensioners who withdrew their money from their banks, put it into a fund, which was said to return money, and which turned out to be a shonkey fund, and lost it all. That was real immorality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I again have with me in Canberra two students from my electorate who are here to see at first hand the workings of the national capital and the Parliament of Australia. As you would agree, Madam Speaker, they have been here during a very exciting week. This is the tenth occasion on which I have invited students from senior high schools in my electorate of O'Connor to visit Canberra. The two young ladies, who are in the chamber tonight, are Stephanie Tonkin and Michelle Mader. Stephanie, whilst living in the small community of Coomberdale, attends school in the town of Moora a few kilometres away at the Central Midlands Senior High School. Moora is located approximately 180 kilometres north of Perth and is a community with a population of 1,750. Michelle is from the District of Woodanilling and attends the Katanning Senior High School, which requires her to travel around 50 kilometres a day. Katanning is 260 kilometres south-east of Perth and has a population of approximately 5,300. The girls have contributed all the material for this speech and, as honourable members will see, both Stephanie and Michelle are very proud of their home towns and the schools that they are representing here today.

SPEECH.PARA: Central Midlands District High School, located at Moora, has approximately 280 students and 30 teachers. Although small when compared with city high schools, Central Midlands offers a vital service to the people of Moora and districts. Many subjects are offered to the students and sport is also a major part of their learning activities. Katanning high school has approximately 650 students and 50 teachers and offers a friendly student-teacher relationship. Subjects are varied and include law, photography and horticulture. This school offers education to a large district. Sport also plays a major role at Katanning and a wide range of activities is offered to students. Both schools have residential hostels located close by, thus offering accommodation to those students living in outlying areas who are unable to travel daily to school by public or private transport. The opportunity to board is available under expert supervision. The service offered is excellent and both hostels are well patronised and have waiting lists of many years.

Katanning has become a centre for Christmas and Cocos Islanders who have chosen to migrate to the mainland and have assimilated into the local community exceptionally well, bringing with them a new religion to the district. They regularly go to the mosque to pray and most follow their traditional way of life. I was fortunate to be a guest of the Moslem community when its mosque was dedicated by the Tunku Abdul Rahman of Malaysia. Moora proposes to establish a silica mine near the town and this will be one of only four in Australia. The ore from the mine will eventually be used in the production of silicon chips, solar cells and alloys worldwide, thus bringing the exciting era of high technology to the district. Katanning senior high school has produced a number of winners over the years, the latest being Yein Wei Ong, who won the Western Australian State spelling competition-a grand achievement.

Each year a number of exchange students from overseas arrive in Australia to attend a host school and community for varying periods from a few weeks to one year. Both Katanning and Central Midlands senior high schools participate in these student exchange programs, thereby enabling local students to learn about a completely new culture and society. Many friendships are initiated with these exchange students and contacts are made with future travel plans in the mind of many. Overseas students who have been involved in these programs have come from countries such as South Africa, West Germany, the United States of America, Denmark, Japan and the Central American country of Panama.

Both districts are major wheat and sheep producing areas of Western Australia and contribute to Australia's export earnings through wheat, wool, sheepmeat and live sheep exports. Both districts are served by regular rail and road transport. Katanning has the largest sheep sale yards in Western Australia, outside of the metropolitan area, and is also a major administrative centre for co-operative bulk handling, housing the principal authority that handles the transport of grain. The sand plain region of Moora is abundant with natural wildflowers of which Western Australia is both proud and famous. These wildflowers are in great demand in Europe and Asia and for the last 10 years Moora has been involved in the export of these wildflowers. It is now developing into a major export industry, as I have said a number of times in this Parliament.

During their stay in Canberra, the girls have seen most of the sights, including the Australian War Memorial and Black Mountain Tower. They have attended several sessions of the Parliament, including Question Time in the Senate and the House of Representatives and, of course, they have met with you, Madam Speaker. Both Stephanie and Michelle thank their schools for the opportunity to visit Canberra and experience at first hand the workings of the Parliament. I am extremely happy to have had both Stephanie and Michelle in Canberra with me this week. They are great ambassadresses not only for Coomerdale and Woodanilling and their schools, but also for Western Australia. I thank you, Madam Speaker, for your assistance in allowing me to deliver this speech on their behalf tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recent reports of the discovery of DDT in Australian meat exports to the United States of America and of the subsequent risks that discovery imposes on future export sales highlight the endemic use of pesticides in Australia. That DDT imposes health risks is no longer in doubt. The publication of Silent Spring exposed the ecological changes which are occurring within our environment and the dangers that those changes bring to the health of ourselves and our children. DDT is included in the chlorinated hydrocarbon group of chemicals which also include dieldrin, aldrin, chlordane and heptachlor. All of these chemicals are widely used in Australian agriculture and in domestic areas to kill insect pests such as termites and spiders. Despite their widespread and generally unregulated use, little is known of the long term effect on human beings exposed to them. It is, however, known that chlorinated hydrocarbons are carcinogenic. A risk analysis of chemicals used for termite control published by the United States Environmental Protection Agency in November 1983 concluded that there were major uncertainties. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The risk assessment for these chemicals is incomplete because of the lack of definitive data on the extent of human exposure, the amount of exposure, and, most importantly, data on the critical biological end point in humans exposed to these chemicals.

It was reported in the Age on Tuesday, 12 November 1983 that Mr Don Mathews of the Victorian Chemical Laboratory, a State government authority, believed that the training of registered operators of these chemicals could be improved. In other words, the present training of registered operators was insufficient. There is ample evidence that this is the case. It is common practice in many areas in Australia that the ground on which new housing is to be built and existing houses are sprayed to destroy insect pests.

I recall a case in which I was involved concerning a Mr Peter Wilson of Warrandyte in the State of Victoria. Mr Wilson had his house sprayed to remove termites and insect pests. Some time later, concerned at the odour remaining in his house, he called for an investigation to be made as to the chemical used and its safety. Tests disclosed that one of the chlorinated hydrocarbon group of chemicals had been used and that the strength and amount used was excessive. In fact, the house was unfit for human habitation. Mr Wilson went through a difficult and costly process to make that house safe for himself, his wife and children. The long term effect on Mr Wilson and his family has not been determined. There was no prosecution of the registered operator, no removal of his licence and no determination as to the safety of other houses sprayed by him and the risks to those families.

A feature of the chlorinated hydrocarbon group of chemicals is their ability to invade air and dust particules and hence invade the human body through toxic effect on the skin. One of the great problems is that we are finding in Australia that the milk of mothers is being affected quite heavily by the use of these chemicals. Choice magazine reported and documented a case in Perth concerning the use of heptachlor where a woman's milk, some 10 months after the use of this chemical, was defective. This mother was feeding a child. A survey tested 40 women for pesticide levels in breast milk and it showed that they had dieldrin levels 37 times the `safe' level applicable to the babies they were feeding with their milk.

These recorded levels of chemicals stored in the tissues of mothers is only the tip of the iceberg. This situation is occurring, despite State regulations controlling the use of the chemicals and requiring domestic users to be licensed. In agricultural areas massive quantities of these chemicals are being used without any control whatsoever. The users have no knowledge or concept of the dangers inherent to our ecological balance or the risks to humans.

In a well publicised and documented incident in the western part of Victoria, the use of chlorinated hydrocarbon chemicals in a dairy district resulted in pasture so contaminated that the milk collected was unfit for human consumption. When such chemicals are sprayed there is no control to prevent the absorption of the chemical into adjoining houses and into humans. Because we do not know the long term effects of even small doses, we may be sitting on a health problem of grave proportions.

There are grave problems in this area and I am greatly concerned that we are pouring tonnes of these chemicals into Australia at the moment. There is little or no control and I believe it is time for a national attempt to set forth a code of conduct and regulations controlling their use. If we do not, the risk is that our food exports, as exposed by the recent case relating to DDT in exported meat, will become so grave that no country will buy contaminated meat from Australia. The risk to our health, to our children's health and to the export market is grave.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I raise tonight concerns the foreign tax credit scheme which comes into operation on 1 July for professional sportsmen and sportswomen. The implications of the scheme will be quite significant and could be reasonably described as the equivalent of what used to be referred to as the brain drain. This matter was referred to in the House during Question Time on 29 April when my predecessor as the shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), addressed a question to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) concerning the implications of the foreign tax credit scheme. In part, the question stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Is the Minister aware that an Australian resident sportsman who, after 1 July, wins a major tournament overseas and pays tax in that country will then pay additional Australian tax? What will the Minister do about the sportsmen and women who are contemplating leaving Australia and basing themselves overseas because of Australia's high taxes, together with the new foreign tax credit scheme that will operate after 1 July?

The Minister then replied that he would take up the matter with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to check the fine detail. Essentially, he suggested that the implication in the question was incorrect. The Minster then came into the House the next day after Question Time and said:

I was not quite sure of the answer yesterday and did not want to give the honourable member inaccurate information. But I am pleased to tell the House that, as usual, he was wrong. Honourable members will not be surprised about that-he was wrong again.

There was then some interjection between the Minister and the honourable member for McPherson. The honourable member for McPherson said by way of interjection: `They have to pay again'. The Minister responded: `They do not pay again. They get a credit for the tax that they pay overseas'. The interjections continued, but the Minister completely refuted the implication of the question. The Minister then provided the honourable member for McPherson with a more detailed response, part of which included the statement:
If the foreign country is one with which Australia has a double tax treaty then this is not a new tax treatment; it was a feature of the former Government's tax system.

Whilst the Minister may have checked his facts to some degree, I say that I have checked the matter further and have found the Minister's answer is in fact quite wrong. The Minister said that when an Australian sports professional wins a professional event and pays tax in a foreign country that tax would be calculated as a credit against the total tax bill for which that person would be liable in Australia. He said that there was nothing new about that. Of course he was referring to the situation that will pertain after 1 July. The fact is that prior to 1 July a professional sports man or woman who won an event and received prize money overseas would not have to pay additional tax in Australia. I refer the Minister to Article 13 of the tax treaty between, for example, Australia and the United Kingdom. I refer to the CCH publication, which I think is generally highly regarded. It states:

If the United Kingdom earnings of Australian entertainers and athletes touring the United Kingdom are subjected to tax in the United Kingdom, Australia would exempt those earnings from its tax under sec. 23 (q) of the Assessment Act.

In other words, if one wins the British Open and pays #20,000 in tax, when one gets home one will pay no more tax. However, after 1 July that person will pay the Australian tax. Because we have internationally high tax levels more tax will have to be paid here than would have to be paid in most of the overseas countries that sports men or women, for example, would compete within. It means that in Australia after 1 July a person will have to top up in relation to payment of tax, and I point out that in this regard the Minister was completely wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes that I have available to me I want to raise an issue concerning public safety in my electorate. I draw the attention of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to a proposal to build six or eight dolphins adjacent to Spectacle Island in the Parramatta River near Drummoyne. I have raised this matter because, as honourable members might know, ammunition is brought overnight from Newington on the Paramatta River to Spectacle Island and then the next day it is taken to Garden Island and the naval ships. This whole procedure of bringing ammunition through heavily populated, residential harbourside suburbs must cease. The ammunition must be taken down to Jervis Bay. This whole public safety issue worries me greatly.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been approached by some of the representatives of the Sea Scouts on Snapper Island who are being evacuated from Snapper Island to Elizabeth Bay or Rushcutters Bay on the grounds of public safety. This worries me greatly because I have been shown a map of what is supposed to be a blast area, which includes part of Hunter's Hill and seems to go in to Drummoyne, which is in my electorate. I know that the procedures are foolproof, that the ammunition is incapable of being charged and exploding, but there is always the risk of saboteurs or of human error. I call on the Minister to have a look at this matter and to stop any development in the Spectacle Island area and to prevent the storage of ammunition at this site.
